analyzed: tatra na kevalam ekam manaḥ eva api tu manasaḥ vṛttayaḥ sarvāḥ tu ak ādi indriya rūpāḥ sva viṣayān anubhāvya anartha kāriṇyaḥ iti āha mātrāḥ indriya grāhya viṣayāḥ
translated: There, not only the mind, but also all the modifications of the mind, in the form of the sense organs such as the eye, cause harm by experiencing their respective objects. Thus he says: The sense objects are grasped by the senses.

original: teṣāṃ sparśā anubhavāḥ /
analyzed: teṣām sparśāḥ anubhavāḥ
translated: Their contacts are experiences.

original: śītoṣṇety āgamāpāyina iti yad eva śītalajalādikam uṣṇakāle sukhadam /
analyzed: śīta uṣṇa iti āgama apāyinaḥ iti yat eva śītala jala ādikam uṣṇa kāle sukha dam
translated: Cold and hot are impermanent. What gives pleasure in hot weather, such as cool water,

original: tad eva śītakāle duḥkhadam ato 'niyatatvād āgamāpāyitvāc ca tān viṣayānubhavān titikṣasva sahasva /
analyzed: tat eva śīta kāle duḥkha dam atas niyata tvāt āgama apāyi tvāt ca tān viṣaya anubhavān titikṣasva sahasva
translated: the same gives pain in cold weather. Therefore, because they are uncertain and impermanent, bear, endure those experiences of objects.

original: teṣāṃ sahanam eva śāstravihito dharmaḥ /
analyzed: teṣām sahanam eva śāstra vihitaḥ dharmaḥ
translated: Bearing them is itself the dharma enjoined by the scriptures.

original: nahi māghe māsi jalasya duḥkhatvabuddhyaiva śāstre vihitaḥ snānarūpo dharmas tyajyate /
analyzed: nahi māghe māsi jalasya duḥkha tva buddhyā eva śāstre vihitaḥ snāna rūpaḥ dharmaḥ tyajyate
translated: For, in the month of Magha, the religious duty in the form of bathing, which is enjoined by the scriptures, is not abandoned merely by the idea that water is painful.

original: dharma eva kāle sarvānarthanivartako bhavati /
analyzed: dharmaḥ eva kāle sarva anartha nivartakaḥ bhavati
translated: Religion itself, when performed at the proper time, removes all evils.

original: evam eva ye putrabhrātrādyotpattikāle dhanādyupārjanakāle ca sukhadās ta eva mṛtyukāle duḥkhadā āgamāpāyino
analyzed: evam eva ye putra bhrātra adya utpatti kāle dhana ādi upārjana kāle ca sukha dāḥ te eva mṛtyu kāle duḥkha dāḥ āgama apāyinaḥ
translated: In the same way, those who give happiness at the time of the birth of a son, brother, etc., and at the time of earning wealth, etc., are the very ones who give pain at the time of death. They are impermanent, coming and going.

original: 'nityās tān api titikṣasva /
analyzed: nityāḥ tān api titikṣasva
translated: Bear with them too.

original: na tu tadanurodhena yuddharūpaḥ śāstravihitaḥ svadharmas tyājyo vihitadharmānācaraṇaṃ khalu kāle mahānarthakṛd eveti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: na tu tad anurodhena yuddha rūpaḥ śāstra vihitaḥ svadharmaḥ tyājyaḥ vihita dharma an ācaraṇam khalu kāle mahā anartha kṛt eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But the duty enjoined by the scriptures, in the form of fighting, should not be abandoned out of regard for them. For, indeed, the non-performance of enjoined duties at the proper time is a great evil, this is the idea.

original: baladevaḥ / nanu bhīṣmādayo mṛtāḥ kathaṃ bhaviṣyantīti tadduḥkhanimittaḥ śoko mābhūt /
analyzed: baladevaḥ nanu bhīṣma ādayaḥ mṛtāḥ katham bhaviṣyanti iti tad duḥkha nimittaḥ śokaḥ
translated: Balarama. Now, if you think that since Bhishma and others are dead, let there be no grief caused by their sorrow,

original: tadvicchedaduḥkhanimittas tu me manaprabhṛtīni pradahantīti cet tatrāha mātreti /
analyzed: tad viccheda duḥkha nimittaḥ tu me mana prabhṛtīni pradahanti iti ced tatra āha mātrā iti
translated: but let my mind and other organs be burnt by the sorrow caused by the separation from them, then he says matra etc.

original: mātrās tv agādīndriyavṛttayaḥ mīyante paricchidyante viṣayā abhir iti vyutpatteḥ /
analyzed: mātrāḥ tu ak ādi indriya vṛttayaḥ mīyante paricchidyante viṣayāḥ abhiḥ iti vyutpatteḥ
translated: The senses are the functions of the organs beginning with the eye. They are called matras because objects are measured and delimited by them, according to the derivation of the word.

original: sparśās tābhir viṣayāṇām anubhavānte khalu śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkhadā bhavanti /
analyzed: sparśāḥ tābhiḥ viṣayāṇām anubhava ante khalu śīta uṣṇa sukha duḥkha dāḥ bhavanti
translated: At the end of the experience of objects by those [sense faculties], they become the givers of cold, heat, pleasure, and pain.

original: yad eva śītalam udakaṃ grīṣme sukhadaṃ tad eva hemante duḥkhadam ity ato 'niyatatvād āgamāpāyitvāc cānityān asthirāṃs tān titikṣasva sahasva
analyzed: yat eva śītalam udakam grīṣme sukha dam tat eva hemante duḥkha dam iti atas niyata tvāt āgama apāyi tvāt ca anityān asthirān tān titikṣasva sahasva
translated: That very cold water which is pleasant in summer, that very same [water] is painful in winter. Therefore, because they are uncertain and subject to coming and going, endure them, bear them, as impermanent and unstable.

original: etad uktaṃ bhavati māghasnānaṃ duḥkhakaram api dharmatayā vidhānād yathā kriyate tathā bhīṣmādibhiḥ saha yuddhaṃ duḥkhakaram api tathā vidhānāt
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati māgha snānam duḥkha karam api dharmatayā vidhānāt yathā kriyate tathā bhīṣma ādibhiḥ saha yuddham duḥkha karam api tathā vidhānāt
translated: This is what is said: Just as bathing in the Māgha month is performed even though it causes pain because it is enjoined as a duty, in the same way, the battle with Bhīṣma and others should be undertaken even though it causes pain because it is enjoined as a duty.

original: kāryam eva /
analyzed: kāryam eva
translated: It is indeed to be done.

original: tatratyo duḥkhānubhavas tv āgantuko dharmasiddhatvāt soḍhavyaḥ /
analyzed: tatratyaḥ duḥkha anubhavaḥ tu āgantukaḥ dharma siddha tvāt soḍhavyaḥ
translated: The experience of pain there is adventitious, and because it is established as a property of Dharma, it should be endured.

original: dharmāj jñānodayena mokṣalābhe tūttaratra
analyzed: dharmāt jñāna udayena mokṣa lābhe tu uttaratra
translated: But when liberation is attained through the arising of knowledge from Dharma, then

original: tasya nānuvṛttiś ca jñānaniṣṭhā paripākaṃ vinaiva dharmatyāgas tv anarthahetur iti /
analyzed: tasya nā anuvṛttiḥ ca jñāna niṣṭhā paripākam vinā eva dharma tyāgaḥ tu anartha hetuḥ iti
translated: it does not continue. Abandoning Dharma without the maturity of the stage of knowledge is a cause of harm.

original: kaunteya bhārateti padābhyām ubhayakulaśuddhasya te dharmabhraṃśo nocita iti sūcyate ////🔽BhG /
analyzed: kaunteya bhārata iti padābhyām ubhaya kula śuddhasya te dharma bhraṃśaḥ na ucitaḥ iti sūcyate 🔽bhg
translated: By the two words O son of Kuntī, in the Bhārata it is indicated that for you, who are pure in both families, the loss of Dharma is not proper.

original: yaṃ hi na vyathayanty ete puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha /
analyzed: yam hi na vyathayanti ete puruṣam puruṣa ṛṣabha
translated: For, O best of men, he whom these contacts of the senses do not afflict,

original: samaduḥkhasukhaṃ dhīraṃ so 'mṛtatvāya kalpate ////
analyzed: sama duḥkha sukham dhīram saḥ mṛta tvāya kalpate
translated: who is the same in pain and pleasure, and is steadfast, he is fit for immortality.

original: śrīdharaḥ / tatpratikāraprayatnād api tatsahanam evocitaṃ mahāphalatvād ity āha yaṃ hīti /
translated: [Sridhara: Even from the effort to counteract them, it is proper to bear them, because of their great fruit. This is what is said by For, O best of men, he whom...]

original: ete mātrāsparśā yaṃ puruṣaṃ na vyathayanti nābhibhavanti /
analyzed: ete mātrā sparśāḥ yam puruṣam na vyathayanti na abhibhavanti
translated: These contacts of the senses do not afflict, do not overcome, him.

original: same duḥkhasukhe sa tam /
analyzed: same duḥkha sukhe sa tam
translated: He is the same in pain and pleasure.

original: sa tair avikṣipyamāṇo dharmajñānadvārā amṛtatvāya mokṣāya kalpate yogyo bhavati ////🔽madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: sa taiḥ a vikṣipyamāṇaḥ dharma jñāna dvārā amṛta tvāya mokṣāya kalpate yogyaḥ bhavati  madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Being unstirred by them, he is fit, through the knowledge of dharma, for immortality, for liberation.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: [Madhusudana: For immortality means for liberation.]🔽[Visvanatha: For immortality means for liberation.]

original: evaṃ vicāreṇa tattatsahanābhyāse sati te viṣayānubhavāḥ kāle kila nāpi duḥkhayanti /
analyzed: evam vicāreṇa tat tat sahana abhyāse sati te viṣaya anubhavāḥ kāle kila nā api duḥkhayanti
translated: Thus, when one practices bearing them through such reflection, those experiences of objects do not cause pain after some time.

original: yadi ca na duḥkhayanti /
analyzed: yadi ca na duḥkhayanti
translated: And if they do not cause pain,

original: tadātmamuktiḥ svapratyāsannaivety āha yam iti /
analyzed: tadā ātma muktiḥ sva pratyāsannā eva iti āha yam iti
translated: then liberation is very near for him. This is what is said by For, O best of men, he whom...

original: amṛtatvāya mokṣāya ////
analyzed: amṛta tvāya mokṣāya
translated: [Sridhara: For immortality means for liberation.]

original: baladevaḥ / dharmārthaduḥkhasahanābhyāsasyottaratra sukhahetutvaṃ darśayann āha yaṃ hīti /
translated: [Baladeva: Showing that the practice of bearing dharma, wealth and pain is a cause of happiness later on, it is said by For, O best of men, he whom...]

original: ete mātrāsparśāḥ priyāpriyaviṣayānubhāvā yaṃ dhīraṃ dhiyam īrayati dharmeṣv iti
analyzed: ete mātrā sparśāḥ priya apriya viṣaya anubhāvāḥ yam dhīram dhiyam īrayati dharmeṣu iti
translated: These contacts with the objects of sense, which are pleasant and unpleasant, do not disturb the wise man who directs his mind to the objects of duty.

original: vyutpatter dharmaniṣṭhaṃ puruṣaṃ na vyathayanti sukhaduḥkhamūrcchitaṃ na kurvanti
analyzed: vyutpatteḥ dharma niṣṭham puruṣam na vyathayanti sukha duḥkha mūrcchitam na kurvanti
translated: They do not make him intoxicated with pleasure and pain.

original: so 'mṛtatvāya muktaye kalpyate /
analyzed: saḥ mṛta tvāya muktaye kalpyate
translated: He is fit for immortality, for liberation.

original: na tu tādṛśo duḥkhasukhamūrcchita ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: na tu tādṛśaḥ duḥkha sukha mūrcchitaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: he is not like that, intoxicated with pleasure and pain.

original: uktam arthaṃ sphuṭayan puruṣaṃ viśinaṣṭi sameti /
analyzed: uktam artham sphuṭayan puruṣam viśinaṣṭi sama iti
translated: Making clear the meaning stated, he distinguishes the person with the word 'sama' (equal).

original: dharmānuṣṭhānasya kaṣṭasādhyatvād duḥkham anuṣaṅgalabdhaṃ sukhaṃ ca yasya samaṃ bhavati tābhyāṃ mukhamlānitollāsarahitam ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: dharma anuṣṭhānasya kaṣṭa sādhya tvāt duḥkham anuṣaṅga labdham sukham ca yasya samam bhavati tābhyām mukha mlānita ullāsa rahitam iti arthaḥ
translated: Since the performance of duty is difficult to accomplish, he whose pleasure and pain are equal, i.e., free from depression and elation due to those two, is said to be equal.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ /
analyzed: na asataḥ vidyate bhāvaḥ na abhāvaḥ vidyate sataḥ
translated: There is no existence of what is non-existent, nor the existence of what is existent.

original: ubhayor api dṛṣṭo 'ntas tv anayos tattvadarśibhiḥ ////
analyzed: ubhayoḥ api dṛṣṭaḥ ntaḥ tu anayoḥ tattva darśibhiḥ
translated: The end of both of these is seen by the seers of truth.

original: śrīdharaḥ / nanu tathāpi śītoṣṇādikam atiduḥsahaṃ kathaṃ soḍhavyam /
translated: Shridhar: Well, even so, how is the unbearable cold, heat, etc. to be borne?

original: atyantaṃ tatsahane ca kadācid dehanāśaḥ syād ity āśaṅkya tattvavicārataḥ sarvaṃ soḍhuṃ śakyam ity āśayenāha nāsato vidyata iti /
analyzed: atyantam tad sahane ca kadācid deha nāśaḥ syāt iti āśaṅkya tattva vicārataḥ sarvam soḍhum śakyam iti āśayena āha na asataḥ vidyate iti
translated: And if one is able to bear them to the utmost, then there may be destruction of the body. Fearing this, he says, 'Of the non-existent, etc.', with the idea that everything can be borne by the investigation of reality.

original: asato 'nātmadharmatvād avidyamānasya śītoṣṇāder ātmani bhāvaḥ sattā na vidyate /
analyzed: asataḥ na ātma dharma tvāt a vidyamānasya śīta uṣṇa ādeḥ ātmani bhāvaḥ sattā na vidyate
translated: Of the non-existent, i.e., of cold, heat, etc., which are not existent because they are not attributes of the Self, there is no existence, i.e., being, in the Self.

original: tathā sataḥ satsvabhāvasyātmano 'bhāvo nāśo na vidyate /
analyzed: tathā sataḥ sat svabhāvasya ātmanaḥ bhāvaḥ nāśaḥ na vidyate
translated: Similarly, of the existent, i.e., of the Self, which has the nature of existence, there is no non-existence, i.e., destruction.

original: evam ubhayoḥ sadasator anto nirṇayo dṛṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: evam ubhayoḥ sat asatoḥ antaḥ nirṇayaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: Thus, the end, i.e., the decision, of both the existent and the non-existent is seen.

original: kaiḥ / tattvadarśibhiḥ vastuyāthārthyavedibhiḥ /
analyzed: kaiḥ tattva darśibhiḥ vastu yāthārthya vedibhiḥ
translated: By whom? By the seers of truth, i.e., by those who know the reality of things.

original: evambhūtavivekena sahasvety arthaḥ ////
analyzed: evambhūta vivekena sahasva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: bear it with such discrimination.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: etac ca vivekadaśān adhirūḍhān prati uktam /
analyzed: etat ca viveka daśān adhirūḍhān prati uktam
translated: And this is said for those who have attained the stage of discrimination.

original: vastutas tu asaṅgo hy ayaṃ puruṣaḥ iti śruter jīvātmanaś ca sthūlasūkṣmadehābhyāṃ taddharmaiḥ śokamohādibhiś ca sambandho nāsty eva /
analyzed: vastutas tu a saṅgaḥ hi ayam puruṣaḥ iti śruteḥ jīvātmanaḥ ca sthūla sūkṣma dehābhyām tad dharmaiḥ śoka moha ādibhiḥ ca sambandhaḥ na asti eva
translated: But in reality, according to the Upanisadic text, 'This Purusha is unattached' (Br. 3.9.26), the individual Self has no connection with the gross and subtle bodies or with their attributes like sorrow, delusion, etc.

original: tatsambandhasya avidyā kalpitatvād ity āha neti /
analyzed: tad sambandhasya avidyā kalpita tvāt iti āha na iti
translated: Because that connection is imagined by ignorance, he says, 'No' (verse 11).

original: asato 'nātmadharmatvād ātmani jīve avartamānasya śokamohādes tadāśrayasya dehasya ca bhāvaḥ sattā nāsti /
analyzed: asataḥ na ātma dharma tvāt ātmani jīve avartamānasya śoka moha ādeḥ tad āśrayasya dehasya ca bhāvaḥ sattā na asti
translated: Because of the unreality of grief, delusion, etc., and the body which is their substratum, which are not present in the Self, the individual soul, there is no existence, no reality, of the body.

original: tathā sataḥ satyarūpasya jīvātmano 'bhāvo nāśo nāsti /
analyzed: tathā sataḥ satya rūpasya jīvātmanaḥ bhāvaḥ nāśaḥ na asti
translated: Similarly, there is no non-existence, no destruction, of the real individual soul, which is of the nature of reality.

original: tasmād ubhayor etayor asatsator anto nirṇayo 'yaṃ dṛṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt ubhayoḥ etayoḥ asat satoḥ antaḥ nirṇayaḥ yam dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: Therefore, this conclusion is seen regarding both these, the unreal and the real.

original: tena bhīṣmādiṣu tvadādiṣu ca jīvātmasu satyatvād anaśvareṣu dehadaihikavivekaśokamohādayo naiva santi kathaṃ bhīṣmādayo naṅkṣanti /
analyzed: tena bhīṣma ādiṣu tvad ādiṣu ca jīvātmasu satya tvāt anaśvareṣu deha daihika viveka śoka moha ādayaḥ nā eva santi katham bhīṣma ādayaḥ naṅkṣanti
translated: Hence, since the individual souls in Bhishma and others, and in you and others, are real and imperishable, grief, delusion, etc., which are based on the discrimination between the body and the embodied self, do not exist at all. How then can Bhishma and others perish?

original: kathaṃ vā tāṃs tvaṃ śocasīti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: katham vā tān tvam śocasi iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Or how can you grieve for them? This is the idea.

original: baladevaḥ / tad evaṃ bhagavatā pārthasyāsthānāśocitvena tatpāṇḍityam ākṣiptam /
analyzed: baladevaḥ tat evam bhagavatā pārthasya asthāna a śoci tvena tat pāṇḍityam ākṣiptam
translated: Balarama: Thus, the Lord has rebuked Arjuna's scholarship by his grieving for what is unreal.

original: śokaharaṃ ca svopāsanam eva tac copāsopāsakabhedaghaṭitam ity upāsyāj jīvāṃśinaḥ svasmād upāsakānāṃ jīvāṃśānāṃ tāttvikaṃ dvaitam upadiṣṭam
analyzed: śoka haram ca sva upāsanam eva tat ca upāsā upāsaka bheda ghaṭitam iti upāsyāt jīva aṃśinaḥ svasmāt upāsakānām jīva aṃśānām tāttvikam dvaitam upadiṣṭam
translated: And He has taught that His own worship, which removes grief, consists of the distinction between the worshipper and the worshipped, and that the true duality is between the individual souls, who are parts of Him and are the worshipped, and the individual souls, who are parts of Him and are the worshippers.

original: atha yad ātmatattvena tu brahmatattvaṃ dīpopameneha yuktaḥ prapaśyet ŚvetU /
analyzed: atha yat ātma tattvena tu brahma tattvam dīpa upamena iha yuktaḥ prapaśyet śvā tu
translated: Now, O Shvetaketu, one should properly see here the truth of Brahman, which is the same as the truth of the Self, by means of the analogy of the lamp.

original: ity ādāv aṃśasvarūpajñānasyāṃśisvarūpajñānopayogitvaśravaṇāt tad ādau saniṣṭhādīn
analyzed: iti ādau aṃśa svarūpa jñānasya aṃśi svarūpa jñāna upayogi tva śravaṇāt tat ādau saniṣṭha ādīn
translated: Thus, in the beginning, the knowledge of the nature of the parts is heard to be useful for the knowledge of the nature of the part-possessor, therefore, the part-possessor etc.🔽🔽

original: sarvān pratyaviśeṣeṇopadeśyaṃ tac ca dehātmanor vaidharmyadhiyam antarā na syād
analyzed: sarvān prati aviśeṣeṇa upadeśyam tat ca deha ātmanoḥ vaidharmya dhiyam antarā na syāt
translated: Because in such passages as this, the knowledge of the nature of the parts is heard to be useful for the knowledge of the nature of the whole, therefore, that [knowledge of the nature of the parts] should be taught without distinction to all, beginning with the individual soul. And that [knowledge of the nature of the parts] would not be [possible] without the cognition of the dissimilarity between the body and the self.

original: iti tadvaidharmyabodhāyārabhyate nāsata ity ādibhiḥ /🔽asataḥ pariṇāmino dehāder bhāvo 'pariṇāmitvaṃ na vidyate /
analyzed: iti tad vaidharmya bodhāya ārabhyate na āsate iti ādibhiḥ  asataḥ pariṇāminaḥ deha ādeḥ pariṇāmi tvam na vidyate
translated: Therefore, in order to awaken to that dissimilarity, [the text] begins with not of the non-existent and so on.🔽The existence of the changing body and so on, which are non-existent, is not non-changing.

original: sato ' pariṇāmina ātmanas tv abhāvaḥ pariṇāmitvaṃ na vidyate /
analyzed: sataḥ pariṇāminaḥ ātmanaḥ tu abhāvaḥ pariṇāmi tvam na vidyate
translated: But the non-existence of the unchanging self, which is existent, is not changing.

original: dehātmānau pariṇāmāpariṇāmasvabhāvau bhavataḥ /
analyzed: deha ātmānau pariṇāma apariṇāma svabhāvau bhavataḥ
translated: The body and the self have the nature of being changeable and unchangeable, respectively.

original: evam ubhayor asatsacchabditayor dehātmanor
analyzed: evam ubhayoḥ asat sat śabditayoḥ deha ātmanoḥ
translated: Thus, the end, the determination, of both, the body and the self, which are called non-existent and existent,

original: anto nirṇayas tattvadarśibhis tadubhayasvabhāvavedibhiḥ puruṣair dṛṣṭo 'nubhūtaḥ /
analyzed: antar nirṇayaḥ tattva darśibhiḥ tad ubhaya svabhāva vedibhiḥ puruṣaiḥ dṛṣṭaḥ nubhūtaḥ
translated: has been seen, experienced, by those who see the truth, by those who know the nature of both.

original: atrāsacchabdena vinaśvaraṃ dehādi jaḍaṃ sacchabdena tv avinaśvaram ātmacaitanyam ucyate /
analyzed: atra asat śabdena vinaśvaram deha ādi jaḍam sat śabdena tu avinaśvaram ātma caitanyam ucyate
translated: Here, the perishable body and so on, which are inert, are called non-existent, while the imperishable consciousness of the self is called existent.

original: evam eva śrīviṣṇupurāṇe 'pi nirṇītaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ jyotīṃṣi viṣṇur bhuvanāni viṣṇur ViP / / ity upakramya yad asti yan nāsti ca vipravarya
analyzed: evam eva śrī viṣṇupurāṇe nirṇītam dṛṣṭam jyotīṃṣi viṣṇuḥ bhuvanāni viṣṇuḥ vip iti upakramya yat asti yat na asti ca vipra varya
translated: In the same way, it is also ascertained in the Śrī Viṣṇu Purāṇa: The luminaries are Viṣṇu, the worlds are Viṣṇu, O brāhmaṇa, whatever exists or does not exist, O best of brāhmaṇas, is Viṣṇu.

original: ity asti /
analyzed: iti asti
translated: It exists.

original: nāstiśabdavācyayoś cetanajaḍayos tathātvaṃ vastv asti kiṃ kutradcid ity ādibhir nirūpitaḥ /
analyzed: nāsti śabda vācyayoḥ cetana jaḍayoḥ tathātvam vastu asti kim kutradcid iti ādibhiḥ nirūpitaḥ
translated: And the existence and non-existence of the conscious and the insentient denoted by the words exists and does not exist are determined by such statements as Is there anything anywhere? etc.

original: tatra nāsti śabdavācyaṃ jaḍam /🔽astiśabdavātyaṃ tu caitanyam iti svayam eva vivṛtam /
analyzed: tatra na asti śabda vācyam jaḍam  tu caitanyam iti svayam eva vivṛtam
translated: Among them, the insentient denoted by the word does not exist🔽and the consciousness denoted by the word exists is itself explained.

original: yat tu satkāryavādasthāpanāyai tatpadyam ity āhus tanniravadhānaṃ dehātmasvabhāvānabhijñānamohitaṃ prati tanmohavinivṛttaye tatsvabhāvābhijñāpanasya
analyzed: yat tu satkārya vāda sthāpanāyai tat padyam iti āhuḥ tat niravadhānam deha ātma svabhāva anabhijñāna mohitam prati tad moha vinivṛttaye tad svabhāva abhijñāpanasya
translated: But those who say that verse is for establishing the doctrine of existent effects, that is without consideration, because for one who is deluded by not knowing the nature of the self as the body, for the cessation of that delusion, the teaching of its nature

original: prakṛtatvāt ////
analyzed: prakṛta tvāt
translated: is the subject matter.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: avināśi tu tad viddhi yena sarvam idaṃ tatam /
analyzed: avināśi tu tat viddhi yena sarvam idam tatam
translated: But know that to be indestructible by which all this is pervaded.

original: vināśam avyayasyāsya na kaścit kartum arhati ////
analyzed: vināśam avyayasya asya na kaścid kartum arhati
translated: No one can cause the destruction of this imperishable one.

original: śrīdharaḥ / atra satsvabhāvam avināśi vastu sāmānyenoktaṃ tataṃ tatsākṣitvena vyāptaṃ taṃ tu ātmasvarūpam avināśi vināśaśūnyaṃ viddhi jānīhi
translated: Sridhara: Here, the nature of the existent, which is indestructible, is stated in general. It is pervaded by Him as the witness of that. But know that the nature of the Self is indestructible, devoid of destruction.

original: tatra hetum āha vināśam iti ////
analyzed: tatra hetum āha vināśam iti
translated: To state the reason for that, He says, destruction...

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ ity asyārthaṃ spaṣṭayati avināśīti /
analyzed: na abhāvaḥ vidyate sataḥ iti asya artham spaṣṭayati avināśi iti
translated: To clarify the meaning of the existent has no non-existence, he says indestructible...

original: taṃ jīvātmasvarūpaṃ yena sarvam idaṃ śarīraṃ tataṃ vyāptam /
analyzed: tam jīvātma svarūpam yena sarvam idam śarīram tatam vyāptam
translated: Know that the nature of the individual soul is pervaded by Him, by which this entire body is pervaded.

original: nanu śarīramātravyāpicaitanyatve jīvātmano madhyamaparimāṇatvena anityatvaprasaktiḥ / maivam /
analyzed: nanu śarīra mātra vyāpi caitanya tve jīvātmanaḥ madhyama parimāṇa tvena anitya tva prasaktiḥ mā evam
translated: If consciousness pervades only the body, then the individual soul would have a middle-sized dimension and would be subject to destruction. That is not so.

original: sūkṣmāṇām apy ahaṃ jīvaḥ iti bhagavadukteḥ /
analyzed: sūkṣmāṇām api aham jīvaḥ iti bhagavat ukteḥ
translated: Because it is stated by the Lord: I am the subtle individual soul.

original: eṣoṇur ātmā cetasā veditavyo yasmin prāṇaḥ pañcadhā saṃviveśa iti /
analyzed: eṣā uṇuḥ ātmā cetasā veditavyaḥ yasmin prāṇaḥ pañcadhā saṃviveśa iti
translated: This atom-sized Self is to be known by the mind, in which the life-force has entered in five ways.

original: bālāgraśatabhāgasya śatadhā kalpitasya ca /
analyzed: bālāgra śata bhāgasya śatadhā kalpitasya ca
translated: One hundredth part of the tip of a hair is imagined to be one hundred times smaller.

original: bhāgo jīvaḥ sa vijñeyaḥ ŚvetU / iti /
analyzed: bhāgaḥ jīvaḥ sa vijñeyaḥ iti
translated: The individual soul is to be known as that part, O Shvetaketu.🔽Another is seen to be the size of the tip of a thumb.

original: ārāgramātro hy aparo 'pi dṛṣṭaḥ iti śrutibhyaś ca tasya paramāṇuparimāṇatvam eva /
analyzed: ārā agra mātraḥ hi aparaḥ pi dṛṣṭaḥ iti śrutibhyaḥ ca tasya paramāṇu parimāṇa tvam eva
translated: From these Vedic statements, it is clear that its size is that of an atom.

original: tad api sampūrṇadehavyāpiśaktimattvaṃ jatujaṭitasya mahāmaṇer mahauṣadhikhaṇḍasya vā śirasy urasi vā dhṛtasya sampūrṇadehapuṣṭikaraṇaśaktimattvam
analyzed: tat api sampūrṇa deha vyāpi śaktimat tvam jatu jaṭitasya mahā maṇeḥ mahā oṣadhi khaṇḍasya vā śirasi urasi vā dhṛtasya sampūrṇa deha puṣṭi karaṇa śaktimat tvam
translated: That also is like the case of a great gem or a piece of a powerful medicine, which, when worn on the head or the chest, has the power to nourish the entire body.

original: iva nāsamañjasam /
analyzed: iva na asamañjasam
translated: That also, the state of having power that pervades the entire body, is not inconsistent, like the state of having the power to nourish the entire body when a great gem or a piece of powerful medicine is worn on the head or chest.

original: svarganarakanānāyoniṣu gamanaṃ ca tasyopādhipāravaśyād eva /
analyzed: svarga naraka nānā yoniṣu gamanam ca tasya upādhi pāravaśyāt eva
translated: And the going to heaven, hell, and various wombs is due to the influence of limiting adjuncts alone.

original: tad uktaṃ prāṇam adhikṛtya dattātrayeṇa yena saṃsarate pumān iti /
analyzed: tat uktam prāṇam adhikṛtya dattā trayeṇa yena saṃsarate pumān iti
translated: That is stated by Dattatreya with regard to the vital principle: By which a person transmigrates.

original: ataevāsya sarvagatatvam apy agrimaśloke vakṣyamāṇaṃ nāsamañjasam /
analyzed: ataeva asya sarva gata tvam api agrima śloke vakṣyamāṇam nā asamañjasam
translated: Therefore, its omnipresence, which will be stated in the next verse, is not inconsistent.

original: ataevāvyayasya nityasya nityo nityānāṃ cetanaś cetanānām eko bahūnāṃ yo vidadhāti kāmān ŚvetU / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: ataeva avyayasya nityasya nityaḥ nityānām cetanaḥ cetanānām ekaḥ bahūnām yaḥ vidadhāti kāmān śvetu iti śruteḥ
translated: For this very reason, the Śruti says: The imperishable, the eternal, the conscious of the conscious, the one of the many, who grants desires, is Śveta.

original: yad vā / nanu deho jīvātmā paramātmety etad vastutrikaṃ manuṣyatiryagādiṣu sarvatra dṛśyate /
analyzed: yat vā nanu dehaḥ jīvātmā paramātmā iti etat vastu trikam manuṣya tiryak ādiṣu sarvatra dṛśyate
translated: Or, is it not the case that these three things, the body, the individual soul, and the supreme self, are seen everywhere in humans, animals, etc.?

original: tatrādyayor dehajīvayos tattvaṃ nāsato vidyate bhāvaḥ ity anenoktam /
analyzed: tatra ādyayoḥ deha jīvayoḥ tattvam na asataḥ vidyate bhāvaḥ iti anena uktam
translated: There, the truth of the first two, the body and the individual soul, has been stated by Non-existence is not known of what was not.

original: tṛtīyasya paramātmavastunaḥ kiṃ tattvam ity ata āha avināśi tv iti /
analyzed: tṛtīyasya paramātma vastunaḥ kim tattvam iti atas āha avināśi tu iti
translated: What is the truth of the third thing, the supreme self? To that, he says But it is imperishable.

original: tu bhinnopakrame /
analyzed: tu bhinna upakrame
translated: But it is different when the subject is different.

original: paramātmano māyājīvābhyāṃ svarūpataḥ pārthakyād idaṃ jagat ////
analyzed: paramātmanaḥ māyā jīvābhyām svarūpataḥ pārthakyāt idam jagat
translated: This world is different from the Supreme Self and the individual soul in its nature.

original: baladevaḥ / uktaṃ jīvātmadehayoḥ svabhāvaṃ viśadayaty avināśīti dvābhyām /
translated: Balarama: The two verses beginning with The soul is indestructible clarify the nature of the individual soul and the body.

original: taj jīvātmatattvam avināśi nityaṃ viddhi /
analyzed: tat jīvātma tattvam avināśi nityam viddhi
translated: Know that the reality of the individual soul is indestructible and eternal.

original: yena sarvam idaṃ śarīraṃ tataṃ dharmabhūtena jñānena vyāptam asti /
analyzed: yena sarvam idam śarīram tatam dharma bhūtena jñānena vyāptam asti
translated: By which this entire body is pervaded by the dharma-like knowledge.

original: asyāvyayasya parmāṇutvena ca vināśānarhasya vināśaṃ na kaścit sthūlo 'rthaḥ kartum arhati prāṇasyeva dehaḥ /
analyzed: asya avyayasya parma aṇu tvena ca vināśa anarhasya vināśam na kaścid sthūlaḥ rthaḥ kartum arhati prāṇasya iva dehaḥ
translated: No gross object can destroy this imperishable atom-sized soul, just as the body cannot destroy the life-force.

original: iha jīvātmano dehaparimitatvaṃ na pratyetavyam /
analyzed: iha jīvātmanaḥ deha parimita tvam na pratyetavyam
translated: Here, the individual soul should not be understood as limited to the body.

original: eṣo 'ṇur ātmā cetasā veditavyo yasmin prāṇaḥ pañcadhā saṃviveśa ṃuṇḍU / / ity ādiṣu tasya paramāṇutvaśravaṇāt /
analyzed: eṣaḥ ṇuḥ ātmā cetasā veditavyaḥ yasmin prāṇaḥ pañcadhā saṃviveśa ṃuṇḍu iti ādiṣu tasya parama aṇu tva śravaṇāt
translated: In passages such as This atom-sized soul should be known by the mind, in which the life-force has entered in five ways, it is said to be atomic.

original: tādṛśasya nikhiladehavyāptis tu dharmabhūtajñānenaiva syāt /
analyzed: tādṛśasya nikhila deha vyāptiḥ tu dharma bhūta jñānena eva syāt
translated: Such a soul can pervade the entire body only through the knowledge that is its attribute.

original: evam āha bhagavān sūtrakāraḥ guṇād vālokavad Vs / / / iti /
analyzed: evam āha bhagavān sūtrakāraḥ guṇāt vā āloka vat iti
translated: Thus the Blessed Lord of Sages has said: Like light, from its attribute (Sutra 1.1.10).

original: ihāpi svayaṃ vakṣyati yathā prakāśayaty ekaḥ Gītā / ity ādinā ////
analyzed: iha api svayam vakṣyati yathā prakāśayati ekaḥ gītāḥ iti ādinā
translated: Here also he will say by himself, 'As one shines, illuminating all things' (11.40), etc.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg

original: antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ /
analyzed: antavantaḥ ime dehāḥ nityasya uktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ
translated: These bodies are said to be perishable of the eternal embodied one,

original: anāśino 'prameyasya tasmād yudhyasva bhārata ////
analyzed: anāśino prameyasya tasmāt yudhyasva bhārata
translated: Who is imperishable and immeasurable. Therefore, O descendant of Bharata, fight!

original: śrīdharaḥ / āgamāpāyadharmakaṃ sandarśyati antavanta iti /
translated: Sridhar: Showing that the body has the quality of coming and going, (the Lord) says, 'These bodies are perishable,' etc.

original: anto vināśo vidyate yeṣāṃ te antavantaḥ /
analyzed: antaḥ vināśaḥ vidyate yeṣām te antavantaḥ
translated: Those that have destruction are perishable.

original: nityasya sarvadaikarūpasya śarīriṇaḥ śarīravataḥ /
analyzed: nityasya sarvadā eka rūpasya śarīriṇaḥ śarīravataḥ
translated: Of the eternal, always of one form, embodied one, having a body.

original: ataevānāśino vināśarahitasya aprameyasyaparicchinnasyātmana ime sukhaduḥkhādidharmakadehā uktās tattvadarśibhiḥ /
analyzed: ataeva anāśinaḥ vināśa rahitasya aprameyasya aparicchinnasya ātmanaḥ ime sukha duḥkha ādi dharmaka dehāḥ uktāḥ tattva darśibhiḥ
translated: And for that very reason, of the imperishable, free from destruction, immeasurable, unlimited Self, these bodies having the qualities of happiness, sorrow, etc. are said by the seers of truth.

original: yasmād evam ātmano na vināśaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt evam ātmanaḥ na vināśaḥ
translated: Since the Self is thus indestructible,

original: na ca sukhaduḥkhādisambandhaḥ /
analyzed: na ca sukha duḥkha ādi sambandhaḥ
translated: and is not related to happiness, sorrow, etc.,

original: tasmān mohajaṃ śoktaṃ tyaktvā yudhyasva /
analyzed: tasmāt moha jam śoktam tyaktvā yudhyasva
translated: Therefore, abandoning grief born of delusion, fight.

original: svadharmaṃ mā tyakṣīr ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: svadharmam mā tyakṣīḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: do not abandon your own duty.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: nanu sphuraṇarūpasya sataḥ katham avināśitvaṃ tasya dehadharmatvād dehasya cānukṣaṇavināśād
analyzed: nanu sphuraṇa rūpasya sataḥ katham avināśi tvam tasya deha dharma tvāt dehasya ca anu kṣaṇa vināśāt
translated: But how can the existent, which is of the nature of manifestation, be indestructible? Since it has the qualities of the body, and the body is destroyed every moment,

original: iti bhūtacaitanyavādinas tān nirākurvann āsato vidyate bhāva ity etad vivṛṇoti antavanta iti /
analyzed: iti bhūtacaitanyavādinaḥ tān nirākurvan āsataḥ vidyate bhāvaḥ iti etat vivṛṇoti antavantaḥ iti
translated: Thus, refuting those who hold the doctrine of the sentience of elements, he explains this statement existence is real by saying they have an end.

original: antavanto vināśina ime 'parokṣā dehā upacitāpacitarūpatvāc charīrāṇi /
analyzed: antavantaḥ vināśinaḥ ime parokṣāḥ dehāḥ upacita apacita rūpa tvāt śarīrāṇi
translated: These proximate bodies, which have the form of being accumulated and diminished, are perishable and have an end.

original: bahuvacanāt sthūlasūkṣmakāraṇarūpā virāṭsūtrāvyākṛtākhyāḥ samaṣṭivyaṣṭyātmanaḥ
analyzed: bahuvacanāt sthūla sūkṣma kāraṇa rūpāḥ virāṭsūtra avyākṛta ākhyāḥ samaṣṭi vyaṣṭi ātmanaḥ
translated: Due to the plural number, they are gross, subtle, and causal in nature, known as Virāṭ, Sūtra, and Avyakta, having the nature of the aggregate and the individual.

original: sarve nityasyāvināśina eva śarīriṇa ādhyāsikasambandhena śarīravataekasyātmanaḥ🔽svaprakāśasphuraṇarūpasya sambandhino dṛśyatvena bhogyatvena coktāḥ śrutibhir
analyzed: sarve nityasya avināśinaḥ eva śarīriṇaḥ ādhyāsika sambandhena śarīravataḥ ekasya ātmanaḥ  sva prakāśa sphuraṇa rūpasya sambandhinaḥ dṛśya tvena bhogya tvena ca uktāḥ śrutibhiḥ
translated: All of them are eternally imperishable bodies of the embodied one, related to the body through superimposition, of the one Self🔽which is of the nature of self-luminous manifestation, spoken of by the Upaniṣads and the expounders of Brahman

original: brahmavādibhiś ca /
analyzed: brahma vādibhiḥ ca
translated: as the object of perception and as the object of enjoyment.

original: tathā ca taittirīyake 'nnamayādyānandamayānantān pañca kośān kalpayitvā tadadhiṣṭhānam akalpitaṃ brahma pucchaṃ pratiṣṭhā TaittU / iti 🔽darśitam /🔽tatra pañcīkṛtapañcamahābhūtatatkāryātmako
analyzed: tathā ca taittirīyake nna maya ādi ānanda maya anantān pañca kośān kalpayitvā tad adhiṣṭhānam a kalpitam brahma puccham pratiṣṭhā iti  darśitam  tatra pañcīkṛta pañca mahābhūta tad kārya ātmakaḥ
translated: And thus, in the Taittirīya Upaniṣad, having postulated five sheaths beginning with food and ending with bliss, the unpostulated Brahman, which is the basis of those, is shown as the tail and the support.🔽There, the aggregate of gross bodies consisting of the five great elements in their evolved and unevolved states,

original: virāṇmūrtarāśir annamayakośaḥ sthūlasamaṣṭiḥ /
analyzed: virāj mūrta rāśiḥ anna maya kośaḥ sthūla samaṣṭiḥ
translated: is the food-made sheath, the gross aggregate.

original: tatkāraṇībhūto 'pañcīkṛtapañcamahābhūtatatkāryātmako hiraṇyagarbhaḥ sūtram
analyzed: pañcīkṛta pañca mahābhūta tad kārya ātmakaḥ hiraṇyagarbhaḥ sūtram
translated: That is the cause, consisting of the five gross elements and their effects, is Hiraṇyagarbha. The Sūtra

original: amūrtarāśiḥ sūkṣmasamaṣṭiḥ trayaṃ vā idaṃ nāma rūpaṃ karma BAU / / iti bṛhadāraṇyakoktatryannātmakaḥ
analyzed: amūrta rāśiḥ sūkṣma samaṣṭiḥ trayam vai idam nāma rūpam karma iti bṛhadāraṇyaka ukta tri anna ātmakaḥ
translated: is the formless aggregate, the subtle universal. The three, namely name, form, and action, are mentioned in the Brhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad.

original: sarvakarmātmakatvena kriyāśaktimātram ādāya prāṇamayakośa uktaḥ /
analyzed: sarva karma ātmaka tvena kriyāśakti mātram ādāya prāṇa maya kośaḥ uktaḥ
translated: He is said to be the sheath of vital airs, taking only the power of action in the form of all actions.

original: nāmātmakatvena jñānaśaktimātram ādāyamanomayakośa uktaḥ /
analyzed: nāma ātmaka tvena jñānaśakti mātram ādāya manaḥ maya kośaḥ uktaḥ
translated: He is said to be the sheath of mind, taking only the power of knowledge in the form of name.

original: rūpātmakatvena tadubhayāśrayatayā kartṛtvam ādāya vijñānamayakośa uktaḥ /
analyzed: rūpa ātmaka tvena tad ubhaya āśraya tayā kartṛ tvam ādāya vijñāna maya kośaḥ uktaḥ
translated: He is said to be the sheath of consciousness, taking the doership by being the support of both in the form of form.

original: tataḥ prāṇamayamanomayavijñānamayātmaika eva hiraṇyagarbhākhyo liṅgaśarīrakośaḥ /
analyzed: tatas prāṇa maya manaḥ maya vijñāna maya ātmā ekaḥ eva hiraṇyagarbha ākhyaḥ liṅga śarīra kośaḥ
translated: Therefore, the single self consisting of vital airs, mind, and consciousness is the sheath of the subtle body called Hiraṇyagarbha.

original: tatkāraṇībhūtas tu māyopahitacaitanyātmā sarvasaṃskāraśeṣo 'vyākṛtākhya ānandamayakośaḥ /
analyzed: tad kāraṇībhūtaḥ tu māyā upahita caitanya ātmā sarva saṃskāra śeṣaḥ vyākṛta ākhyaḥ ānanda maya kośaḥ
translated: But the sheath of bliss called the unmanifest, consisting of all impressions and having a self covered by Māyā, is the cause of that.

original: te ca sarva ekasyaivātmanaḥ śarīrāṇīty uktam /🔽tasyaiṣa eva śārīra
analyzed: te ca sarve ekasya eva ātmanaḥ śarīrāṇi iti uktam  tasya eṣaḥ eva śārīra
translated: And it is said that all those are the bodies of the very same self.🔽This very self is the embodied self of that,

original: ātmā yaḥ pūrvasya TaittU / / iti /
analyzed: ātmā yaḥ pūrvasya taittu iti
translated: as said in the Taittirīya Upaniṣad.

original: tasya prāṇamayasyaiṣa eva śarīre bhavaḥ śārīra ātmā yaḥ satyajñānādilakṣaṇo guhānihitatvenoktaḥ pūrvasyānnamayasya /
analyzed: tasya prāṇa mayasya eṣaḥ eva śarīre bhavaḥ śārīraḥ ātmā yaḥ satya jñāna ādi lakṣaṇaḥ guhā nihita tvena uktaḥ pūrvasya anna mayasya
translated: The embodied Self, which is described as being hidden in the cave, and which has the characteristics of truth, knowledge, etc., is the existence of this vital air.

original: evaṃ prāṇamayamanomayavijñānamayānandamayeṣu yojyam /
analyzed: evam prāṇa maya manaḥ maya vijñāna maya ānanda mayeṣu yojyam
translated: The same should be applied to the parts consisting of vital air, mind, knowledge, and bliss.

original: athaveme sarve dehās trailokyavartisarvaprāṇisambandhina ekasyaivātmana uktā iti yojanā /
analyzed: athavā ime sarve dehāḥ trailokya varti sarva prāṇi sambandhinaḥ ekasya eva ātmanaḥ uktāḥ iti yojanā
translated: Or, all these bodies, related to all beings in the three worlds, are said to belong to one Self. This is the connection.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ
translated: And thus the scripture says:

original: eko devaḥ sarvabhūteṣu gūḍhaḥ
analyzed: ekaḥ devaḥ sarva bhūteṣu gūḍhaḥ
translated: The one God, hidden in all beings,

original: sarvavyāpī sarvabhūtāntarātmā /
analyzed: sarva vyāpī sarva bhūta antarātmā
translated: pervading all, the inner Self of all beings,

original: karmādhyakṣaḥ sarvabhūtādhivāsaḥ
translated: the overseer of actions, the abode of all beings,

original: sākṣī ceto kevalo nirguṇaś ca // ŚvetU /
analyzed: sākṣī kevalaḥ nirguṇaḥ ca
translated: the witness, the mind alone, the qualityless one. (Svet. 6.14)

original: iti sarvaśarīrasambandhinam ekam ātmānaṃ nityaṃ vibhuṃ darśayati /🔽nanu nityatvaṃ yāvatkālasthāyitvaṃ tathā cāvidyādivat kālena saha nāśe 'pi tadupapannam ity ata āha anāśina iti /
analyzed: iti sarva śarīra sambandhinam ekam ātmānam nityam vibhum darśayati  nanu nitya tvam yāvat kāla sthāyi tvam tathā ca avidyā ādi vat kālena saha nāśe pi tat upapannam iti atas āha anāśinaḥ iti
translated: Thus it shows the one eternal, all-pervading Self related to all bodies.🔽But eternality is lasting for some time, and even in the case of destruction along with time, like ignorance, etc., it is appropriate. Therefore he says of the indestructible (verse 17).

original: deśataḥ kālato vastutaś caparicchinasyāvidyādeḥ kalpitatvenānityatve 'pi yāvatkālasthāyisvarūpam
analyzed: deśataḥ kālataḥ vastutaḥ ca paricchinasya avidyā ādeḥ kalpita tvena anitya tve pi yāvat kāla sthāyi svarūpam
translated: Even though ignorance, etc., which are limited in space, time, and substance, are not eternal because they are imagined, the form that lasts for some time

original: aupacārikaṃ nityatvaṃ vyavahriyate yāvadvikāraṃ tu vibhāgo lokavat Vs / / iti nyāyāt /
analyzed: aupacārikam nitya tvam vyavahriyate yāvadvikāram tu vibhāgaḥ loka vat iti nyāyāt
translated: For, according to the principle: The figurative permanence is spoken of, but the division is according to the rule: 'As long as there is modification, like in the world' (Vs 2.1.10).

original: ātmanas tu paricchedatrayaśūnyasyākalpitasya vināśahetvabhāvān mukhyam eva kūṭasthanityatvaṃ na tu pariṇāminityatvaṃ yāvatkālasthāyitvaṃ
analyzed: ātmanaḥ tu pariccheda traya śūnyasya akalpitasya vināśa hetu abhāvāt mukhyam eva kūṭastha nitya tvam na tu pariṇāmi nitya tvam yāvat kāla sthāyi tvam
translated: But the Self, which is devoid of the three limitations, and is not imagined, has no cause for destruction, so it has the primary, immutable permanence, not the permanence of transformation, or the permanence of existing for a certain period of time.

original: cety abhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: ca iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: This is the intention.

original: nanv etādṛśe dehini kiṃcit pramāṇam avaśyaṃ vācyam anyathā niṣpramāṇasya tasyālīkatvāpatteḥ śāstrārambhavaiyarthyāpatteś ca /
analyzed: nanu etādṛśe dehini kiṃcid pramāṇam avaśyam vācyam anyathā niṣpramāṇasya tasya alīka tva āpatteḥ śāstra ārambha vaiyarthya āpatteḥ ca
translated: But some valid means of knowledge must be stated about such a embodied being, otherwise, because it would be without any valid means of knowledge, it would be false, and because it would lead to the futility of beginning the scripture.

original: tathā ca vastuparicchedo duṣpariharaḥ śāstrayonitvāt Vs / / iti nyāyāc ca /
analyzed: tathā ca vastu paricchedaḥ duṣpariharaḥ śāstra yoni tvāt iti nyāyāt ca
translated: And in that case, the determination of an entity is difficult to avoid, because of the principle: 'Because it has the scripture as its source' (Vs 1.1.1).

original: ata āha aprameyasyeti /
analyzed: atas āha aprameyasya iti
translated: Therefore, he says: 'Of the immeasurable' etc.

original: ekadhaivānudraṣṭavyam etad apramayaṃ dhruvam BAU / / apramayam aprameyam /
analyzed: ekadhā eva anudraṣṭavyam etat apramayam dhruvam apramayam aprameyam
translated: 'This should be seen as one only, immeasurable, and certain' (Tai. 2.1.1). 'Imeasurable' means immeasurable.

original: na tatra sūryo bhāti na candratārakaṃ
analyzed: na tatra sūryaḥ bhāti na candra tārakam
translated: 'There the sun does not shine, nor the moon and stars,

original: nemā vidyuto bhānti kuto 'yam agniḥ / KaṭhU /🔽tam eva bhāntam anubhāti sarvaṃ
analyzed: na imāḥ vidyutaḥ bhānti kutas yam agniḥ kaṭhu  tam eva bhāntam anubhāti sarvam
translated: nor these lightnings, much less this fire' (Ka. 2.2.15).🔽'All this shines following Him,

original: tasya bhāsā sarvam idaṃ vibhāti ṃuṇḍU / /
analyzed: tasya bhāsā sarvam idam vibhāti ṃuṇḍu
translated: by His light all this shines' (Mu. 2.2.11).

original: iti ca śruteḥ svaprakāśacaitanyarūpa evātmātas tasya sarvabhāsakasya svabhānārthaṃ na svabhāsyāpekṣā /
analyzed: iti ca śruteḥ sva prakāśa caitanya rūpaḥ eva ātmā atas tasya sarva bhāsakasya sva bhāna artham na sva bhāsya apekṣā
translated: And because of this Vedic text, the Self is of the nature of self-luminous consciousness. Therefore, that which illuminates everything does not depend on being illuminated by itself for its own manifestation.

original: kintu kalpitājñānatatkāryanivṛttyarthaṃ kalpitavṛttiviśeṣāpekṣā /
analyzed: kintu kalpita ajñāna tad kārya nivṛtti artham kalpita vṛtti viśeṣa apekṣā
translated: But it depends on the imagined specific modifications for the cessation of the imagined ignorance and its effects.

original: kalpitasyaiva kalpitavirodhitvāt /
analyzed: kalpitasya eva kalpita virodhi tvāt
translated: Because the imagined can only contradict the imagined.

original: yakṣānurūpo baliḥ iti nyāyāt /
analyzed: yakṣa anurūpaḥ baliḥ iti nyāyāt
translated: By the principle that the offering should be commensurate with the Yaksha.

original: tathā ca sarvakalpitanivartakavṛttiviśeṣotpattyarthaṃ śāstrārambhaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca sarva kalpita nivartaka vṛtti viśeṣa utpatti artham śāstra ārambhaḥ
translated: And thus the beginning of the scripture is for the purpose of producing the specific modifications that remove all the imagined.

original: tasya tattvam asy ādivākyamātrādhīnatvāt /
analyzed: tasya tat tvam asi ādi vākya mātra adhīna tvāt
translated: Because its truth depends only on the initial statement That art thou.

original: svataḥ sarvadābhāsamānatvāt sarvakalpanādhiṣṭhānatvād dṛśyamātrabhāsakatvāc ca na tasya tucchatvāpattiḥ /
analyzed: svatas sarvadā ābhāsamāna tvāt sarva kalpanā adhiṣṭhāna tvāt dṛśya mātra bhāsaka tvāt ca na tasya tuccha tva āpattiḥ
translated: And thus, because it is self-luminous at all times, because it is the basis of all imagination, and because it illuminates only the visible, it does not become void.

original: tathā caikam evādvitīyaṃ satyaṃ jñānam anantaṃ brahmety ādiśāstram eva svaprameyānurodhena svasyāpi kalpitatvam āpādayati anyathā svaprāmāṇyānupapatteḥ
analyzed: tathā ca ekam eva advitīyam satyam jñānam anantam brahma iti ādi śāstram eva sva prameya anurodhena svasya api kalpita tvam āpādayati anyathā sva prāmāṇya anupapatteḥ
translated: And thus, the scriptures beginning with That alone is true, knowledge, infinite, Brahman, without a second imply even its own imagined nature in accordance with its own subject matter, otherwise its own validity would be impossible.

original: kalpitasya cākalpitaparicchedakatvaṃ nāstīti prākpratipāditam /
analyzed: kalpitasya ca akalpita paricchedaka tvam na asti iti prāk pratipāditam
translated: And it has been previously established that the imagined cannot define the un-imagined.

original: ātmanaḥ svaprakāśatvaṃ ca yuktito 'pi bhagavatpūjyapādair upapāditam /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ sva prakāśa tvam ca bhagavat pūjya pādaiḥ upapāditam
translated: And the self-luminousness of the self has been established logically also by the revered teacher.

original: tathā hi yatra jijñāsoḥ saṃśayaviparyayavyatirekapramāṇānām anyatamam api nāsti tatra tadvirodhi jñānam iti sarvatra dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: tathā hi yatra jijñāsoḥ saṃśaya viparyaya vyatireka pramāṇānām anyatamam api nā asti tatra tad virodhi jñānam iti sarvatra dṛṣṭam
translated: Thus, wherever there is no doubt, error, or exclusion among those sought to be known, there is knowledge contrary to that - this is seen everywhere.

original: anyathā tritayānyatamāpatteḥ /
analyzed: anyathā tritaya anyatama āpatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, because of falling into one of the three,

original: ātmani cāhaṃ vā nāhaṃ veti na kasyacit saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: ātmani ca aham vā na aham vā iti na kasyacid saṃśayaḥ
translated: and in the self, no one has doubt like am I or am I not?

original: nāpi nāham iti viparyayo vyatirekaḥ pramā veti tatsvarūpapramā sarvadāstīti vācyaṃ tasya sarvasaṃśayaviparyayadharmitvāt /
analyzed: nā api na aham iti viparyayaḥ vyatirekaḥ pramā vā iti tad svarūpa pramā sarvadā asti iti vācyam tasya sarva saṃśaya viparyaya dharmi tvāt
translated: Nor is there error like I am not or exclusion or valid knowledge, so it must be said that there is always valid knowledge of its own nature, because it is the substratum of all doubt and error.

original: dharmyaśe sarvam abhrāntaṃ prakāre tu viparyayaḥ iti nyāyāt /
analyzed: sarvam abhra antam prakāre tu viparyayaḥ iti nyāyāt
translated: Because of the rule: Everything is non-erroneous in the substratum, but there is error in the mode.

original: ata evoktam
analyzed: atas eva uktam
translated: For this very reason it is said:

original: pramāṇam apramāṇaṃ ca pramābhāsas tathaiva ca /
analyzed: pramāṇam apramāṇam ca pramā ābhāsaḥ tathā eva ca
translated: Valid knowledge and invalid knowledge, and similarly the appearance of valid knowledge,

original: kurvanty eva pramāṃ yatra tadasambhāvanā kutaḥ //
analyzed: kurvanti eva pramām yatra tad asambhāvanā kutas
translated: how can there be impossibility of that where they produce valid knowledge?

original: BṛhadvāmanaP / /
analyzed: bṛhat vāmanap
translated: Brihad-Vamana

original: pramābhāsaḥ saṃśayaḥ /
translated: The appearance of valid knowledge is doubt.

original: svaprakāśe sadrūpe dharmiṇi pramāṇāpramāṇayor viśeṣo nāstīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: sva prakāśe sat rūpe dharmiṇi pramāṇa apramāṇayoḥ viśeṣaḥ na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the existent form which is self-luminous, there is no distinction between valid knowledge and invalid knowledge with regard to the substratum.

original: ātmano 'bhāsamānatve ca ghaṭajñānaṃ mayi jātaṃ na vety ādisaṃśayaḥ syāt /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ bhāsamāna tve ca ghaṭa jñānam mayi jātam na vā iti ādi saṃśayaḥ syāt
translated: And if the self were not manifest, there would be doubt as to whether the cognition of the pot arose in me or not.

original: na cāntarapadārthe viṣayasyaiva saṃśayādipratibandhakatvasvabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na ca antara padārthe viṣayasya eva saṃśaya ādi pratibandhaka tva svabhāvaḥ
translated: And in the case of an internal object, the very object itself has the nature of obstructing doubt, etc.

original: bāhyapadārthe k ptena virodhijñānenaiva saṃśayādipratibandhasaṃbhava āntarapadārthe svabhāvabhedakalpanāyā anaucityāt /
analyzed: bāhya padārthe virodhi jñānena eva saṃśaya ādi pratibandha saṃbhavaḥ āntara padārthe svabhāva bheda kalpanāyāḥ anaucityāt
translated: In the case of an external object, doubt, etc. can be obstructed by a contradictory cognition itself. In the case of an internal object, it is improper to assume a difference in nature.

original: anyathā sarvaviplavāpatteḥ /
analyzed: anyathā sarva viplava āpatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be the consequence of everything being destroyed.

original: ātmamanoyogamātraṃ cātmasākṣātkāre hetuḥ /
analyzed: ātma manaḥ yoga mātram ca ātma sākṣātkāre hetuḥ
translated: And the mere contact of the self and the mind is the cause for the self being directly perceived.

original: yasya ca jñānamātre hetutvād ghaṭādibhāne 'py ātmabhānaṃ samūhālambananyāyena tārkikāṇāṃ pravareṇāpi durnivāraṃ /
analyzed: yasya ca jñāna mātre hetu tvāt ghaṭa ādi bhāne pi ātma bhānam samūha ālambana nyāyena tārkikāṇām pravareṇa api durnivāram
translated: And since it is the cause for mere cognition, the manifestation of the self also in the manifestation of the pot, etc. cannot be warded off even by the best of logicians, by the principle of the apprehension of a collection.

original: na ca cākṣuṣatvamānasattvādisaṅkaraḥ /
analyzed: na ca cākṣuṣa tva māna sattva ādi saṅkaraḥ
translated: And there is no confusion of being visual, being mental, etc.

original: laukikatvālaukikatvavad aṃśabhedenopapatteḥ /
analyzed: laukika tva alaukika tva vat aṃśa bhedena upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible by the difference of parts, like being worldly and being otherworldly.

original: saṅkarasyādoṣatvāc cākṣuṣatvāder jātitvānabhyupagamād vā /
analyzed: saṅkarasya adoṣa tvāt cākṣuṣa tva ādeḥ jāti tva anabhyupagamāt vā
translated: And because confusion is not a fault, or because being visual, etc. are not accepted as universals.

original: vyavasāyamātra
analyzed: vyavasāya mātra
translated: Only in the case of ascertainment

original: evātmabhānasāmagryā vidyamānatvād anuvyavasāyo 'py apāstaḥ /
analyzed: eva ātma bhāna sāmagryāḥ vidyamāna tvāt anuvyavasāyaḥ pi apāstaḥ
translated: because the assemblage for the manifestation of the self exists, the subsequent ascertainment is also refuted.

original: na ca vyavasāyabhānārthaṃ sa tasya dīpavat svavyavahāre sajātīyānapekṣatvāt /
analyzed: na ca vyavasāya bhāna artham sa tasya dīpa vat sva vyavahāre sajātīya anapekṣa tvāt
translated: And it is not like a lamp, in that it is required for the apprehension of the apprehension, because it is not dependent on a member of the same class in its own operation.

original: na hi ghaṭatajjñānayor iva vyavasāyānuvyavasāyayor api viṣayatvaviṣayitvavyavasthāpakaṃ vaijātyam asti vyaktibhedātiriktavaidharmyānabhyupagamāt
analyzed: na hi ghaṭa tad jñānayoḥ iva vyavasāya anuvyavasāyayoḥ api viṣaya tva viṣayi tva vyavasthāpakam vaijātyam asti vyakti bheda atirikta vaidharmya anabhyupagamāt
translated: For there is no difference in kind that establishes the relation of object and subject between the apprehension and the subsequent apprehension of the apprehension, as there is between the pot and its knowledge, because no difference in properties other than individual difference is accepted.

original: viṣayatvāvacchedakarūpeṇaiva viṣayitvābhyupagame ghaṭatajjñānayor api tadbhāvāpattir aviśeṣāt /🔽nanu yathā ghaṭavyavahārārthaṃ ghaṭajñānam abhyupeyate tathā ghaṭajñānavyavahārārthaṃ
analyzed: nanu yathā ghaṭa vyavahāra artham ghaṭa jñānam abhyupeyate tathā ghaṭa jñāna vyavahāra artham
translated: If the subject is accepted as having the form of the object only, then the pot and its knowledge would also have that, because there is no difference.

original: ghaṭajñānaviṣayaṃ jñānam abhyupeyaṃ vyavahārāsya vyavahartavyajñānasādhyatvād iti cet /
analyzed: ghaṭa jñāna viṣayam jñānam abhyupeyam vyavahāra asya vyavahartavya jñāna sādhya tvāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that just as pot-knowledge is accepted for the purpose of the operation of the pot, so the knowledge of the knowledge of the pot should be accepted for the purpose of the operation of the knowledge of the pot, because the operation is accomplished by the knowledge of what is to be operated on,

original: kānupapattir udbhāvitā devānāṃpriyeṇa svaprakāśavādinaḥ /
analyzed: kā anupapattiḥ udbhāvitā devānāṃpriyeṇa sva prakāśa vādinaḥ
translated: then what inconsistency has been brought out by the dear friend of the god of love, the proponent of self-luminous knowledge?

original: nahi vyavahartavyabhinnatvam api jñānaviśeṣaṇaṃ vyavahārahetutāvacchedakaṃ gauravāt /
analyzed: nahi vyavahartavya bhinna tvam api jñāna viśeṣaṇam vyavahāra hetu tā avacchedakam gauravāt
translated: For the knowledge of the pot is not a qualifier of the knowledge, nor is it a cause of the operation, because of the burden of complexity.

original: tathā ceśvarajñānavadyogijñānavat prameyam iti jñānavac ca svenaiva svavyavahāropapattau na jñānāntarakalpanāvakāśaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca īśvara jñānavat yogi jñāna vat prameyam iti jñānavat ca svena eva sva vyavahāra upapattau na jñāna antara kalpanā avakāśaḥ
translated: And so, just as in the case of the knowledge of God, and in the case of the knowledge of the yogin, the object is known, and so, just as in the case of knowledge, the activity with regard to itself is possible by itself alone, there is no scope for postulating another knowledge.

original: anuvyavasāyasyāpi ghaṭajñānavyavahārahetutvaṃ kiṃ ghaṭajñānajñānatvena kiṃ vā ghaṭajñānatvenaiveti vivecanīyam /
analyzed: anuvyavasāyasya api ghaṭa jñāna vyavahāra hetu tvam kim ghaṭa jñāna jñāna tvena kim vā ghaṭa jñāna tvena eva iti vivecanīyam
translated: It should be examined whether the cognition of the cognition of the pot is the cause of the activity with regard to the pot-cognition by being the cognition of the cognition of the pot, or by being the pot-cognition itself.

original: ubhayasyāpi tatra sattvāt /🔽tatra ghaṭavyavahāre ghaṭajñānatvenaiva hetutāyāḥ k ptatvāt tenaiva rūpeṇa ghatajñānavyavahāre /
analyzed: ubhayasya api tatra sattvāt  tatra ghaṭa vyavahāre ghaṭa jñāna tvena eva hetutāyāḥ tena eva rūpeṇa
translated: Because both are present there.🔽There, since the causal relation with regard to the activity with regard to the pot is established by being the pot-cognition itself, it is possible for it to be the cause of the activity with regard to the pot-cognition by that form itself.

original: pi hetutopapattau na ghaṭajñānajñānatvaṃ hetutāvacchedakaṃ
analyzed: pi hetu tā upapattau na ghaṭa jñāna jñāna tvam hetu tā avacchedakam
translated: The cognition of the cognition of the pot is not the determiner of the causal relation

original: gauravān mānābhāvāc ca /🔽tathā ca nānuvyavasāyasiddhir ekasyaiva vyavasāyasya vayvasātari vyavaseye vyavasāye ca vyavahārajanakatvopapatter iti tripuṭīpratyakṣavādinaḥ
analyzed: gauravāt māna abhāvāt ca  tathā ca na anuvyavasāya siddhiḥ ekasya eva vyavasāyasya vayvasātari vyavaseye vyavasāye ca vyavahāra janaka tva upapatteḥ iti tripuṭīpratyakṣavādinaḥ
translated: because of the complexity and the absence of evidence.

original: prābhākarāḥ /
analyzed: prābhākarāḥ
translated: And so, there is no establishment of the cognition of the cognition, because it is possible for a single cognition, not being the object of another cognition, to be the cause of the activity with regard to the object and the cognition. Thus say the Prabhākaras, who maintain the doctrine of the perception of the triad.

original: aupaniṣadāstu manyante svaprakāśajñānarūpa evātmā na svaprakāśajñānāśrayaḥ kartṛkarmavirodhena tadbhānānupapatteḥ /
analyzed: aupaniṣadāḥ tu manyante sva prakāśa jñāna rūpaḥ eva ātmā na sva prakāśa jñāna āśrayaḥ kartṛ karma virodhena tad bhāna anupapatteḥ
translated: But the followers of the Upaniṣads think that the self is of the nature of self-luminous knowledge only, not the substratum of self-luminous knowledge, because its manifestation is not possible due to the contradiction between agent and object.

original: jñānabhinnatve ghaṭādivajjaḍatvena kalpitatvāpatteś ca /
analyzed: jñāna bhinna tve ghaṭa ādi vat jaḍa tvena kalpita tva āpatteḥ ca
translated: And if it were different from knowledge, it would be inert like a pot, and so would be an illusion.

original: svaprakāśajñānamātrasvarūpo 'py ātmāvidyopahitaḥ san sākṣīty ucyate /
analyzed: sva prakāśa jñāna mātra svarūpaḥ pi ātmā avidyā upahitaḥ san sākṣī iti ucyate
translated: The self, which is of the nature of self-luminous knowledge only, when covered by ignorance, is called the witness.

original: vṛttimadantaḥkaraṇopahitaḥ pramātety ucyate /
translated: When covered by the internal organ with modifications, it is called the knower.

original: tasya cakṣurādīni karaṇāni /
analyzed: tasya cakṣuḥ ādīni karaṇāni
translated: And its instruments are the eyes, etc.

original: sa cakṣurādidvārāntaḥkaraṇapariṇāmena ghaṭādīn vyāpya tadākāro bhavati /
analyzed: sa cakṣuḥ ādi dvārā antaḥkaraṇa pariṇāmena ghaṭa ādīn vyāpya tad ākāraḥ bhavati
translated: It, pervading pots, etc. through the transformation of the internal organ with the eyes, etc. as its door, becomes of their form.

original: tato ghaṭāvacchinnacaitanyaṃ pramātrabhedāt svājñānaṃ nāśayad aparokṣaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tatas ghaṭa avacchinna caitanyam pramātṛ abhedāt sva ajñānam nāśayat aparokṣam bhavati
translated: Then the consciousness limited by the pot, being non-different from the knower, destroys its own ignorance and becomes manifest.

original: ghaṭaṃ ca svāvacchedakaṃ svatādātmyādhyāsād bhāsayati /
analyzed: ghaṭam ca sva avacchedakam sva tādātmya adhyāsāt bhāsayati
translated: And it illuminates the pot, which is its own limiting adjunct, by superimposing its own identity on it.

original: antaḥkaraṇapariṇāmaś ca vṛttyākhyo 'tisvacchaḥ svāvacchinnenaiva caitanyena bhāsyata ity antaḥkaraṇatadvṛttighaṭānām aparokṣatā /
analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa pariṇāmaḥ ca vṛtti ākhyaḥ u ti svacchaḥ sva avacchinnena eva caitanyena bhāsyate iti antaḥkaraṇa tad vṛtti ghaṭānām aparokṣa tā
translated: And the transformation of the internal organ called modification is very transparent, and is illuminated only by the consciousness limited by itself. Thus the pot, the internal organ, and its modification are manifest.

original: tad etad ākāratrayam ahaṃ jānāmi ghaṭam iti /
analyzed: tat etat ākāra trayam aham jānāmi ghaṭam iti
translated: This triad of forms is I know the pot.

original: bhāsakacaitanyasyaikarūpatve
translated: Even though the illuminating consciousness is of one form,

original: 'pi ghaṭaṃ prati vṛttyapekṣatvāt pramātṛtā /
analyzed: pi ghaṭam prati vṛtti apekṣa tvāt pramātṛ tā
translated: it is the cognizer in relation to the pot because it depends on manifestation.

original: antaḥkaraṇatadvṛttīḥ prati tu vṛttyanapekṣatvāt sākṣiteti vivekaḥ /
analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa tad vṛttīḥ prati tu vṛtti anapekṣa tvāt sākṣi tā iti vivekaḥ
translated: But in relation to the internal organ and its modifications, it is the witness because it does not depend on manifestation. This is the distinction.

original: advaitasiddhau siddhāntabindau ca vistaraḥ /
analyzed: advaita siddhau siddhānta bindau ca vistaraḥ
translated: This is elaborated in the Advaita Siddhi and the Siddhanta Bindu.

original: yasmād evaṃ prāguktanyāyena ntiyo vibhur asaṃsārī sarvadaikarūpaś cātmā tasmāt
analyzed: yasmāt evam prāgukta nyāyena ntiyaḥ vibhuḥ asaṃsārī sarvadā ekarūpaḥ ca ātmā tasmāt
translated: Since the self is thus, as explained by the previously stated reasoning, eternal, all-pervading, non-transmigrating, and always of one form, therefore,

original: tannāśaśaṅkayā svadharme yuddhe prākpravṛttasya tava tasmād uparatir na yukteti
analyzed: tat na āśaśaṅkayā svadharme yuddhe prāc pravṛttasya tava tasmāt uparatiḥ na yuktā iti
translated: it is not proper for you, who have already engaged in the battle, your own duty, to desist out of fear of its destruction.

original: yuddhābhyanujñayā bhagavān āha tasmād yudhyasva bhārateti /
analyzed: yuddha abhyanujñayā bhagavān āha tasmāt yudhyasva bhārata iti
translated: Thus, the Blessed Lord says, Therefore, fight in the battle of Kurus.

original: arjunasya svadharme yuddhe pravṛttasya tata uparatikāraṇaṃ śokamohau /
analyzed: arjunasya svadharme yuddhe pravṛttasya tatas uparati kāraṇam śoka mohau
translated: The cause of Arjuna's desisting from engaging in the battle, his own duty, is sorrow and delusion.

original: tau ca vicārajanitena vijñānena vādhitāv ity apavādāpavāda utsargasya sthitir iti nyāyena yudhyasvety anuvādo na vidhiḥ /
analyzed: tau ca vicāra janitena vijñānena vādhitau iti apavāda apavādaḥ utsargasya sthitiḥ iti nyāyena yudhyasva iti anuvādaḥ na vidhiḥ
translated: And those two are overcome by the knowledge born of reflection. Thus, by the principle that the exception to the exception stands, the restatement fight is not an injunction.

original: yathā kartṛkarmaṇoḥ kṛti Pāṇ / / ity utsargaḥ /
analyzed: yathā kartṛ karmaṇoḥ kṛti pāṇ iti utsargaḥ
translated: For example, the general rule is kṛti for the agent and object, as stated in Panini's grammar.

original: ubhayaprāptau karmaṇi Pāṇ / / ity apavādaḥ /
analyzed: ubhaya prāptau karmaṇi pāṇ iti apavādaḥ
translated: The exception is kṛ for the object, when both are present.

original: akākārayoḥ strīpratyayayoḥ prayoge neti vaktavyam iti tadapavādaḥ /🔽tathā ca mumukṣor brahmaṇor jijñāsety atrāpavādāpavāde punar utsargasthiteḥ kartṛkarmaṇoḥ kṛtīty anenaiva ṣaṣṭhī /
analyzed: aka ākārayoḥ strī pratyayayoḥ prayoge na iti vaktavyam iti tad apavādaḥ  tathā ca mumukṣoḥ brahmaṇoḥ jijñāsā iti atra apavāda apavāde punar utsarga sthiteḥ kartṛ karmaṇoḥ kṛtī iti anena eva ṣaṣṭhī
translated: In the case of the feminine endings of the words 'aka' and 'kara', it should be said that the rule does not apply. This is an exception to the general rule.🔽And thus, in 'brahma jijnasa' (desire to know Brahman) of one who seeks liberation, the exception being overridden, the general rule stands, and the genitive is formed by the suffix 'krit' (as in 'kartur karma') in the sense of agent and object.

original: tathā ca karmaṇi ceti niṣedhāprasārād brahmajijñāseti karmaṣaṣṭhīsamāsaḥ
analyzed: tathā ca karmaṇi ca iti niṣedha aprasārāt brahma jijñāsā iti karma ṣaṣṭhī samāsaḥ
translated: And thus, because the prohibition 'in the case of the object' does not apply, the compound 'brahma jijnasa' (desire to know Brahman) is formed by the genitive case ending.

original: siddho bhavati /
analyzed: siddhaḥ bhavati
translated: This is established.

original: kaścit tv etasmād eva vidher mokṣe jñānakarmaṇoḥ samuccaya iti pralapati /
analyzed: kaścid tu etasmāt eva vidheḥ mokṣe jñāna karmaṇoḥ samuccayaḥ iti pralapati
translated: But someone prattles that from this very injunction, knowledge and action are combined as the means to liberation.

original: tac ca yudhyasvety ato mokṣasya jñānakarmasamuccayasādhyatvāpratīteḥ /
analyzed: tat ca yudhyasva iti atas mokṣasya jñāna karma samuccaya sādhya tva apratīteḥ
translated: And that is not so, because from the injunction 'fight', liberation is not understood to be accomplished by the combination of knowledge and action.

original: vistareṇa caitad agre bhagavadgītāvacanavirodhenaiva nirākariṣyāmaḥ ////
analyzed: vistareṇa ca etat agre bhagavadgītā vacana virodhena eva nirākariṣyāmaḥ
translated: And this will be refuted in detail later on, by showing contradiction with the words of the Bhagavad Gita.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: nāsato vidyate bhāvaḥ ity asyārthaṃ spaṣṭayati antavanta iti /
analyzed: na asataḥ vidyate bhāvaḥ iti asya artham spaṣṭayati antavantaḥ iti
translated: To clarify the meaning of 'not from non-existence does existence come', he says 'they are limited' etc.

original: śarīriṇo jīvasyāprameyasyātisūkṣmatvād durjñeyasya /
analyzed: śarīriṇaḥ jīvasya aprameyasya ati sūkṣma tvāt durjñeyasya
translated: Of the embodied one, the individual soul, which is immeasurable and very subtle, and therefore difficult to know.

original: tasmād yudhyasva iti śāstravihitasya svadharmasya tyāgo 'nucita iti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: tasmāt yudhyasva iti śāstra vihitasya svadharmasya tyāgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the idea is that it is not proper to abandon one's own duty prescribed by the scriptures, by saying 'fight'.

original: baladevaḥ / antavanto vināśisvabhāvāḥ /
analyzed: baladevaḥ antavantaḥ vināśi svabhāvāḥ
translated: Balarama: Finite, of the nature of perishability.

original: śarīriṇo jīvātmanaḥ /
analyzed: śarīriṇaḥ jīvātmanaḥ
translated: Of embodied beings, of individual souls.

original: aprameyasyātisūkṣmatvād vijñānavijñātṛsvarūpatvāc ca pramātum aśakyasyety arthaḥ /
analyzed: aprameyasya ati sūkṣma tvāt vijñāna vijñātṛ svarūpa tvāt ca pramātum aśakyasya iti arthaḥ
translated: Of the immeasurable, the meaning is: incapable of being measured because of extreme subtlety and because of being of the nature of the knower of knowledge.

original: tathā cedṛśasvabhāvatvāj jīvataddehau na śokasthānam iti jīvātmano deho dharmānuṣṭānuṣṭhānadvārā tasya bhogāya mokṣāya ca pareśena sṛjyate
analyzed: tathā ca īdṛśa svabhāva tvāt jīva tad dehau na śoka sthānam iti jīvātmanaḥ dehaḥ dharma anuṣṭa anuṣṭhāna dvārā tasya bhogāya mokṣāya ca pareśena sṛjyate
translated: And thus, because of having such a nature, the individual soul and its body are not the objects of grief. Therefore, the body of the individual soul is created by the Supreme Lord through the medium of the performance of dharma for its enjoyment and liberation.

original: sa ca sa ca dharmeṇa bhavet tasmād yudhyasva bhārata ////
analyzed: sa ca sa ca dharmeṇa bhavet tasmāt yudhyasva bhārata
translated: And he should be by dharma. Therefore, fight, O descendant of Bharata!

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gita

original: ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaś cainaṃ manyate hatam /
analyzed: yaḥ enam vetti hantāram yaḥ ca enam manyate hatam
translated: One who knows him as the killer, and one who thinks of him as killed,

original: ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate ////
analyzed: ubhau tau na vijānītaḥ na ayam hanti na hanyate
translated: Both of them do not know. He does not kill, nor is he killed.

original: śrīdharaḥ / tad evaṃ bhīṣmādimṛtyunimittaḥ śoko nivāritaḥ /
translated: Sridhar: Thus, grief caused by the death of Bhishma and others is warded off.

original: yac cātmano hantṛtvanimittaṃ duḥkham uktam etān na hantum icchāmi ity ādinā /
analyzed: yat ca ātmanaḥ hantṛ tva nimittam duḥkham uktam etān na hantum icchāmi iti ādinā
translated: And the sorrow caused by the thought of being the killer of the self, as stated by I do not wish to kill these, etc.,

original: tad api tavad eva nirnimittam ity āha ya enam iti /
analyzed: tat api tavat eva nirnimittam iti āha yaḥ enam iti
translated: that too is groundless, says One who knows him...

original: enam ātmānam /
analyzed: enam ātmānam
translated: Him, the self.

original: ātmano hananakriyāyāḥ karmatvaṃ kartṛtvam api nāstīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ hanana kriyāyāḥ karma tvam kartṛ tvam api na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the Self is neither the object nor the agent of the act of killing.

original: tatra hetur nāyam iti ////
analyzed: tatra hetuḥ na ayam iti
translated: The reason for that is stated in the words, 'This Self is not killed' (2.20).

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: nanv evam aśocyān anvaśocacas tvam ity ādinā bhīṣmādibandhuvicchedanibandhane śoke 'panīte 'pi tadvadhakartṛtvanibandhanasya pāpasya
analyzed: nanu evam a śocyān anvaśocacaḥ tvam iti ādinā bhīṣma ādi bandhu viccheda nibandhane śoke panīte tad vadha kartṛ tva nibandhanasya pāpasya
translated: Now, although grief caused by the separation from relatives like Bhishma etc. has been removed by the words 'you grieve for those who are not to be grieved for' etc., the sin caused by being the instrument of their death

original: nāsti pratīkāraḥ /
analyzed: na asti pratīkāraḥ
translated: has no remedy.

original: nahi yatra śoko nāsti tatra pāpaṃ nāstīti niyamaḥ /
analyzed: nahi yatra śokaḥ na asti tatra pāpam na asti iti niyamaḥ
translated: For there is no rule that where there is no grief, there is no sin.

original: dveṣyabrāhmaṇavadhe pāpābhāvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: dveṣya brāhmaṇa vadhe pāpa abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: For then it would follow that there is no sin in killing a hated Brahmin.

original: ato 'haṃ kartā tvaṃ preraka iti dvayor api hiṃsānimittapātakāpatter ayuktam idaṃ
analyzed: atas ham kartā tvam prerakaḥ iti dvayoḥ api hiṃsā nimitta pātaka āpatteḥ ayuktam idam
translated: Therefore, it is not proper to say this, since both of you would incur the sin of violence by thinking 'I am the doer' and 'you are the instigator'.

original: vacanaṃ tasmād yudhyasva bhāratety āśaṅkya kāṭhakapaṭhitaya rcā pariharati bhagavān ya enam iti /
analyzed: vacanam tasmāt yudhyasva bhārata iti āśaṅkya kāṭhaka paṭhitayā ṛcā pariharati bhagavān yaḥ enam iti
translated: Fearing this objection, the Lord replies with a verse from the Kathaka recension, 'He who knows Him as the killer' (2.20).

original: enaṃ prakṛtaṃ dehinam adṛśyatvādiguṇakaṃ yo hantāraṃ hananakriyāyāḥ kartāraṃ vetti aham asya hanteti vijānāti /
analyzed: enam prakṛtam dehinam adṛśya tva ādi guṇakam yaḥ hantāram hanana kriyāyāḥ kartāram vetti aham asya hantā iti vijānāti
translated: He who knows the killer, the agent of the act of killing, as the killer of this embodied Self, which is the subject under discussion and has the qualities of being unmanifest etc., thinking 'I am His killer',

original: yaś cānya enaṃ manyate hataṃ hananakriyāyāḥ karmabhūtaṃ dehahananena hato 'ham iti vijānāti /
analyzed: yaḥ ca anyaḥ enam manyate hatam hanana kriyāyāḥ karma bhūtam deha hananena hataḥ ham iti vijānāti
translated: And he who thinks of him as other than that, as the object of the act of killing, knows him as killed by the killing of the body, thinking 'I am killed.'

original: tāv ubhau dehābhimānitvād enam avikāriṇam akārakasvabhāvam ātmānaṃ na vijānīto na vivekena jānītaḥ śāstrāt /
analyzed: tau ubhau deha abhimāni tvāt enam avikāriṇam akāraka svabhāvam ātmānam na vijānītaḥ na vivekena jānītaḥ śāstrāt
translated: Both of them, because of their identification with the body, do not know this Self, which is changeless and whose nature is not an agent, by discrimination through the scriptures.

original: kasmāt yasmān nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate kartā karma ca na bahvatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: kasmāt yasmāt na ayam hanti na hanyate kartā karma ca na arthaḥ
translated: Why is it so? Because this one does not kill, is not killed, is not the agent, and the action is not manifold - this is the meaning.

original: atra ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ hataṃ cety etāvati vaktavye padānām āvṛttir vākyālaṅkārārthā /
analyzed: atra yaḥ enam vetti hantāram hatam ca iti etāvati vaktavye padānām āvṛttiḥ vākya alaṅkāra arthā
translated: Here, when only this much should be said - 'he who knows him as the killer and as killed' - the repetition of words is for the sake of embellishing the sentence.

original: athavā ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ tārkikādir ātmanaḥ kartṛtvābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: athavā yaḥ enam vetti hantāram tārkika ādiḥ ātmanaḥ kartṛ tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Or, he who knows him as the killer is the logician, etc., because they accept the Self as the agent.

original: tathā yaś cainaṃ manyate hataṃ cārvākādir ātmano vināśitvābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: tathā yaḥ ca enam manyate hatam cārvāka ādiḥ ātmanaḥ vināśi tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Similarly, he who thinks of him as killed is the Cārvāka, etc., because they accept the Self to be destroyed.

original: tāv ubhau na vijānīta iti yojyam /🔽vādibhedakhyāpanāya pṛthag upanyāsaḥ /
analyzed: tau ubhau na vijānīte iti yojyam  vādi bheda khyāpanāya pṛthak upanyāsaḥ
translated: Both of them do not know - this should be connected.🔽The separate statement is for the purpose of proclaiming the difference of the disputants.

original: atiśūrātikātaraviṣayatayā vā pṛthagupadeśaḥ /
analyzed: ati śūra ati kātara viṣaya tayā vā pṛthak upadeśaḥ
translated: Or, the separate teaching is for the purpose of those who are excessively brave and excessively timid.

original: hantā cen manyate hantuṃ hataś cen manyate hatam KaṭhU / / iti pūrvārdhe śrautaḥ pāṭhaḥ ////
analyzed: hantā ced manyate hantum hataḥ ced manyate hatam kaṭhu iti pūrva ardhe śrautaḥ pāṭhaḥ
translated: If the killer thinks he is killing, and if the killed thinks he is killed, then both of them are ignorant. This is the Vedic text in the first half.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: bho vayasya arjuna /
analyzed: bho vayasya arjuna
translated: O friend Arjuna,

original: tvam ātmā /
analyzed: tvam ātmā
translated: you are the Self.

original: na hanteḥ kartā /
analyzed: na hanteḥ kartā
translated: You are not the agent of killing,

original: nāpi hanteḥ karma ity āha ya iti /🔽enaṃ jīvātmānaṃ hantāraṃ vetti bhīṣmādīn arjuno hantīti yo vettīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: na api hanteḥ karma iti āha yaḥ iti  enam jīvātmānam hantāram vetti bhīṣma ādīn arjunaḥ hanti iti yaḥ vetti iti arthaḥ
translated: nor are you the object of killing. This is stated by the word 'ya' (who).🔽He who knows this living Self as the killer, meaning that Arjuna kills Bhishma and others,

original: hatam iti bhīṣmādibhir arjuno hanyate iti yo vetti /
analyzed: hatam iti bhīṣma ādibhiḥ arjunaḥ hanyate iti yaḥ vetti
translated: and he who thinks that the killed, meaning that Bhishma and others kill Arjuna,

original: tāv ubhāv apy ajñāninau /
analyzed: tau ubhau api ajñāninau
translated: both of them are ignorant.

original: ato 'rjuno 'yaṃ gurujanaṃ hantīty ajñānilokagītād duryaśaḥ kā te bhītir iti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: atas rjunaḥ yam guru janam hanti iti ajñāni loka gītāt duryaśaḥ kā te bhītiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, Arjuna, what fear have you of the ill fame sung by ignorant people that you are killing your elders?

original: baladevaḥ / uktam avināśitvaṃ draḍhayati /🔽enam uktasvabhāvam ātmānaṃ jīvaṃ yo hantāraṃ khaḍgādinā hiṃsakaṃ vetti yaś cainaṃ tena hataṃ hiṃsitaṃ manyate tāv ubhau tatsvarūpaṃ na vijānītaḥ
analyzed: enam ukta svabhāvam ātmānam jīvam yaḥ hantāram khaḍga ādinā hiṃsakam vetti yaḥ ca enam tena hatam hiṃsitam manyate tau ubhau tad svarūpam na vijānītaḥ
translated: Balarama: To strengthen the statement of indestructibility, he says:🔽He who knows this Self, of the nature described, as the killer, the one who injures with a sword etc., and he who thinks that it is killed, injured by that, both of them do not know its nature.

original: atisūkṣmasya caitanyasya tasya chedādyasambhavān nāyam ātmā hanti na hanyate /
analyzed: ati sūkṣmasya caitanyasya tasya cheda ādi asambhavāt na ayam ātmā hanti na hanyate
translated: Because it is extremely subtle, consciousness cannot be cut etc., so this Self is neither killed nor does it kill.

original: hanteḥ kartā karma ca bhavatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: hanteḥ kartā karma ca bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: the agent and the object are of the verb 'to kill'.

original: hanter dehaviyogārthatvān na tenātmanāṃ nāśo mantavyaḥ /
analyzed: hanteḥ deha viyoga ārtha tvāt na tena ātmanām nāśaḥ mantavyaḥ
translated: Since the verb 'to kill' means separation of the body, the destruction of the souls should not be inferred from it.

original: śrutiś caivam āha hantā cen manyate hantuṃ hataś cen manyate hatam KaṭhU / / ity ādinā /
analyzed: śrutiḥ ca evam āha hantā ced manyate hantum hataḥ ced manyate hatam kaṭhu iti ādinā
translated: And the Śruti says this: 'If the killer thinks he kills, if the killed thinks he is killed' (Kaṭha 2.2.6), etc.

original: etena mā hiṃsyāt sarvabhūtāni ity ādivākyaṃ dehaviyogaparaṃ vyākhyātam /
analyzed: etena mā hiṃsyāt sarva bhūtāni iti ādi vākyam deha viyoga param vyākhyātam
translated: By this, the statement 'One should not injure any being' etc. is explained to mean separation from the body.

original: na cātrātmanaḥ kartṛtvaṃ prasiddham iti vācyam /🔽dehaviyojane tat tasya sattvāt ////
analyzed: na ca atra ātmanaḥ kartṛ tvam prasiddham iti vācyam  deha viyojane tat tasya sattvāt
translated: And it should not be said that the Self is not known to be the agent in this.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Because in the separation of the body, that [separation] belongs to it [the Self].🔽BhG 2.20

original: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācin
analyzed: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācid
translated: Never is this born, nor does it ever die;

original: nāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ /
analyzed: na ayam bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyas
translated: Nor having come to life does it ever become non-existent.

original: ajo nityaḥ śāśvato 'yaṃ purāṇo
analyzed: ajaḥ nityaḥ śāśvataḥ yam purāṇaḥ
translated: Undying, eternal, ever-existing, primordial,

original: na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre ////
analyzed: na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre
translated: This is not killed when the body is killed.

original: śrīdharaḥ / na hanyata ity etad eva ṣaḍbhāvavikāraśūnyatvena draḍhayati neti /
