original: nitya evātmā jāyate mriyate ceti tārkikāḥ /
analyzed: nityaḥ eva ātmā jāyate mriyate ca iti tārkikāḥ
translated: The logicians say that the self is permanent and is born and dies.

original: tathā hi pretyabhāvo janma /
analyzed: tathā hi pretyabhāvaḥ janma
translated: Thus, birth is the state after death.

original: sa cāpūrvadehendriyādisambandhaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca apūrva deha indriya ādi sambandhaḥ
translated: And that is the connection with a new body, senses, etc.

original: evaṃ maraṇam api pūrvadehendriyādivicchedaḥ /
analyzed: evam maraṇam api pūrva deha indriya ādi vicchedaḥ
translated: Similarly, death is the separation from the previous body, senses, etc.

original: idaṃ cobhayaṃ dharmādharmanimittatvāt tadādhārasya nityasyaiva mukhyam /
analyzed: idam ca ubhayam dharma adharma nimitta tvāt tad ādhārasya nityasya eva mukhyam
translated: And this pair is primary only for the permanent, which is the basis of dharma and adharma, because it is caused by dharma and adharma.

original: anityasya tu kṛtahānyakṛtābhyāgamaprasaṅgena dharmādharmādhāratvānupapatter
analyzed: anityasya tu kṛta hāni akṛta abhyāgama prasaṅgena dharma adharma ādhāra tva anupapatteḥ
translated: But for the impermanent, the impossibility of being the basis of dharma and adharma follows from the consequence of the loss of what is done and the acquisition of what is not done.

original: na janmamaraṇe mukhye iti vadanti /
analyzed: na janma maraṇe mukhye iti vadanti
translated: Therefore, birth and death are not primary, they say.

original: ntiyasyām evety anye /
analyzed: ntiyasyām eva iti anye
translated: Others say it is in the very same.

original: tatrānityatvapakṣe 'pi śocyatvam ātmano niṣedhati atha cainam iti /🔽atheti pakṣāntare /
analyzed: tatra anitya tva pakṣe śocya tvam ātmanaḥ niṣedhati atha ca enam iti  atha iti pakṣa antare
translated: There, even in the view of impermanence, he denies the sorrowfulness of the self with And yet they grieve for it.🔽And means in another case.

original: co 'py arthe /
analyzed: caḥ pi arthe
translated: Yet has the meaning of also.

original: yadi durbodhatvād ātmavastuno 'sakṛcchravaṇe 'py avadhāraṇāsāmarthyān maduktapakṣānaṅgīkāreṇa pakṣāntaram abhyupaiṣi /
analyzed: yadi durbodha tvāt ātma vastunaḥ sakṛt śravaṇe pi avadhāraṇa asāmarthyāt mad ukta pakṣa anaṅgīkāreṇa pakṣa antaram abhyupaiṣi
translated: If, because of the difficulty of understanding, you accept another view by not accepting my view, even though you have heard about the nature of the self repeatedly, because of your inability to ascertain it,

original: tatrāpy anityatvapakṣam evāśritya yady enam ātmānaṃ nityaṃ jātaṃ nityaṃ mṛtaṃ vā manyase /
analyzed: tatra api anitya tva pakṣam eva āśritya yadi enam ātmānam nityam jātam nityam mṛtam vā manyase
translated: then, even in that case, if you consider that self to be permanent, born permanently, or dead permanently,

original: vāśabdaś cārthe /
analyzed: vā śabdaḥ ca arthe
translated: the word or has the meaning of also.

original: kṣaṇikatvapakṣe nityaṃ pratikṣaṇaṃ pakṣāntare āvaśyakatvān nityaṃ niyataṃ jāto 'yaṃ mṛto 'yam iti laukikapratyayavaśena yadi kalpayasi tathāpi
analyzed: kṣaṇikatva pakṣe nityam pratikṣaṇam pakṣa antare āvaśyaka tvāt nityam niyatam jātaḥ yam mṛtaḥ yam iti laukika pratyaya vaśena yadi kalpayasi tathā api
translated: In the case of momentariness, if you imagine by the power of worldly cognition that this one is born, this one dies, because it is necessary to have a different position every moment, then also,

original: he mahābāho /
analyzed: he mahā bāho
translated: O mighty-armed one,

original: puruṣadhaureyeti sopahāsaṃ kumatābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: puruṣa dhaureya iti sa upahāsam kumata abhyupagamāt
translated: calling you the best of men is a mockery, because of accepting a bad view.

original: tvayy etādṛśī kudṛṣṭir na sambhavatīti sānukampaṃ vā /
analyzed: tvayi etādṛśī kudṛṣṭiḥ na sambhavati iti sa anukampam vā
translated: Or it is with compassion, thinking such a bad view cannot arise in you.

original: evaṃ aha bata mahat pāpaṃ kartuṃ vyavasitā vayam Gītā / ity ādi yathā śocasi evaṃ prakāram anuśokaṃ kartuṃ svayam api tvaṃ tādṛśa eva
analyzed: evam aha bata mahat pāpam kartum vyavasitāḥ vayam gītāḥ iti ādi yathā śocasi evam prakāram anuśokam kartum svayam api tvam tādṛśaḥ eva
translated: Just as you lament, thinking Alas, we have resolved to commit a great sin, in that way, being such yourself,

original: san nārhasi yogyo na bhavasi /🔽kṣaṇikatvapakṣe dehātmavādapakṣe dehena
analyzed: san na arhasi yogyaḥ na bhavasi  kṣaṇikatva pakṣe deha ātma vāda pakṣe dehena
translated: you are not fit, you are not worthy,

original: saha janmavināśapakṣe ca janmāntarābhāvena pāpabhayāsambhavāt pāpabhayenaiva khalu tvam anuśocasi /
analyzed: saha janma vināśa pakṣe ca janma antara abhāvena pāpa bhaya asambhavāt pāpa bhayena eva khalu tvam anuśocasi
translated: in the case of momentariness, in the case of the view that the body is the self, in the case of the view that birth and destruction are together with the body, because there is no rebirth, you lament only out of fear of sin.

original: tac caitādṛśe darśane na sambhavati bandhuvināśadarśitvābhāvād ity adhikaṃ /
analyzed: tat ca etādṛśe darśane na sambhavati bandhu vināśa darśi tva abhāvāt iti adhikam
translated: And that is excessive, because in such a view, there is no appearance of the destruction of relatives.

original: pakṣāntare dṛṣṭaduḥkhanimittaṃ śokam abhyanujñātum evaṃkāraḥ /
analyzed: pakṣa antare dṛṣṭa duḥkha nimittam śokam abhyanujñātum evaṃkāraḥ
translated: The verse Thus... is to allow grief caused by seen suffering in another case.

original: dṛṣṭaduḥkhanimittaśokasambhave 'py adṛṣṭaduḥkhanimittaḥ śokaḥ sarvathā nocita ity arthaḥ prathamaślokasya ////
analyzed: dṛṣṭa duḥkha nimitta śoka sambhave pi adṛṣṭa duḥkha nimittaḥ śokaḥ sarvathā na ucitaḥ iti arthaḥ prathama ślokasya
translated: The sense of the first verse is that even when sorrow arises from the seen cause of suffering, sorrow from the unseen cause of suffering is in no way proper.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: tad evaṃ śāstrīyatattvadṛṣṭyā tvām ahaṃ prabodhayan /
analyzed: tat evam śāstrīya tattva dṛṣṭyā tvām aham prabodhayan
translated: Thus, awakening you with the view of the truth taught in the scriptures,

original: vyāvahārahikatattvadṛṣṭyāpi prabodhayāmi avadhehīty āha atheti /
analyzed: vyāvahāra hika tattva dṛṣṭyā api prabodhayāmi avadhehi iti āha atha iti
translated: I also awaken you with the view of the truth taught in worldly usage. Pay attention, he says with the word atha (now).

original: nityajātaṃ dehe jāte saty enaṃ nityaṃ niyataṃ jātaṃ manyase /
analyzed: nitya jātam dehe jāte sati enam nityam niyatam jātam manyase
translated: When the body is born, you think it is eternally and certainly born.

original: tathā deha eva mṛte mṛtaṃ nityaṃ niyataṃ manyase /
analyzed: tathā dehe eva mṛte mṛtam nityam niyatam manyase
translated: Similarly, when the body dies, you think it is eternally and certainly dead.

original: mahābāho iti parākramavataḥ kṣatriyasya tava tad api yuddham avaśyakaṃ svadharmaḥ / yad uktaṃ
analyzed: mahā bāho iti parākramavataḥ kṣatriyasya tava tat api yuddham avaśyakam svadharmaḥ yat uktam
translated: O mighty-armed one, that battle is also your necessary duty, as it is for a valorous kshatriya. As it is said:

original: kṣatriyāṇām ayaṃ dharmaḥ prajāpativinirmitaḥ /
analyzed: kṣatriyāṇām ayam dharmaḥ prajāpati vinirmitaḥ
translated: This is the duty of kshatriyas, created by Prajapati.

original: bhrātāpi bhrātaraṃ hanyād yena ghorataras tataḥ // iti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: bhrātā api bhrātaram hanyāt yena ghorataraḥ tatas iti bhāvaḥ
translated: A brother should kill his brother, for that is more terrible. This is the idea.

original: baladevaḥ / evaṃ svoktasya jīvātmano 'śocyatvam uktvā paroktasyāpi tasya tad ucyate paramatajñānāya /
analyzed: baladevaḥ evam sva uktasya śocya tvam uktvā para uktasya api tasya tat ucyate para mata jñānāya
translated: Balarama: Having thus stated the imperishability of the individual soul taught by himself, he now states the imperishability of the same taught by others, for the knowledge of other's views.

original: tadabhijñaḥ khalu śiṣyas tadavakarais tan nirasya vijayī san svamate sthairyam āsīt /
analyzed: tad abhijñaḥ khalu śiṣyaḥ tad avakaraiḥ tat nirasya vijayī san sva mate sthairyam āsīt
translated: The disciple who is aware of that, having refuted that with its own arguments, being victorious, remains firm in his own view.

original: tathā hi manuṣyatvādiviśiṣṭe bhūmyādibhūtacatuṣṭaye tāmbūlarāgavat madaśaktivac ca caitanyam utpadyate /
analyzed: tathā hi manuṣya tva ādi viśiṣṭe bhūmi ādi bhūta catuṣṭaye tāmbūla rāga vat mada śakti vat ca caitanyam utpadyate
translated: Thus, consciousness arises in the four elements such as earth, distinguished by humanity, etc., like the redness of betel nut, like the power of intoxication.

original: tādṛśas taccatuṣṭayabhūto deha evātmā /
analyzed: tādṛśaḥ tad catuṣṭaya bhūtaḥ dehaḥ eva ātmā
translated: That very body, which is of such a nature and is composed of those four elements, is the self.

original: sa ca sthiro 'pi pratikṣaṇapariṇāmād utpattivināśayogīti lokapratyakṣasiddham iti lokāyatikā manyante /
analyzed: sa ca sthiraḥ prati kṣaṇa pariṇāmāt utpatti vināśa yogī iti loka pratyakṣa siddham iti lokāyatikāḥ manyante
translated: And that [self], although permanent, is subject to origination and destruction due to moment-to-moment transformation, so it is established by the direct perception of the world, thus the Lokāyata thinkers think.

original: dehād bhinno vijñānasvarūpo 'py ātmā pratikṣaṇavināśīti vaibhāṣikādayo bauddhā vadanti /
analyzed: dehāt bhinnaḥ vijñāna sva rūpaḥ pi ātmā pratikṣaṇa vināśī iti vaibhāṣika ādayaḥ bauddhāḥ vadanti
translated: The Buddhists such as the Vaibhāṣikas say that the self, which is of the nature of consciousness and different from the body, is subject to moment-to-moment destruction.

original: tad etad ubhayamate 'py ātmanaḥ śocyatvaṃ pratiṣedhati /
analyzed: tat etat ubhaya mate pi ātmanaḥ śocya tvam pratiṣedhati
translated: He [Śāntarakṣita] refutes the sorrowfulness of the self in both of these views.

original: atheti pakṣāntare /
analyzed: atha iti pakṣa antare
translated: Now [means] in another case.

original: co 'pyarthe /
analyzed: caḥ pi arthe
translated: And [means] also.

original: tvaṃ cen maduktajīvātmayāthātmyāvagāhanāsamartho lokāyatikādipakṣam ālambase /
analyzed: tvam ced mad ukta jīvātma yāthātmya avagāhana asamarthaḥ lokāyatika ādi pakṣam ālambase
translated: If you, being unable to understand the true nature of the living self as I have explained it, rely on the view of the Lokāyata and others,

original: tatra dehātmapakṣe enaṃ dehalakṣaṇam ātmānaṃ nityaṃ vā
analyzed: tatra deha ātma pakṣe enam deha lakṣaṇam ātmānam nityam vā
translated: there, in the view that the body is the self, you consider this self characterized by the body to be either eternal

original: mṛtaṃ manyase /
analyzed: mṛtam manyase
translated: or dead.

original: vāśabdaś cārthe /
analyzed: vā śabdaḥ ca arthe
translated: The word or [means] also.

original: tathāpi tvam enaṃ aho bata mahat pāpaṃ ity ādivacanaiḥ śocituṃ nārhasi /
analyzed: tathā api tvam enam aho bata mahat pāpam iti ādi vacanaiḥ śocitum nā arhasi
translated: Still, you should not grieve for him with such words as 'Alas! What a great calamity!'

original: pariṇāmasvabhāvasya tasya tasya cātmano janmavināśayor anivāryatvāj janmāntarābhāvena pāpabhayāsambhavāc ca /
analyzed: pariṇāma svabhāvasya tasya tasya ca ātmanaḥ janma vināśayoḥ anivārya tvāt janma antara abhāvena pāpa bhaya asambhavāt ca
translated: Because the nature of transformation is inevitable for him and for that self, and because there is no possibility of sin due to the absence of rebirth.

original: he mahābāho iti sopahāsaṃ sambodhanaṃ kṣatriyavaryasya vaidikasya ca te nedṛśaṃ kumataṃ dhāryam iti bhāvaḥ ///
analyzed: he mahā bāho iti sa upahāsam sambodhanam kṣatriya varyasya vaidikasya ca te na īdṛśam kumatam dhāryam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: O mighty-armed one, the address with a taunt is to convey that such a bad opinion should not be held by you, who are the best of the Kshatriyas and a Vedic scholar.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyur dhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca /
analyzed: jātasya hi dhruvaḥ mṛtyuḥ dhruvam janma mṛtasya ca
translated: For one who is born, death is certain; and for one who dies, birth is certain.

original: tasmād aparihārye 'rthe na tvaṃ śocitum arhasi ////
analyzed: tasmāt aparihārye rthe na tvam śocitum arhasi
translated: Therefore, for an inevitable thing, you should not grieve.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kuta iti /
analyzed: śrīdharaḥ kutas iti
translated: Shridhar: Why?

original: ata āha jātasyetyādi /
analyzed: atas āha jātasya ityādi
translated: To that, the Lord says, 'For one who is born,' etc.

original: hi yasmāj jātasya svārambhakakarmakṣaye mṛtyur dhruvo niścitaḥ /
analyzed: hi yasmāt jātasya sva ārambhaka karma kṣaye mṛtyuḥ dhruvaḥ niścitaḥ
translated: For, since the death of one who is born is certain when the actions that caused his birth are exhausted,

original: mṛtasya ca taddehakṛtena karmaṇā janmāpi dhruvam eva /
analyzed: mṛtasya ca tad deha kṛtena karmaṇā janma api dhruvam eva
translated: and birth is also certain for one who dies by the action done in that body,

original: tasmād evam aparihārye 'rthe avaśyambhāvini janmamaraṇalakṣaṇe 'rthe tvaṃ vidvān śocitum nārhasi yogyo na bhavasi ////
analyzed: tasmāt evam aparihārye rthe avaśyambhāvini janma maraṇa lakṣaṇe rthe tvam vidvān śocitum na arhasi yogyaḥ na bhavasi
translated: therefore, for an inevitable thing, for an inevitable matter characterized by birth and death, you, being wise, should not grieve, you are not fit to grieve.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: nanv ātmana ābhūtasaṃplavasthāyitvapakṣe ca dṛṣṭādṛṣṭaduḥkhasambhavāt tadbhayena śocāmīty ata āha dvitīyaślokena jātasya hīti /
analyzed: nanu ātmanaḥ ābhūtasaṃplava sthāyi tva pakṣe ca dṛṣṭa adṛṣṭa duḥkha sambhavāt tad bhayena śocāmi iti atas āha dvitīya ślokena jātasya hi iti
translated: Objection: If the soul is eternal, existing till the dissolution of all elements, then, since seen and unseen sorrows are possible, I grieve out of fear of them. To this, the Lord says in the second verse, 'For one who is born...'

original: hi yasmāj jātasya svakṛtadharmādharmādivaśāl labdhaśarīrendriyādisambandhasya
analyzed: hi yasmāt jātasya sva kṛta dharma adharma ādi vaśāt labdha śarīra indriya ādi sambandhasya
translated: For, since one who is born, who has obtained the connection with the body, senses, etc. by the power of his own done virtues, sins, etc.,

original: sthirasyātmano dhruva āvaśyako mṛtyus taccharīrādivicchedas tadārambhakakarmakṣayanimittaḥ
analyzed: sthirasya ātmanaḥ dhruvaḥ āvaśyakaḥ mṛtyuḥ tad śarīra ādi vicchedaḥ tad ārambhaka karma kṣaya nimittaḥ
translated: death, the separation of that body, etc., which is caused by the exhaustion of the actions that produced it, is certain, inevitable, for the stable soul.

original: saṃyogasya viyogāvasānatvāt /
analyzed: saṃyogasya viyoga avasāna tvāt
translated: Because the end of conjunction is separation.

original: tathā dhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca prāgdehakṛtakarmaphalopabhogārthaṃ sānuśayasyaiva prastutatvān na jīvanmukte vyabhicāraḥ /
analyzed: tathā dhruvam janma mṛtasya ca prāc deha kṛta karma phala upabhoga artham sa anuśayasya eva prastuta tvāt na jīvanmukte vyabhicāraḥ
translated: Similarly, birth is certain for one who has died, for the enjoyment of the fruits of actions done in a previous body, because one with residual tendencies is being discussed. There is no invalidation in the case of one liberated while living.

original: tasmād evam aparihārye parihartum aśakye 'smin janmamaraṇalakṣaṇe 'rthe viṣaye tvam evaṃ vidvān na śocitum arhasi /
analyzed: tasmāt evam aparihārye parihartum aśakye smin janma maraṇa lakṣaṇe rthe viṣaye tvam evam vidvān na śocitum arhasi
translated: Therefore, you, knowing this, should not grieve over this inevitable matter, which is unavoidable and cannot be averted, characterized by birth and death.

original: tathā ca vakṣyati ṛte 'pi tvāṃ na bhaviṣyanti sarve Gītā / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyati ṛte tvām na bhaviṣyanti sarve gītāḥ iti
translated: And thus he will say, 'Even without you, all will not exist' (Gītā).

original: yadi hi tvayā yuddhe 'nāhanyamānā ete jīveyur eva tadā yuddhāya śokas tavocitaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi hi tvayā yuddhe na a hanyamānāḥ ete jīveyuḥ eva tadā yuddhāya śokaḥ tava ucitaḥ syāt
translated: For if these were to live, not being struck by you in battle, then grief on your part would be proper for the battle.

original: ete tu karmakṣayāt
analyzed: ete tu karma kṣayāt
translated: But these die by themselves, due to the exhaustion of their karma.

original: svayam eva mriyanta iti tatparihārāsamarthasya tava dṛṣṭduḥkhanimittaḥ śoko nocita iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: svayam eva mriyante iti tad parihāra asamarthasya tava dṛṣṭ duḥkha nimittaḥ śokaḥ na ucitaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: So grief on your part, which is incapable of averting that, is not proper for the cause of seen suffering. This is the idea.

original: evam adṛṣṭaduḥkhanimitte 'pi śoke tasmād aparihārye 'rthe ity evottaram /
analyzed: evam adṛṣṭa duḥkha nimitte śoke tasmāt aparihārye rthe iti eva uttaram
translated: Similarly, even in grief caused by unseen suffering, the answer is Therefore, in that unavoidable matter.

original: yuddhākhyaṃ hi karma kṣatriyasya niyatam agnihotrādivat /
analyzed: yuddha ākhyam hi karma kṣatriyasya niyatam agnihotra ādi vat
translated: For the duty of a kshatriya is war, like the agnihotra and other [sacrifices].

original: tac ca yudha samprahāre ity asmād dhātor niṣpannaṃ śatruprāṇaviyogānukūlaśastraprahārarūpaṃ vihitatvāgnīṣomīyādisiṃhāvan na pratyavāyajanakam
analyzed: tat ca samprahāre iti asmāt dhātoḥ niṣpannam śatru prāṇa viyoga anukūla śastra prahāra rūpam vihita tva agnīṣomīya ādi siṃhā vat na pratyavāya janakam
translated: And that is accomplished from the verbal root yudh meaning to fight, and has the form of a blow with a weapon favorable to the separation of the enemy's life, like the agnisomiya and other [sacrifices], and does not cause a sin.

original: tathā ca gautamaḥ smarati na doṣo hiṃsāyām āhave 'nyatra vyaśvāsārathyanuyudhakṛtāñjaliprakīrṇakeśaparāṅmukhopaviṣṭasthalavṛkṣārūḍhadūtagobrāhmaṇavādibhyaḥ
analyzed: tathā ca gautamaḥ smarati na doṣaḥ hiṃsāyām āhave nyatra vyaśva asārathi anuyudha kṛtāñjali prakīrṇa keśa parāṅmukha upaviṣṭa sthala vṛkṣa ārūḍha dūta go brāhmaṇa vādibhyaḥ
translated: And thus Gautama remembers: There is no sin in killing in battle, except for those without horses, charioteers, weapons, with folded hands, with disheveled hair, facing away, sitting on the ground, on trees, messengers, cows, Brahmins, and those who speak.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: brāhmaṇagrahaṇaṃcātrāyoddhṛbrāhmaṇaviṣayaṃ gavādiprāyapāṭhād iti sthitam /
analyzed: brāhmaṇa grahaṇam ca atra ayoddhṛ brāhmaṇa viṣayam gavādi prāya pāṭhāt iti sthitam
translated: And the mention of the Brāhmaṇa here is to be taken as referring to the Brāhmaṇa who has taken up arms, because of the predominance of the mention of the cow etc. This is the settled conclusion.

original: etac ca sarvaṃ svadharmam api cāvekṣyety atra spaṣṭīkariṣyati /🔽tathā ca yuddhalakṣaṇe 'rthe 'gnihotrādivad vihitatvād aparihārye parihartum aśakye tadakaraṇe pratyavāyaprasaṅgāt tvam adṛṣṭaduḥkhabhayena
analyzed: etat ca sarvam svadharmam api ca avekṣya iti atra spaṣṭīkariṣyati  tathā ca yuddha lakṣaṇe rthe gnihotra ādi vat vihita tvāt aparihārye parihartum aśakye tad akaraṇe pratyavāya prasaṅgāt tvam adṛṣṭa duḥkha bhayena
translated: And all this will be made clear in the passage, Having also considered your own duty.🔽And thus, in the matter characterized by battle, since it is enjoined like the Agnihotra etc., and is unavoidable, i.e., cannot be avoided, since there would be a calamity if it is not performed, you should not grieve out of fear of unseen suffering,

original: śocituṃ nārahasīti pūrvavat /
analyzed: śocitum na arahasi iti pūrvavat
translated: as before.

original: yadi tu yuddhākhyaṃ karma kāmyam eva 🔽ya āhaveṣu yudhyante bhūmyartham aparāṅmukhāḥ /
analyzed: yadi tu yuddha ākhyam karma kāmyam eva  ye āhaveṣu yudhyante bhūmi artham a parāṅmukhāḥ
translated: But if the action called battle is only an optional rite,🔽Those who fight in battles for the sake of land, not turning away,

original: akūṭair āyudhair yānti te svargaṃ yogino yathā // Yajñ / /
analyzed: akūṭaiḥ āyudhaiḥ yānti te svargam yoginaḥ yathā
translated: with weapons that are not deceitful, go to heaven like yogis.

original: iti yājñavalkyavacanāt /
analyzed: iti yājñavalkya vacanāt
translated: Thus says Yājñavalkya.

original: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm Gītā / iti bhagavadvacanāc ca /
analyzed: hataḥ vā prāpsyasi svargam jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm gītāḥ iti bhagavat vacanāt ca
translated: Either killed, you will attain heaven, or victorious, you will enjoy the earth. Thus says the Blessed Lord.

original: tadāpi prārabdhasya kāmyasyāpi avaśyaparisamāpanīyatvena nityatulyatvāt tvayā ca yuddhasya prārabdhatvād aparihāryatvaṃ tyulyam eva /
analyzed: tadā api prārabdhasya kāmyasya api avaśya parisamāpanīya tvena nitya tulya tvāt tvayā ca yuddhasya prārabdha tvāt aparihārya tvam tyulyam eva
translated: Even then, since even an optional rite that has been begun must necessarily be completed, it is as obligatory as a compulsory rite, and since the battle has been begun by you, it is equally unavoidable.

original: athavātmanityatvapakṣa eva ślokadvayam arjunasya paramāstikasya vedabāhyamatābhyupagamāsambhavāt /
analyzed: athavā ātma nitya tva pakṣe eva śloka dvayam arjunasya parama āstikasya veda bāhya mata abhyupagama asambhavāt
translated: Or, in the case of the view of the self's eternality, there are two verses, because it is impossible for Arjuna, a great theist, to accept non-Vedic doctrines.

original: akṣarayojanā tu nityaś cāsau dehendriyādisambandhavaśāj jātaś ceti nityajātas
analyzed: akṣara yojanā tu nityaḥ ca asau deha indriya ādi sambandha vaśāt jātaḥ ca iti nityajātaḥ
translated: As for the interpretation of the word akṣara (imperishable), it is both eternal and born due to the connection with the body, senses, etc.

original: tam enam ātmānaṃ nityam api santaṃ jātaṃ cen manyase tathā nityam api santaṃ mṛtaṃ
analyzed: tam enam ātmānam nityam api santam jātam ced manyase tathā nityam api santam mṛtam
translated: If you think that this self, though eternal, is born, and likewise, though eternal, is dead,

original: cen manyase tathāpi tvaṃ nānuśocitum arhasīti hetum āha jātasya hīty ādinā /
analyzed: ced manyase tathā api tvam na anuśocitum arhasi iti hetum āha jātasya hi iti ādinā
translated: then also you should not grieve. The reason is stated by jātasya hi (of one who is born), etc.

original: nityasya jātatvaṃ mṛtatvaṃ ca prāgvyākhyātam /
analyzed: nityasya jāta tvam mṛta tvam ca prāk vyākhyātam
translated: The eternality of the born and the dead has been explained before.

original: spaṣṭam anyat /
analyzed: spaṣṭam anyat
translated: The rest is clear.

original: bhāṣyam apy asmin pakṣe yojanīyam ////
analyzed: bhāṣyam api asmin pakṣe yojanīyam
translated: The commentary should also be applied in this case.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /🔽hi yasmāt tasya svārambhakakarmakṣaye mṛtyur dhruvo niścitaḥ /
analyzed: hi yasmāt tasya sva ārambhaka karma kṣaye mṛtyuḥ dhruvaḥ niścitaḥ
translated: Visvanatha.🔽Hi, because, for him, death is certain when the karma that causes his birth is exhausted.

original: mṛtasya ca taddehakṛtena karmaṇā janmāpi dhruvam eva /
analyzed: mṛtasya ca tad deha kṛtena karmaṇā janma api dhruvam eva
translated: And for one who is dead, birth is also certain due to the karma done in that body.

original: aparihārye 'rthe iti mṛtyur janma ca parihartum acakyam eva ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: aparihārye rthe iti mṛtyuḥ janma ca parihartum acakyam eva iti arthaḥ
translated: In an unavoidable matter, the meaning is that death and birth are indeed unavoidable.

original: baladevaḥ / atha śarīrātirikto nitya ātmā /
analyzed: baladevaḥ atha śarīra atiriktaḥ nityaḥ ātmā
translated: Baladeva. Now, the self is different from the body and is eternal.

original: tasyāpūrvaśarīrendriyayogo janma /
analyzed: tasya apūrva śarīra indriya yogaḥ janma
translated: Birth is the union of the eternal self with a new body and senses.

original: pūrvaśarīrendriyaviyogas tu maraṇaṃ tadubhayaṃ ca dharmādharmahetukatvāt tadāśrayasya nityasyātmano mukhyaṃ /
analyzed: pūrva śarīra indriya viyogaḥ tu maraṇam tat ubhayam ca dharma adharma hetuka tvāt tad āśrayasya nityasya ātmanaḥ mukhyam
translated: But death is the separation of the self from a previous body and senses. And since both of these are caused by virtue and vice, the primary [cause of birth and death] is the eternal self, which is their substratum.

original: tadatiriktasya śarīrasya tu gauṇam /
analyzed: tad atiriktasya śarīrasya tu gauṇam
translated: But the body, which is different from that [self], is secondary.

original: tasyānityasya kṛtahānyakṛtābhyāgamaprasaṅgena tadāśrayatvānupapatter iti tārkikā manyante /
analyzed: tasya anityasya kṛta hāni akṛta abhyāgama prasaṅgena tad āśraya tva anupapatteḥ iti tārkikāḥ manyante
translated: Because it is impossible for it to be the substratum of the self, since it would then follow that the self would be subject to the loss of what is done and the experience of what is not done, since it is impermanent. This is what the logicians think.

original: tatpakṣe 'py ātmanaḥ śocyatvaṃ pariharati jātasyeti /
analyzed: tad pakṣe pi ātmanaḥ śocya tvam pariharati jātasya iti
translated: Even in their view, he [Bhishma] avoids the sorrowfulness of the self by saying of one who is born, etc.

original: hir hetau /
analyzed: hiḥ hetau
translated: Hi is for cause.

original: jātasya svakarmavaśāt prāptaśarīrādiyogasya nityasyāpy ātmanas tadārambhakakarmakṣayahetuko mṛtyur dhruvo niścitaḥ /
analyzed: jātasya sva karma vaśāt prāpta śarīra ādi yogasya nityasya api ātmanaḥ tad ārambhaka karma kṣaya hetukaḥ mṛtyuḥ dhruvaḥ niścitaḥ
translated: For one who is born, who has attained the union with a body, etc. by the power of his own actions, even though he is eternal, death is certain, caused by the exhaustion of the actions that produced that [body].

original: mṛtasya taccharīrakṛtakarmahetukaṃ janma ca dhruvaṃ syāt /
analyzed: mṛtasya tad śarīra kṛta karma hetukam janma ca dhruvam syāt
translated: And birth, caused by the actions done by that [body], would certainly occur for one who has died.

original: tasmād evam aparihārye parihartum aśakye janmamaraṇātmake 'rthe tvaṃ vidvān śocituṃ nārhasi /
analyzed: tasmāt evam aparihārye parihartum aśakye janma maraṇa ātmake rthe tvam vidvān śocitum nā arhasi
translated: Therefore, in this unavoidable, inescapable matter consisting of birth and death, you, being wise, should not grieve.

original: tvayi yuddhān nivṛtte 'py ete svārambhake karmaṇi kṣīṇe sati mariṣyanty eva /
analyzed: tvayi yuddhāt nivṛtte pi ete svārambhake karmaṇi kṣīṇe sati mariṣyanti eva
translated: Even if you were to turn away from the battle, they would die when their own actions that produced them are exhausted.

original: tava tu svadharmād vicyutir bhāvinīti
analyzed: tava tu svadharmāt vicyutiḥ bhāvinī iti
translated: But in your case, there will be a falling away from your own duty.

original: bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the idea.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyaktamadhyāni bhārata /
analyzed: avyakta ādīni bhūtāni vyakta madhyāni bhārata
translated: The beings have the unmanifest for their beginning, the manifest for their middle, O scion of the Bharata dynasty,

original: avyaktanidhanāny eva tatra kā paridevanā ////
analyzed: avyakta nidhanāni eva tatra kā paridevanā
translated: and the unmanifest for their end. What is there to grieve about in this?

original: śrīdharaḥ / kiṃ ca dehānāṃ svabhāvaṃ paryālocya tadupādhike ātmano janmamaraṇe śoko na kārya iti /
analyzed: ca              na   iti
translated: Moreover, considering the nature of the bodies, grief should not be indulged in with regard to the birth and death of the Self which is qualified by them.

original: ata āha avyaktādīnīty ādi /
analyzed: atas āha avyakta ādīni iti ādi
translated: To this, the Lord says: The beings, etc.

original: avyaktaṃ pradhānam /
analyzed: avyaktam pradhānam
translated: The unmanifest is the primordial material nature.

original: tad eva ādir utpatteḥ pūrvarūpaṃ yeṣāṃ tāni avyaktādīni /
analyzed: tat eva ādiḥ utpatteḥ pūrva rūpam yeṣām tāni avyakta ādīni
translated: Those which have that alone as their beginning, i.e. their prior form, are the unmanifest-originated.

original: bhūtāni śarīrāṇi /
analyzed: bhūtāni śarīrāṇi
translated: The beings are the bodies.

original: kāraṇātmanāpi sthitānām eva utpatteḥ /
analyzed: kāraṇa ātmanā api sthitānām eva utpatteḥ
translated: Because they originate even while existing in the form of their cause.

original: tathā vyaktam abhivyaktaṃ madhyaṃ janmamaraṇāntarālaṃ sthitilakṣaṇaṃ yeṣāṃ tāni vyaktamadhyāni /
analyzed: tathā vyaktam abhivyaktam madhyam janma maraṇa antarālam sthiti lakṣaṇam yeṣām tāni vyakta madhyāni
translated: Similarly, those which have the manifest, i.e. the manifest, the middle, the period between birth and death, characterized by continuance, are the manifest-middled.

original: avyakte nidhanaṃ layo yeṣāṃ tānīmāny evaṃbhūtāny eva /
analyzed: avyakte nidhanam layaḥ yeṣām tāni imāni evaṃbhūtāni eva
translated: Those which have the unmanifest for their end, i.e. dissolution, are these very ones.

original: tatra teṣu kā paridevanā /
analyzed: tatra teṣu kā paridevanā
translated: What is there to grieve about in this?

original: kaḥ śokanimitto vilāpaḥ /
analyzed: kaḥ śoka nimittaḥ vilāpaḥ
translated: What is the lamentation caused by grief?

original: pratibuddhasya svapnadṛṣṭavastuṣv iva śoko na yujyata ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: pratibuddhasya svapna dṛṣṭa vastuṣu iva śokaḥ na yujyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that grief is not proper for one who is enlightened, just as with regard to the objects seen in a dream.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana

original: tad evaṃ sarvaprakāreṇātmano 'śocyatvam upapāditam athedānīm ātmano 'śocyatve 'pi bhūtasaṅghātātmakāni śarīrāṇy uddiśya śocāmīty arjunāśaṅkām
analyzed: tat evam sarva prakāreṇa ātmanoḥ śocya tvam upapāditam atha idānīm ātmanoḥ śocya tve pi bhūta saṅghāta ātmakāni śarīrāṇi uddiśya śocāmi iti arjuna āśaṅkām
translated: Thus, in every way, the non-mournability of the self has been established. Now, even though the self is non-mournable, the Blessed Lord removes Arjuna's doubt that he mourns with reference to the bodies consisting of collections of elements,

original: apanudati bhagavān avyaktādīnīti /
analyzed: apanudati bhagavān avyakta ādīni iti
translated: saying the unmanifest, etc.

original: ādau janmanaḥ prāgavyaktāni anupalabdhāni bhūtāni pṛthivyādibhūtamayāni śarīrāṇi madhye janmānantaraṃ maraṇāt prāgvyaktāni upalabdhāni
analyzed: ādau janmanaḥ prāk avyaktāni anupalabdhāni bhūtāni pṛthivī ādi bhūta mayāni śarīrāṇi madhye janma anantaram maraṇāt prāk vyaktāni upalabdhāni
translated: Before birth, the elements, which are the bodies consisting of the elements such as earth, were unmanifest, i.e., imperceptible. In the middle, after birth and before death, they were manifest, i.e., perceptible.

original: nidhane punar avyaktāny eva bhavanti /
analyzed: nidhane punar avyaktāni eva bhavanti
translated: At the end, they again become unmanifest.

original: yathā svapnendrajālādau pratibhāsamātrajīvanāni śuktirūpyādivan na tu jñānāt prāg ūrdhvaṃ vā sthitāni dṛṣṭisṛṣṭyabhyupagamāt /
analyzed: yathā svapna indrajāla ādau pratibhāsa mātra jīvanāni śukti rūpya ādi vat na tu jñānāt prāk ūrdhvam vā sthitāni dṛṣṭi sṛṣṭi abhyupagamāt
translated: Just as in a dream, a magical illusion, etc., they exist merely as appearances, like the silver in a shell, and are not seen to exist before or after knowledge, because of the acceptance of the creation by the seeing.

original: tathā ca ādāv ante ca yan nāsti vartamāne 'pi tat tathā ṃā / Kā / / iti nyāyena madhye 'pi na santy evaitāni /
analyzed: tathā ca ādau ante ca yat na asti vartamāne tat tathā iti nyāyena madhye na santi eva etāni
translated: And thus, in the middle also, they do not exist, because of the maxim: What does not exist at the beginning and end, that is so also in the present.

original: nāsato vidyate bhāvaḥ Gītā / iti prāgukteś ca /
analyzed: na asataḥ vidyate bhāvaḥ gītā iti prāgukteḥ ca
translated: And because it has been said before: The non-existent does not become existent.

original: evaṃ sati tatra teṣu mithyābhūteṣv atyantatuccheṣu bhūteṣu kā paridevanā ko vā duḥkhapralāpo na ko 'py ucita ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: evam sati tatra teṣu mithyābhūteṣu atyanta tuccheṣu bhūteṣu kā paridevanā kaḥ vā duḥkha pralāpaḥ na kaḥ api ucitaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: When this is so, then what lamentation, what grieving, is there over those false elements, which are utterly worthless? The meaning is that none at all is proper.

original: na hi svapne vividhān bandhūn upalabhya pratibuddhas tadvicchedena śocati pṛthagjano 'pi etad evoktaṃ purāṇe adarśanād āpatitaḥ punaś cādarśanaṃ
analyzed: na hi svapne vividhān bandhūn upalabhya pratibuddhaḥ tad vicchedena śocati etat eva uktam purāṇe adarśanāt āpatitaḥ punar ca adarśanam
translated: For even an ordinary person, having experienced various relatives in a dream, does not grieve at their cessation upon waking. This very thing is stated in the Purana: Having come from the unseen, and again gone to the unseen,

original: gataḥ bhūtasaṅgha iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: gataḥ bhūta saṅghaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: the end is that the collection of elements is destroyed.

original: tathā ca śarīrāṇy apy uddiśya śoko nocita iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca śarīrāṇi api uddiśya śokaḥ na ucitaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus the meaning is that grief is not proper even with regard to the bodies.

original: ākāśādimahābhūtābhiprāyeṇa vā śloko yojyaḥ /
analyzed: ākāśa ādi mahābhūta abhiprāyeṇa vā ślokaḥ yojyaḥ
translated: Or the verse should be applied with the intention of the great elements such as space.

original: avyaktam avyākṛtam avidyopahitacaitanyam ādiḥ prāg avasthā yeṣāṃ tāni tathā vyaktaṃ
analyzed: avyaktam avyākṛtam avidyā upahita caitanyam ādiḥ prāk avasthā yeṣām tāni tathā vyaktam
translated: Those for whom the unmanifest, the undefined, consciousness enveloped by ignorance, is the beginning, the prior state, they are so. The manifest

original: nāmarūpābhyām evāvidyakābhyāṃ prakaṭībhūtaṃ na tu svena paramārthasadātmanā madhyaṃ
analyzed: nāma rūpābhyām eva avidyakābhyām prakaṭībhūtam na tu svena paramārtha sat ātmanā madhyam
translated: is that which is manifested by name and form alone, which are of the nature of ignorance, but not by itself, by its own nature of ultimate reality. The middle

original: sthityavasthā yeṣāṃ tādṛśāni bhūtāni ākāśādīni avyaktanidhanāny evāvyakte svakāraṇe
analyzed: sthiti avasthā yeṣām tādṛśāni bhūtāni ākāśa ādīni avyakta nidhanāni eva avyakte sva kāraṇe
translated: is that which has the state of persistence for them. Such elements as space, which have the unmanifest as their end, in their own cause, the unmanifest,

original: mṛd iva ghaṭādīnāṃ nidhanaṃ pralayo yeṣāṃ teṣu bhūteṣu kā paridevaneti pūrvavat /
analyzed: mṛd iva ghaṭa ādīnām nidhanam pralayaḥ yeṣām teṣu bhūteṣu kā paridevanā iti pūrvavat
translated: In the elements, which are like clay, the dissolution, the destruction, of pots etc., what is there to lament, as before.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ tad dhedaṃ tarhy avyākṛtam āsīt tannāmarūpābhyām eva vyākriyata BAU / / ity ādir avyaktopādānatāṃ sarvasya prapañcasya 🔽darśayati /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ tat dha idam tarhi avyākṛtam āsīt tat nāma rūpābhyām eva vyākriyata bau iti ādiḥ avyakta upādāna tām sarvasya prapañcasya  darśayati
translated: And thus the Śruti shows that the entire universe has the unmanifest as its material cause, beginning with Then indeed at that time this was the undifferentiated. It was differentiated by name and form alone.

original: layasthānatvaṃ tu tasyārthasiddhaṃ kāraṇa eva kāryalayasya darśanāt /
analyzed: laya sthāna tvam tu tasya artha siddham kāraṇe eva kārya layasya darśanāt
translated: But its being the place of dissolution is established by the meaning, because the dissolution of the effect is seen in the cause itself.

original: granthāntare tu vistaraḥ /
analyzed: grantha antare tu vistaraḥ
translated: And the details are in another text.

original: tathā cājñānakalpitatvena tucchāny ākāśādibhūtāny apy uddiśya śoko nocitaś cet tatkāryāṇy
analyzed: tathā ca ajñāna kalpita tvena tucchāni ākāśa ādi bhūtāni api uddiśya śokaḥ na ucitaḥ ced tad kāryāṇi
translated: And thus, if lamenting is not proper even with regard to the elements like space, which are worthless due to being imagined by ignorance,

original: uddiśya nocita iti kim u vaktavyam iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: uddiśya na ucitaḥ iti kim u vaktavyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: what need be said about lamenting with regard to their effects? This is the idea.

original: athavā sarvadā teṣām avyaktarūpeṇa vidyamānatvād vicchedābhāvena tannimittaḥ pralāpo nocita ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: athavā sarvadā teṣām avyakta rūpeṇa vidyamāna tvāt viccheda abhāvena tad nimittaḥ pralāpaḥ na ucitaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Or the meaning is: since they always exist in the form of the unmanifest, there is no separation, so lamenting caused by that is not proper.

original: bhāratety anena sambodhayan śuddhavaṃśodbhavatvena śāstrīyam arthaṃ pratipattum arho 'si kim iti na pratipadyasa iti sūcayati ////
analyzed: bhārata iti anena sambodhayan śuddha vaṃśa udbhava tvena śāstrīyam artham pratipattum arho si kim iti na pratipadyase iti sūcayati
translated: By addressing him as Bhārata, he indicates that you are worthy of understanding the scriptural meaning by being born in a pure family, so why do you not understand?

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Viśvanātha.

original: tad evaṃ na jāyate na mriyate ityādinā /
analyzed: tat evam na jāyate na mriyate ityādinā
translated: Thus, with It is not born, it does not die, etc.,

original: dehapakṣe ca jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyuḥ ity anena śokaviṣayaṃ nirākṛtya idānīm ubhayapakṣe 'pi nirākaroti avyakteti /
analyzed: deha pakṣe ca jātasya hi dhruvaḥ mṛtyuḥ iti anena śoka viṣayam nirākṛtya idānīm ubhaya pakṣe nirākaroti avyakta iti
translated: and having refuted the basis for grief with For one who is born, death is certain, he now refutes it in both cases, with Unmanifest etc.

original: bhūtāni devamanuṣyatiryagādīni /
analyzed: bhūtāni deva manuṣya tiryak ādīni
translated: The elements are gods, humans, animals, etc.

original: avyaktāni na vyaktaṃ vyaktir ādau janmapūrvakāle yeṣāṃ /
analyzed: avyaktāni na vyaktam vyaktiḥ ādau janma pūrva kāle yeṣām
translated: They are unmanifest, not manifest, not manifest at the beginning, before birth.

original: kintu tadānīm api liṅgadehaḥ sthūladehaś ca svārambhakapṛthivyādisattvāt kāraṇātmanā vartamāno 'spaṣṭam āsīd evety arthaḥ /
analyzed: kintu tadānīm api liṅga dehaḥ sthūla dehaḥ ca sva ārambhaka pṛthivī ādi sattvāt kāraṇa ātmanā vartamānaḥ spaṣṭam āsīt eva iti arthaḥ
translated: But even then, the subtle body and the gross body existed in an indistinct form, because the earth etc. that constitute them existed in the form of their causes. This is the meaning.

original: vyaktaṃ vyaktir madhye yeṣāṃ tāni /
analyzed: vyaktam vyaktiḥ madhye yeṣām tāni
translated: They are manifest, manifest in the middle, for which they are.

original: na vyakti nidhanād anantaraṃ yeṣāṃ tāni /
analyzed: na vyakti nidhanāt anantaram yeṣām tāni
translated: They are not manifest, not manifest after death, for which they are.

original: mahāpralaye 'pi karmamātrādīnāṃ sattvāt sūkṣmarūpeṇa bhūtāni santy eva /
analyzed: mahāpralaye pi karmamātra ādīnām sattvāt sūkṣma rūpeṇa bhūtāni santi eva
translated: Even in the great dissolution, the elements exist in a subtle form because of the existence of mere karma etc.

original: tasmāt sarvabhūtāni ādyantarayor avyaktāni madhye vyaktānīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt sarva bhūtāni ādi antarayoḥ avyaktāni madhye vyaktāni iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, all beings are unmanifest at the beginning and end, manifest in the middle. This is the meaning.

original: yad uktaṃ śrutibhiḥ sthiracarajātayaḥ syur ajayotthanimittayujaḥ iti /
analyzed: yat uktam śrutibhiḥ sthira cara jātayaḥ syuḥ ajayā uttha nimitta yujaḥ iti
translated: As stated by the scriptures: The stable and moving species would be connected with the cause arising from the unborn.

original: kā paridevanā kaḥ śokanimittaḥ vilāpaḥ /
analyzed: kā paridevanā kaḥ śoka nimittaḥ vilāpaḥ
translated: What is the lamentation? What is the cause of grief? What is the wailing?

original: tathā coktaṃ nāradena
analyzed: tathā ca uktam nāradena
translated: And thus it is said by Narada:

original: yan manyase dhruvaṃ lokam adhruvaṃ vā na cobhayam /
analyzed: yat manyase dhruvam lokam adhruvam vā na ca ubhayam
translated: Whether you consider the world to be permanent, impermanent, or neither,

original: sarvathā na hi śocyās te snehād anyatra mohajāt // BhP / / iti ////
analyzed: sarvathā na hi śocyāḥ te snehāt anyatra moha jāt
translated: in no case should you grieve for them out of affection, except from delusion.

original: baladevaḥ / atha dehātmapakṣe ātmātiriktadehapakṣe ca dehavināśahetukaśoko na yuktas tadārambhakāṇāṃ bhūtamātrāṇām avināśād ity āha
analyzed: baladevaḥ atha deha ātma pakṣe ātma atirikta deha pakṣe ca deha vināśa hetuka śokaḥ na yuktaḥ tad ārambhakāṇām bhūtamātrāṇām avināśāt iti āha  /
translated: Balarama. Now, grief caused by the destruction of the body is not proper, whether it be the side of the body being the self or the side of the body being separate from the self, because the subtle elements which are the constituents of the body are not destroyed. Thus he says:

original: avyaktādīnīti /🔽avyaktaṃ nāmarūpavirahāt sūkṣmaṃ pradhānam ādi ādirūpaṃ yeṣāṃ tāni avyaktanidhanāni /
analyzed: avyakta ādīni iti  avyaktam nāma rūpa virahāt sūkṣmam pradhānam ādi ādi rūpam yeṣām tāni avyakta nidhanāni
translated: From the unmanifest, etc.🔽The unmanifest is the subtle primordial matter, which is devoid of name and form. Those which have it as their beginning are from the unmanifest.

original: avyakte tādṛśi pradhāne nidhanaṃ nāmarūpavimardanalakṣaṇo nāśo yeṣāṃ tāni /
analyzed: avyakte tādṛśi pradhāne nidhanam nāma rūpa vimardana lakṣaṇaḥ nāśaḥ yeṣām tāni
translated: Those which have destruction in that kind of primordial matter which is unmanifest, characterized by the dissolution of name and form, are from the unmanifest.

original: mṛdādike sadrūpe dravye kambugrīvādyavasthāyoge ghaṭasyotpattis tadvirodhikapālādyavasthāyogas tu tasya vināśaḥ kathyate /
analyzed: mṛd ādike sat rūpe dravye kambu grīvā ādi avasthā yoge ghaṭasya utpattiḥ tad virodhi kapāla ādi avasthā yogaḥ tu tasya vināśaḥ kathyate
translated: When a substance like clay assumes the state of a pot with a neck, etc., the origin of the pot is spoken of. But when it assumes the state of a potsherd, etc., which is contrary to that, its destruction is spoken of.

original: taddravyaṃ sarvadā sthāyīti /
analyzed: tat dravyam sarvadā sthāyi iti
translated: That substance always remains.

original: evam evāha bhagavān parāśaraḥ mahī ghaṭatvaṃ ghaṭataḥ kapālikā cūrṇarajas tato 'ṇuḥ ViP / / iti /
analyzed: evam eva āha bhagavān parāśaraḥ mahī ghaṭa tvam ghaṭataḥ kapālikā cūrṇa rajaḥ tatas ṇuḥ vip iti
translated: Thus has the revered Parāśara said: The jar becomes the potsherds, the potsherds become dust and powder, and from that the atom.

original: evaṃ śarīrāṇy ādyantayor nāmarūpāyogād avyaktimanti /
analyzed: evam śarīrāṇi ādi antayoḥ nāma rūpa ayogāt avyaktimanti
translated: Thus, the bodies are non-manifest at the beginning and end, because of the absence of name and form.

original: madhye tu tadyogād vyaktimanti /
analyzed: madhye tu tad yogāt vyaktimanti
translated: But in the middle, they are manifest because of the presence of that [name and form].

original: tadārambhakāni bhūtāni tu sarvadā santīti teṣu vastutaḥ
analyzed: tad ārambhakāni bhūtāni tu sarvadā santi iti teṣu vastutas
translated: But the elements that compose them are always present. Therefore, when they actually exist,

original: satsu kā paridevanā kaḥ śokanimittavilāpa ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: satsu kā paridevanā kaḥ śoka nimitta vilāpaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: what is the lamentation, what is the wailing caused by grief? This is the meaning.

original: dehānyanityātmapakṣe tu vāsāṃsi ity ādikaṃ na vismartavyam /
translated: But in the view of the non-eternal self that is different from the body, one should not forget the words beginning with the garments.

original: yat tv ādyantayor asattvān madhye 'pi bhūtāny asanty evātaḥ svāpnikarathāśvādiprakhyāni
analyzed: yat tu ādi antayoḥ asattvāt madhye bhūtāni asanti eva atas svāpnika ratha aśva ādi prakhyāni
translated: But because of the non-existence at the beginning and end, the elements do not exist even in the middle. Therefore, they are false, like chariots, horses, etc. in a dream.

original: mṛṣābhūtāny eva tena tadviyogahetukaḥ śokaḥ pratibuddhasya na dṛṣṭa iti dṛṣṭisṛṣṭim
analyzed: mṛṣābhūtāni eva tena tad viyoga hetukaḥ śokaḥ pratibuddhasya na dṛṣṭaḥ iti dṛṣṭi sṛṣṭim
translated: Hence, grief caused by separation from them is not seen in one who is enlightened. Therefore, they say that one should accept the creation by perception.

original: abhyupaityāhus tan mandaṃ tadabhyupagame vaidikāsatkāryavādāpatteḥ /
analyzed: abhyupaiti āhuḥ tat mandam tad abhyupagame vaidika asat kārya vāda āpatteḥ
translated: But that is wrong, because if one accepts that, it would lead to the undesirable consequence of the Vedic doctrine of false effects.

original: tad evaṃ matadvaye 'pi dehavināśahetukaḥ śoko nāstīti siddham ////
analyzed: tat evam mata dvaye pi deha vināśa hetukaḥ śokaḥ na asti iti siddham
translated: Thus, it is established that in both views, there is no grief caused by the destruction of the body.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: āścaryavat paśyati kaścid enam
analyzed: āścarya vat paśyati kaścid enam
translated: Some see him as wonderful,

original: āścaryavad vadati tathaiva cānyaḥ /
analyzed: āścarya vat vadati tathā eva ca anyaḥ
translated: Another speaks of it as wonderful, and so does another.

original: āścaryavac cainam anyaḥ śṛṇoti
analyzed: āścaryavat ca enam anyaḥ śṛṇoti
translated: Another hears of it as wonderful.

original: śrutvāpy enaṃ veda na caiva kaścit ////
analyzed: śrutvā api enam veda na ca eva kaścid
translated: But having heard it, no one knows it at all.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kutas tarhi vidvāṃso 'pi loke śocanti /
analyzed: śrīdharaḥ kutas tarhi vidvāṃsaḥ api loke śocanti
translated: Shridhar: But then why do even the wise in the world grieve?

original: ātmājñānād eva ity āśayenātmano durvijñeyatvam āha āścaryavad ityādi /
analyzed: ātma ajñānāt eva iti āśayena ātmanaḥ durvijñeya tvam āha āścarya vat ityādi
translated: With the idea that it is only due to ignorance of the Self, he says that the Self is difficult to know, beginning with wonderful.

original: kaścid enam ātmānaṃ śāstrācāryopadeśābhyāṃ paśyann āścaryavat paśyati /
analyzed: kaścid enam ātmānam śāstra ācārya upadeśābhyām paśyan āścarya vat paśyati
translated: Someone sees this Self through the teachings of scriptures and a teacher, and sees it as wonderful.

original: sarvagatasya nityajñānānadasvabhāvasyātmanaḥ alaukikatvād aindrajālikavad ghaṭamānaṃ paśyann iva vismayena paśyati asambhāvanābhibhūtatvāt
analyzed: sarvagatasya nitya jñāna anada svabhāvasya ātmanaḥ alaukika tvāt aindrajālika vat ghaṭamānam paśyan iva vismayena paśyati asambhāvanā abhibhūta tvāt
translated: Seeing the Self, which is all-pervading, of the nature of eternal knowledge and bliss, as being like a magician's trick, as if it were being accomplished, he sees it with wonder, because he is overwhelmed by disbelief.

original: tathā āścaryavad anyo vadati ca /
analyzed: tathā āścarya vat anyaḥ vadati ca
translated: So does another speak of it as wonderful, and so does another.

original: śṛṇoti cānyaḥ /
analyzed: śṛṇoti ca anyaḥ
translated: Another hears of it as wonderful.

original: kaścit punaḥ viparītabhāvanābhibhūtaḥ śrutvāpi naiva veda /
analyzed: kaścid punar viparīta bhāvanā abhibhūtaḥ śrutvā api na eva veda
translated: But someone, overwhelmed by contrary thoughts, does not know it at all, even having heard it.

original: caśabdād uktvāpi na dṛṣṭvāpi na samyag vedeti draṣṭavyam ////
analyzed: caśabdāt uktvā api na dṛṣṭvā api na samyak veda iti draṣṭavyam
translated: The word ca (and) should be seen as meaning having spoken and having seen also, he does not know it properly.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: nanu vidvāṃso 'pi bahavaḥ śocanti tat kiṃ mām eva punaḥ punar evam upālabhase /
analyzed: nanu vidvāṃsaḥ api bahavaḥ śocanti tat kim mām eva punar punar evam upālabhase
translated: But many wise people also grieve. Then why do you reproach me again and again in this way?

original: anyac ca vaktur eva hi taj jāḍyaṃ śrotā yatra na budhyate iti nyāyāt tvadvacanārthāpartipattiś
analyzed: anyat ca vaktuḥ eva hi tat jāḍyam śrotā yatra na budhyate iti nyāyāt tvad vacana artha apartipattiḥ
translated: And moreover, by the principle that that is the dullness of the speaker where the listener does not understand, the non-understanding of the meaning of your words🔽is also yours, just like others, due to the fault in your own mind. Thus, the intended meaning is that the two faults mentioned do not apply.

original: ca tavāpy anyeṣām iva svāśayadoṣād iti noktadoṣadvayam ity abhipretyātmano durvijñeyatām
analyzed: ca tava api anyeṣām iva sva āśaya doṣāt iti nā ukta doṣa dvayam iti abhipretya ātmanaḥ durvijñeya tām
translated: With this in mind, he says that the self is difficult to know,

original: āha āścaryavad iti /
analyzed: āha āścarya vat iti
translated: as a wonder.

original: enaṃ prakṛtaṃ dehinam āścaryeṇādbhutena tulyatayā vartamānam āvidyakanānāvidhaviruddhadharmavattayā
analyzed: enam prakṛtam dehinam āścaryeṇa adbhutena tulya tayā vartamānam āvidyaka nānāvidha viruddha dharmavat tayā
translated: This embodied one, the subject, is said to be like a wonder, like an extraordinary thing, due to having various contradictory properties that are superimposed.

original: satanm apy asantam iva svaprakāśacaitanyarūpam api jaḍam ivānandaghanam api duḥkhitam
analyzed: sa tanm api asantam iva sva prakāśa caitanya rūpam api jaḍam iva ānanda ghanam api duḥkhitam
translated: Although existent, it is as if non-existent; although having the nature of self-luminous consciousness, it is as if inert; although full of bliss, it is as if suffering;

original: iva nirvikāram api savikāram iva nityam anityam iva prakāśamānam apy aprakāśamānam
analyzed: iva nirvikāram api sa vikāram iva nityam anityam iva prakāśamānam api a prakāśamānam
translated: although changeless, it is as if changing; although eternal, it is as if non-eternal; although shining, it is as if not shining;

original: iva brahmābhinnam api tadbhinnam iva muktam api baddham ivādvitīyam api sadvitīyam
analyzed: iva brahma abhinnam api tat bhinnam iva muktam api baddham iva advitīyam api sa dvitīyam
translated: although non-different from Brahman, it is as if different from it; although liberated, it is as if bound; although without a second, it is as if having a second;

original: iva sambhāvitavicitrānekākārapratītiviṣayaṃ paśyati śāstrācāryopadeśābhyām āvidyakasarvadvaitaniṣedhena
analyzed: iva sambhāvita vicitra aneka ākāra pratīti viṣayam paśyati śāstra ācārya upadeśābhyām āvidyaka sarva dvaita niṣedhena
translated: although the object of various kinds of cognitions, it is seen as such by the teacher's instruction and the scriptures, by negating all superimposed duality.

original: paramātmasvarūpamātrākārāyāṃ vedāntamahāvākyajanyāyāṃ sarvasukṛtaphalabhūtāyām
analyzed: paramātma sva rūpa mātra ākārāyām vedānta mahāvākya janyāyām sarva sukṛta phala bhūtāyām
translated: In the modification of the internal organ, which is the result of the highest good, and which is produced by the great sentences of the Vedanta, and which has the form of the Supreme Self alone,

original: antaḥkaraṇavṛttau pratiphalitaṃ samādhiparipākena sākṣātkaroti kaścic chamadamādisādhanasampannacaramaśarīraḥ
analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa vṛttau pratiphalitam samādhi paripākena sākṣātkaroti kaścid śama dama ādi sādhana sampanna carama śarīraḥ
translated: some one, who is endowed with the means such as tranquility, self-control, etc., and who has the last body, realizes it by the perfection of concentration.

original: kaścid eva na tu sarvaḥ /
analyzed: kaścid eva na tu sarvaḥ
translated: But not everyone.

original: tathā kaścid enaṃ yat paśyati tad āścaryavad iti kriyāviśeṣaṇam
analyzed: tathā kaścid enam yat paśyati tat āścaryavat iti kriyāviśeṣaṇam
translated: Similarly, he who sees this is indeed wonderful is an adverb modifying the verb.

original: ātmadarśanam apy āścaryavad eva yat svarūpato mithyābhūtam api satyasya vyañjakam āvidyakam apy avidyāyā vighātakam avidyām upaghnat tatkāryatayā
analyzed: ātma darśanam api āścaryavat eva yat svarūpataḥ mithyā bhūtam api satyasya vyañjakam āvidyakam api avidyāyāḥ vighātakam avidyām upaghnat tad kārya tayā
translated: The vision of the Self is indeed wonderful. Although it is false in its own nature, it is the manifester of the real. Although it is due to ignorance, it destroys ignorance. By destroying ignorance,

original: svātmānam apy upahantīti /
analyzed: sva ātmānam api upahanti iti
translated: it destroys itself as well, which is its effect.

original: tathā yaḥ kaścid enaṃ paśyati sa āścaryavad iti kartṛviśeṣaṇam /
analyzed: tathā yaḥ kaścid enam paśyati saḥ āścaryavat iti kartṛ viśeṣaṇam
translated: Similarly, he who sees this is indeed wonderful is a qualification of the agent.

original: yato 'sau nivṛttāvidyātatkāryo 'pi prārabdhakarmaprābalyāt tadvān iva vyaharati
analyzed: yatas sau nivṛtta avidyā tad kāryaḥ pi prārabdha karma prābalyāt tadvān iva vyaharati
translated: Because he, although having turned away from ignorance and its effects, behaves as if he had them due to the strength of the previously performed actions.

original: sarvadā samādhiniṣṭho 'pi vyuttiṣṭhati vyutthito 'pi punaḥ samādhim anubhavatīti
analyzed: sarvadā samādhi niṣṭhaḥ u pi vyuttiṣṭhati vyutthitaḥ u pi punar samādhim anubhavati iti
translated: Even though always devoted to concentration, he rises from it. Even though risen, he again experiences concentration.

original: prārabdhakarmavaicitryād vicitracaritraḥ prāptaduṣprāpajñānatvāt sakalalokaspṛhaṇīyo
analyzed: prārabdha karma vaicitryāt vicitra caritraḥ prāpta duṣprāpa jñāna tvāt sakala loka spṛhaṇīyaḥ
translated: Due to the variety of past actions, his conduct is varied. Having attained knowledge that is difficult to attain, he is desirable to the entire world.

original: 'ta āścaryavad eva bhavati /
analyzed: te āścaryavat eva bhavati
translated: Therefore, he is indeed wondrous.

original: tad etat trayam apy āścaryam ātmā taj jñānaṃ tajjñātā ceti paramadurvijñeyam ātmānaṃ tvaṃ katham anāyāsena jānīyā ity abhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: tat etat trayam api āścaryam ātmā tat jñānam tad jñātā ca iti parama durvijñeyam ātmānam tvam katham anāyāsena jānīyāḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: This triad of wonders is the self, its knowledge, and its knower. The self is extremely difficult to know. How can you know it effortlessly? This is the intention.

original: īvam upadeṣṭur abhāvād apy ātmā durvijñeyaḥ /
analyzed: īvam upadeṣṭuḥ abhāvāt api ātmā durvijñeyaḥ
translated: Thus, even due to the absence of an instructor, the self is difficult to know.

original: yo hy ātmānaṃ jānāti sa eva tam anyasmai dhruvaṃ brūyāt /
analyzed: yaḥ hi ātmānam jānāti saḥ eva tam anyasmai dhruvam brūyāt
translated: For only he who knows the self would certainly tell it to another.

original: ajñasyopadeṣṭṛtvāsambhavāt /
analyzed: ajñasya upadeṣṭṛ tva asambhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible for an ignorant person to be an instructor.

original: jānaṃs tu samāhitacittaḥ prāyeṇa kathaṃ bravītu /
analyzed: jānan tu samāhita cittaḥ prāyeṇa katham bravītu
translated: But one who knows, with a concentrated mind, would generally speak.

original: vyutthitacitto 'pi pareṇa jñātum aśakyaḥ /
analyzed: vyutthita cittaḥ pi pareṇa jñātum aśakyaḥ
translated: Even with a distracted mind, he is incapable of being known by others.

original: yathā kathaṃcij jñāto 'pi lābhapūjākhyātyādiprayojanānapekṣatvāc ca bravīty eva /
analyzed: yathā kathaṃcid lābha pūjā khyāti ādi prayojana anapekṣa tvāt ca bravīti eva
translated: Even if known somehow, he speaks due to his independence from the motives of gain, honor, fame, etc.

original: kathaṃcit kāruṇyamātreṇa bruvaṃs tu parameśvaravad atyantadurlabha evety āha āścaryavad vadati tathaiva cānya iti /
analyzed: kathaṃcid kāruṇya mātreṇa bruvan tu parameśvara vat atyanta durlabhaḥ evā iti āha āścarya vat vadati tathā eva ca anyaḥ iti
translated: But one who speaks out of mere compassion somehow is extremely rare, like the Supreme Lord. Thus he says, He speaks as wondrously, and likewise another.

original: yathājānāti tathaiva vadati /
analyzed: yathā ājānāti tathā eva vadati
translated: He speaks exactly as he knows.

original: enam ity anukarṣaṇārthaś cakāraḥ /
analyzed: enam iti anukarṣaṇa arthaḥ cakāraḥ
translated: The word 'this' is used in the sense of 'that'.

original: sa cānyaḥ sarvājñajanavilakṣaṇaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca anyaḥ sarva ajña jana vilakṣaṇaḥ
translated: And that is different from all other people.

original: na tu yaḥ paśyati tato 'nya iti vyāghātāt /🔽atrāpi karmaṇi kriyāyāṃ kartari cāścaryavad iti yojyam /
analyzed: na tu yaḥ paśyati tatas nyaḥ iti vyāghātāt  atra api karmaṇi kriyāyām kartari ca āścarya vat iti yojyam
translated: But it is not that the seer is different from that, because of contradiction.🔽Here also, 'wonderful' should be connected with the action, the object, and the agent.

original: tatra karmaṇaḥ kartuś ca prāg āścaryavattvaṃ vyākhyātaṃ kriyāyās tu vyākhyāyate /
analyzed: tatra karmaṇaḥ kartuḥ ca prāk āścaryavat tvam vyākhyātam kriyāyāḥ tu vyākhyāyate
translated: There, the wonderfulness of the object and the agent has been explained before. But the wonderfulness of the action is being explained now.

original: sarvaśabdāvācyasya śuddhasyātmano yad vacanaṃ
analyzed: sarva śabda avācyasya śuddhasya ātmanaḥ yat vacanam
translated: The statement of the pure Self, which is inexpressible by all words,

original: tad āścaryavat /
analyzed: tat āścaryavat
translated: is wonderful.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ yato vāco nivartante aprāpya manasā saha iti /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ yatas vācaḥ nivartante a prāpya manasā saha iti
translated: And the scripture says: 'From which words turn back, unable to reach it, along with the mind.'🔽The teaching of the pure Self, which is inexpressible by any word, by a word with a special power,

original: kenāpi śabdenāvācyasya śuddhasyātmano viśiṣṭaśaktena padena jahadajahatsvārthalakṣaṇāyā
analyzed: kena api śabdena avācyasya śuddhasya ātmanaḥ viśiṣṭa śaktena padena jahat ajahat svārtha lakṣaṇāyāḥ
translated: overcoming the denotation of its own meaning,

original: kalpitasambandhena lakṣyatāvacchedakam antareṇaiva pratipādanaṃ tad api nirvikalpasākṣātkārarūpam
translated: without the defining characteristic of what is to be defined by a relation that is imagined, is also of the nature of non-conceptual direct perception,

original: atyāścaryam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: ati āścaryam iti arthaḥ
translated: which is extremely wonderful, is the meaning.

original: athavā vinā śaktiṃ vinā lakṣaṇāṃ vinā sambandhāntaraṃ suṣuptotthāpakavākyavat tattvam asyādivākyena yadātmatattvapratipādanaṃ tad āścaryavat
analyzed: athavā vinā śaktim vinā lakṣaṇām vinā sambandha antaram suṣupta utthāpaka vākya vat tattvam asya ādi vākyena yat ātma tattva pratipādanam tat āścaryavat
translated: Or else, without power, without indication, without another relation, like the sentence that awakens one from deep sleep, the teaching of the truth of the self by the sentence beginning with tat is wonderful.

original: śabdaśakter acintyatvāt /
analyzed: śabda śakteḥ a cintya tvāt
translated: Because the power of the word is inconceivable.

original: na ca vinā sambandhaṃ bodhanen 'tiprasaṅgaḥ lakṣaṇāpakṣe 'pi tulyatvāt /
analyzed: na ca vinā sambandham bodhanā id ti prasaṅgaḥ lakṣaṇā pakṣe pi tulya tvāt
translated: And there is no overextension in the case of awakening without a relation, because it is the same even in the case of indication.

original: śakyasambandhasyānekasādhāraṇatvāt /
analyzed: śakya sambandhasya aneka sādhāraṇa tvāt
translated: Because the relation with what is possible is common to many.

original: tātparyaviśeṣān niyama iti cet / na /
analyzed: tātparya viśeṣāt niyamaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the restriction is due to a particular purport, it is not so.

original: tasyāpi sarvān praty aviśeṣāt /
analyzed: tasya api sarvān prati aviśeṣāt
translated: Because that also is not distinguished for all.

original: kaścid eva tātparyaviśeṣam avadhārayati na sarva iti cet /
analyzed: kaścid eva tātparya viśeṣam avadhārayati na sarve iti ced
translated: If it is argued that only some determine a particular purport, not all,

original: hanta tarhi puruṣagata eva kaścid viśeṣo nirdoṣatvarūpo niyāmakaḥ /
analyzed: hanta tarhi puruṣa gataḥ eva kaścid viśeṣaḥ nirdoṣa tva rūpaḥ niyāmakaḥ
translated: then indeed, some distinction belonging to the person itself, in the form of being faultless, is the determiner.

original: na cāsmin pakṣe 'pi na daṇḍavāritaḥ /🔽tathā ca yādṛśasya śuddhāntaḥkaraṇasya tātparyānusandhānapuraḥsaraṃ lakṣaṇayā
analyzed: na ca asmin pakṣe na daṇḍa vāritaḥ  tathā ca yādṛśasya śuddha antaḥkaraṇasya tātparya anusandhāna puraḥsaram lakṣaṇayā
translated: And even in this view, the objection is not warded off by the stick.

original: vākyārthabodho bhavadbhir aṅgī kriyate tādṛśasyaiva kevalaḥ śabdaviśeṣo 'khaṇḍasākṣātkāraṃ
analyzed: vākya artha bodhaḥ bhavadbhiḥ kriyate tādṛśasya eva kevalaḥ
translated: And in this way, for one whose inner organ is pure, for whom the understanding of the meaning of the sentence by indication is accepted by you, preceded by the ascertainment of purport, for him alone, the mere particular word, without parts, directly produces the knowledge of Brahman.

original: vināpi sambandhena janayatīti kim anupapannam / etasmin
analyzed: vinā api sambandhena janayati iti kim anupapannam etasmin
translated: What is impossible in saying that it produces even without a relation?

original: pakṣe śabdavṛttyaviṣayatvād yato vāco nivartanta iti sutarām upapannam /
analyzed: pakṣe śabda vṛtti aviṣaya tvāt yatas vācaḥ nivartante iti sutarām upapannam
translated: In this view, because it is not the object of the operation of words, the statement from which words turn back is all the more reasonable.

original: ayaṃ ca bhagavadabhiprāyo vārtikakāraiḥ prapañcitaḥ 🔽durbalatvād avidyāyā ātmatvād bodharūpiṇaḥ /🔽śabdaśakter acitnyatvād vidmas taṃ mohahānataḥ //
analyzed: ayam ca bhagavat abhiprāyaḥ vārtikakāraiḥ prapañcitaḥ  durbala tvāt avidyāyāḥ ātma tvāt bodha rūpiṇaḥ  śabda śakteḥ acitnya tvāt vidmaḥ tam moha hānataḥ
translated: And this intention of the Blessed Lord has been elaborated by the authors of the Vārttika (Bhāmatī):🔽Because ignorance is weak, because of the nature of the Self, because of the non-existence of the power of words, we know Him from the destruction of delusion.

original: agṛhītvaiva sambandham abhidhānābhidheyayoḥ /
analyzed: a gṛhītvā eva sambandham abhidhāna abhidheyayoḥ
translated: Even without apprehending the relation between the word and its meaning,

original: hitvā nidrāṃ prabudhyante suṣupter bodhitāḥ paraiḥ //
analyzed: hitvā nidrām prabudhyante suṣupteḥ bodhitāḥ paraiḥ
translated: they give up sleep and awaken, being awakened from deep sleep by others.

original: jāgradvan na yataḥ śabdaṃ suṣupte vetti kaścana /
analyzed: jāgrat vat na yatas śabdam suṣupte vetti kaścana
translated: Because no one experiences sound in deep sleep as in the waking state,

original: dhvaste 'to jñānato 'jñāne brahmāsmīti bhavet phalam //
analyzed: dhvaste jñānataḥ jñāne brahma asmi iti bhavet phalam
translated: therefore, by the destruction of ignorance through knowledge, the result 'I am Brahman' would be.

original: avidyāghātinaḥ śabdādyāhaṃ brahmeti dhīr bhavet /
analyzed: avidyā ghātinaḥ śabdāt yā aham brahma iti dhīḥ bhavet
translated: The idea 'I am Brahman' would arise from the word etc. which destroys ignorance.

original: naśyaty avidyayā sārdhaṃ hatvā rogam ivauṣadham // Bṛhat /Vā / /
analyzed: naśyati avidyayā sārdham hatvā rogam iva auṣadham
translated: It perishes along with ignorance, like a medicine after destroying a disease.

original: ity ādinā granthena /
analyzed: iti ādinā granthena
translated: By this and other passages.

original: tad evaṃ vacanaviṣayasya vaktur vacanakriyāyāś cātyāścaryarūpatvād ātmano durvijñānatvam
analyzed: tat evam vacana viṣayasya vaktuḥ vacana kriyāyāḥ ca ati āścarya rūpa tvāt ātmanaḥ durvijñāna tvam
translated: Thus, because the speaker and the act of speaking are of a very wonderful nature, the Self is difficult to know,

original: uktvā śrotur durmilatvād api tad āha āścaryavac cainam anyaḥ śṛṇoti śrtuvā 'py enaṃ vedeti /
analyzed: uktvā śrotuḥ durmila tvāt api tat āha āścaryavat ca enam anyaḥ śṛṇoti pi enam veda iti
translated: Having said this, he says that it is difficult to find a listener, so he says, And another hears it as if it were a wonder, and even though he hears it, he knows it.

original: anyo draṣṭur vaktuśc a muktād vilakṣaṇo mumukṣur vaktāraṃ brahmavidaṃ vidhivad upasṛtyainaṃ🔽śṛṇoti śravaṇākhyavicāraviṣayī karoti vedāntavākyatātparyaniścayenāvadhārayatīti yāvat /
analyzed: anyaḥ draṣṭuḥ vaktuḥ c ā muktāt vilakṣaṇaḥ mumukṣuḥ vaktāram brahma vidam vidhivat upasṛtya enam  śṛṇoti śravaṇa ākhya vicāra viṣayī karoti vedānta vākya tātparya niścayena avadhārayati iti yāvat
translated: Another, who is different from the liberated seer and speaker, who is a seeker of liberation, having approached the speaker, the knower of Brahman, in the proper manner,🔽hears it, makes it the object of inquiry called hearing, and ascertains it by the certainty of the purport of the Vedanta statements.

original: śrutvā cainaṃ manananididhyāsanaparipākād vedāpi sākṣātkaroty api āścaryavat /
analyzed: śrutvā ca enam manana nididhyāsana paripākāt veda api sākṣātkaroti api āścarya vat
translated: And having heard it, he even knows it by direct experience through the ripening of reflection and meditation, as if it were a wonder.

original: tathā cāścaryavat paśyati kaścid enam iti vyākhyātam /
analyzed: tathā ca āścarya vat paśyati kaścid enam iti vyākhyātam
translated: And thus it is explained that someone sees it as if it were a wonder.

original: atrāpi kartur āścaryarūpatvam anekajanmānuṣṭhitasukṛtakṣālitamanomalatayātidurlabhatvāt /
analyzed: atra api kartuḥ āścarya rūpa tvam aneka janma anuṣṭhita sukṛta kṣālita manaḥ mala tayā ati durlabha tvāt
translated: Here also, the agent has the form of a wonder, because he is very difficult to find due to the purity of the mind washed by good deeds performed in many births.

original: tathā ca vakṣyati
analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyati
translated: And thus he will say:

original: manuṣyāṇāṃ sahasreṣu kaś cid yatati siddhaye /
analyzed: manuṣyāṇām sahasreṣu kaḥ cit yatati siddhaye
translated: Among thousands of men, perhaps one strives for perfection.

original: yatatām api siddhānāṃ kaś cin māṃ vetti tattvataḥ // Gītā / iti /🔽śravaṇāyāpi bahubhir yo na labhyaḥ
analyzed: yatatām api siddhānām kaḥ cit mām vetti tattvataḥ gītāḥ iti  śravaṇāya api bahubhiḥ yaḥ na labhyaḥ
translated: And even among those who have attained perfection, perhaps one knows Me truly. (Gita)🔽He who is not obtained even by many for hearing,

original: śṛṇvanto 'pi bahavo yaṃ na vidyuḥ /
analyzed: śṛṇvantaḥ pi bahavaḥ yam na vidyuḥ
translated: even though many hear him, they do not know him.

original: āścaryo vaktā kuśalo 'sya labdhā
analyzed: āścaryaḥ vaktā kuśalaḥ sya labdhā
translated: The speaker is wonderful, skilled, and has attained

original: āścaryo jñātā kuśalānuśiṣṭaḥ //
analyzed: āścaryaḥ jñātā kuśala anuśiṣṭaḥ
translated: The wonderful knower is well-instructed by the skilled one.

original: KaṭhU / / iti śruteś ca /
analyzed: kaṭhu iti śruteḥ ca
translated: Thus it is said in the scriptures.

original: evaṃ śravaṇaśrotavyayor āścaryatvaṃ prāgvad vyākhyeyam /
analyzed: evam śravaṇa śrotavyayoḥ āścarya tvam prāgvat vyākhyeyam
translated: Thus, the wonderfulness of hearing and what is to be heard should be explained as before.

original: nanu yaḥ śravaṇamananādikaṃ karoti sa ātmānaṃ vedeti kim āścaryam ata āha na caiva kaścid iti /
analyzed: nanu yaḥ śravaṇa manana ādikam karoti saḥ ātmānam veda iti kim āścaryam atas āha na ca eva kaścid iti
translated: But how is it wonderful that one who listens, reflects, etc. knows the self? To this he says: And yet no one at all knows this.

original: cakāraḥ kriyākarmapadayor anuṣaṅgārthaḥ /
analyzed: cakāraḥ kriyā karma padayoḥ anuṣaṅga arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) is for the purpose of connecting the words for action and object.

original: kaścid enaṃ naiva veda śravaṇādikaṃ kurvann api /
analyzed: kaścid enam nā eva veda śravaṇa ādikam kurvan api
translated: No one at all knows this, even while performing listening, etc.

original: tad akurvaṃs tu na vedeti kim u vaktavyam /
analyzed: tat akurvan tu na veda iti kim u vaktavyam
translated: But how much more so is it to be said that one who does not perform that does not know?

original: aihikam aprastutapratibandhe taddarśanāt Vs / / / iti nyāyāt /
analyzed: aihikam aprastuta pratibandhe tad darśanāt iti nyāyāt
translated: Because it is seen that when there is an obstruction to what is not being discussed, it exists in this world, according to the principle.

original: uktaṃ ca vārtikakāraiḥ
analyzed: uktam ca vārtika kāraiḥ
translated: And it is said by the authors of the Vartika:

original: kutas tajjñānam iti cet tad dhi bandhaparikṣayāt /
analyzed: kutas tad jñānam iti ced tat hi bandha parikṣayāt
translated: If it is asked from where comes that knowledge, it is because of the destruction of the bondage.

original: asāv api ca bhūtau vā bhāvī vā vartate 'thavā // Bṛh / Vā / Sa / iti /
analyzed: asau api ca bhūtau vā bhāvī vā vartate vā saḥ iti
translated: And that also exists in the past, in the future, or in the present.

original: śravaṇādi kurvatām api pratibandhaparikṣayād eva jñānaṃ jāyate /
analyzed: śravaṇa ādi kurvatām api pratibandha parikṣayāt eva jñānam jāyate
translated: Even for those who perform listening, etc., knowledge arises only from the destruction of the obstruction.

original: anyathā tu na /
analyzed: anyathā tu na
translated: Otherwise, it does not.

original: sa ca pratibandhaparikṣayaḥ kasyacid bhūta eva /
analyzed: sa ca pratibandha parikṣayaḥ kasyacid bhūtaḥ eva
translated: And that destruction of the obstruction is for some in the past itself.

original: yathā hiraṇyagarbhasya /
analyzed: yathā hiraṇyagarbhasya
translated: Like that of Hiraṇyagarbha.

original: kasyacid bhāvī /
analyzed: kasyacid bhāvī
translated: For someone it is in the future.

original: yathā vāsudevasya /
analyzed: yathā vāsudevasya
translated: Like that of Vāsudeva.

original: kasyacid vartate /
analyzed: kasyacid vartate
translated: For someone it is present.

original: yathā śvetaketoḥ /
analyzed: yathā śvetaketoḥ
translated: Like that of Śvetaketu.

original: tathā ca pratibandhakṣayasyātidurlabhatvāt /
analyzed: tathā ca pratibandha kṣayasya ati durlabha tvāt
translated: And because the destruction of the bondage is very difficult to attain,

original: jñānam utpadyate puṃsāṃ kṣayāt pāpasya karmaṇaḥ iti smṛteś ca durvijñeyo 'yam ātmeti nirgalito 'rthaḥ /
analyzed: jñānam utpadyate puṃsām kṣayāt pāpasya karmaṇaḥ iti smṛteḥ ca durvijñeyaḥ yam ātmā iti nirgalitaḥ rthaḥ
translated: and because of the Smṛti text: Knowledge arises in the minds of men by the destruction of sinful actions, the meaning that emerges is that this Self is difficult to know.

original: yadi tu śrutvāpy enaṃ veda na caiva kaścid ity eva vyākhyāyeta tadā āścaryo jñātā kuśalānuśiṣṭaḥ KaṭhU / / iti śrutyaikavākyatā na syāt
analyzed: yadi tu śrutvā api enam veda na ca eva kaścid iti eva vyākhyāyeta tadā āścaryaḥ jñātā kuśala anuśiṣṭaḥ kaṭhu iti śrutyā ekavākyatā na syāt
translated: But if it were explained as even though hearing this, no one knows it at all, then it would not be in agreement with the Vedic text: The knower is wonderful, well-instructed, indeed.

original: yatatām api siddhānāṃ kaś cin māṃ vetti tattvataḥ Gītā / iti bhagavadvacanavirodhaś ceti vidvadbhir avinayaḥ kṣantavyaḥ /
analyzed: yatatām api siddhānām kaḥ cit mām vetti tattvataḥ gītāḥ iti bhagavat vacana virodhaḥ ca iti vidvadbhiḥ avinayaḥ kṣantavyaḥ
translated: And there would be a contradiction with the words of the Lord in the Gītā: Even among the perfected ones who strive, no one knows Me truly. So the learned should forgive the lack of decorum.

original: athavā na caiva kaścid ity asya sarvatra sambandhaḥ kaścid enaṃ na paśyati na vadati
analyzed: athavā na ca eva kaścid iti asya sarvatra sambandhaḥ kaścid enam na paśyati na vadati
translated: Or else, the word at all is to be connected everywhere with no one: No one sees it at all, no one speaks of it at all,🔽no one hears it at all, even though hearing it no one knows it at all. Five types are mentioned: Someone sees it but does not speak of it, someone🔽 Translation: Like that of Hiraṇyagarbha.🔽For someone it is in the future.🔽Like that of Vāsudeva.

original: na śṛṇoti śrutvāpi na vedeti pañca prakārā uktāḥ kaścit paśyaty eva na vadati kaścit
analyzed: na śṛṇoti śrutvā api na veda iti pañca prakārāḥ uktāḥ kaścid paśyati eva na vadati kaścid
translated: For someone it is present.🔽Like that of Śvetaketu.🔽And because the destruction of the bondage is very difficult to attain,🔽and because of the Smṛti text: Knowledge arises in the minds of men by the destruction of sinful actions, the meaning that emerges is that this Self is difficult to know.🔽But if it were explained as even though hearing this, no one knows it at all, then it would not be in agreement with the Vedic text: The knower is wonderful, well-instructed, indeed.🔽And there would be a contradiction with the words of the Lord in the Gītā: Even among the perfected ones who strive, no one knows Me truly. So the learned should forgive the lack of decorum.🔽Or else, the word at all is to be connected everywhere with no one: No one sees it at all, no one speaks of it at all,🔽no one hears it at all, even though hearing it no one knows it at all. Five types are mentioned: Someone sees it but does

original: paśyati na vadati ca kaścit tadvacanaṃ śṛṇoti ca tadarthaṃ jānāti ca kaścic chrutvāpi
analyzed: paśyati na vadati ca kaścid tad vacanam śṛṇoti ca tad artham jānāti ca kaścid śrutvā api
translated: Someone sees it, but no one speaks of it. Someone hears that speech and knows its meaning, but having heard it,

original: na jānāti na kaścit tu sarvabahirbhūta iti /
analyzed: na jānāti na kaścid tu sarva bahis bhūtaḥ iti
translated: no one knows it. No one is completely outside.

original: avidvatpakṣe tu asambhāvanāviparītabhāvanābhibhūtatvād āścaryatulyatvaṃ darśanavadanaśravaṇeṣv iti nigadavyākhyātaḥ ślokaḥ /
analyzed: avidvat pakṣe tu asambhāvanā viparīta bhāvanā abhibhūta tvāt āścarya tulya tvam darśana vadana śravaṇeṣu iti nigada vyākhyātaḥ ślokaḥ
translated: But in the case of the ignorant, because they are overwhelmed by disbelief and distorted meditation, seeing, speaking, and hearing are like a wonder. The verse is explained by the word-commentary.

original: caturthapāde tu dṛṣṭvoktvā śrutvāpīti yojanā ////
analyzed: caturtha pāde tu dṛṣṭvā uktvā śrutvā api iti yojanā
translated: But in the fourth quarter, the construction is having seen, spoken, and heard.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: nanu kim idam āścaryaṃ brūṣe /
analyzed: nanu kim idam āścaryam brūṣe
translated: But what is this wonder that you speak of?

original: kiṃ caitad apy āścaryam /
analyzed: kim ca etat api āścaryam
translated: And is this also a wonder?

original: yad eva prabodhyamānasyāpy aviveko nāpayātīti tatra satyam evem eva ity āha āścaryavad iti /
analyzed: yat eva prabodhyamānasya api avivekaḥ na apayāti iti tatra satyam eva īm eva iti āha āścaryavat iti
translated: That even when being awakened, non-discrimination does not depart. There, it is indeed so, he says like a wonder.

original: enam ātmānaṃ dehaṃ ca tadubhayarūpaṃ sarvalokam ////
analyzed: enam ātmānam deham ca tad ubhaya rūpam sarva lokam
translated: This Self and the body, both of which are the entire world.

original: baladevaḥ / nanu sarvajñena tvayā bahūpadiśyamāno 'py ahaṃ śokanivārakam ātmayāthātmyaṃ na budhye kim etad iti cet tatrāha āścaryavad iti
analyzed: baladevaḥ nanu sarvajñena tvayā aham śoka nivārakam ātma yāthātmyam na budhye kim etat iti ced tatra āha āścarya vat iti
translated: Baladeva. But if you say, Although taught by you, the omniscient one, I do not understand the true nature of the Self, which removes sorrow. What is this? There, he says like a wonder.

original: vijñānāndobhayasvarūpatve 'pi tadbhedāpratiyoginaṃ vijñānasvarūpatve 'pi vijñātṛtayā
analyzed: vijñāna anda ubhaya sva rūpa tve pi tad bheda a pratiyoginam vijñāna sva rūpa tve pi vijñātṛ tayā
translated: Although it has the nature of both consciousness and bliss, it is not subject to the distinction of those two. Although it has the nature of consciousness, it exists as the knower.

original: santaṃ paramāṇutve 'pi vyāptabṛhatkāyaṃ nānākāyasambandhe 'pi tattadvikārair
analyzed: santam paramāṇu tve vyāpta bṛhat kāyam nānā kāya sambandhe pi tad tad vikāraiḥ
translated: Although atomic, it has a body that pervades and is large. Although connected with various bodies, it is untouched by their modifications.

original: aspṛṣṭam evam ādi bahuviruddhadharmatayāścaryavad adbhutasādṛśyena sthitam enaṃ
analyzed: a spṛṣṭam evam ādi bahu viruddha dharma tayā āścarya vat adbhuta sādṛśyena sthitam enam
translated: It exists with many such contradictory attributes, like something wonderful and marvelous.

original: madupadiṣṭaṃ jīvaṃ kaścid eva svadharmānuṣṭhānena satyatapojapādinā ca vimṛṣṭahṛdguruprasādalabdhatādṛśajñānaḥ
analyzed: mad upadiṣṭam jīvam kaścid eva svadharma anuṣṭhānena satya tapaḥ japa ādinā ca vimṛṣṭa hṛd guru prasāda labdha tādṛśa jñānaḥ
translated: Only someone who has examined the self through the practice of his own duties, truth, austerity, muttering of prayers, etc., and has obtained such knowledge through the grace of a guru in the heart,

original: paśyati yāthātmyenānubhavati /
analyzed: paśyati yāthātmyena anubhavati
translated: sees this self as taught by me, and experiences its true nature.
