original: madhusūdanaḥ /🔽nanu kiṃ karmānuṣṭhānam eva puruṣārtho yena niṣphalam eva sadā kartavyam ity ucyate prayojanam anuddiśya na mando 'pi pravartate iti nyāyāt
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ  nanu kim karma anuṣṭhānam eva puruṣa arthaḥ yena niṣphalam eva sadā kartavyam iti ucyate prayojanam an uddiśya na pravartate iti nyāyāt
translated: Madhusudana.🔽But is the performance of action itself the human goal, by which it is said that it should always be performed without results, because of the principle that even a fool does not engage without a stated purpose?

original: tad varaṃ phalakāmanayaiva karmānuṣṭhānam iti cen nety āha dūreṇeti /
analyzed: tat varam phala kāmanayā eva karma anuṣṭhānam iti ced na iti āha dūreṇa iti
translated: If it is argued that it is better to perform action with a desire for results, the answer is no, as stated by far away.

original: buddhiyogād ātmabuddhisādhanabhūtān niṣkāmakarmayogād dūreṇātiviprakarṣeṇāvaram adhamaṃ karma phalābhisandhinā kriyamāṇaṃ janmamaraṇahetubhūtam
analyzed: buddhi yogāt ātma buddhi sādhana bhūtāt niṣkāma karma yogāt dūreṇa ati viprakarṣeṇa avaram adhamam karma phala abhisandhinā kriyamāṇam janma maraṇa hetu bhūtam
translated: Karma performed with a desire for results is inferior, the worst, because it is very far away, i.e. very much removed, from the yoga of wisdom, which is the means of attaining the knowledge of the Self. It is the cause of birth and death.

original: athavā paramātmabuddhiyogād dūreṇāvaraṃ sarvam api karma yasmād /
analyzed: athavā paramātma buddhi yogāt dūreṇa avaram sarvam api karma yasmāt
translated: Or, all karma is inferior because it is very far away from the yoga of wisdom about the supreme Self.

original: he dhanañjaya /
analyzed: he dhanañjaya
translated: O Dhananjaya.

original: tasmād buddhau paramātmabuddhau sarvānarthanivartikāyāṃ śaraṇaṃ pratibandhakapāpakṣayeṇa rakṣakaṃ niṣkāmakarmayogam anviccha kartum iccha
analyzed: tasmāt buddhau paramātma buddhau sarva anartha nivartikāyām śaraṇam pratibandhaka pāpa kṣayeṇa rakṣakam niṣkāma karmayogam anviccha kartum iccha
translated: Therefore, seek, i.e. desire to perform, the yoga of action without desire for results, which is the protector, the remover of obstacles by destroying the sins that obstruct the supreme wisdom about the Self, which is the refuge.

original: ye tu phalahetavaḥ phalakāmā avaraṃ karma kurvanti te kṛpaṇāḥ sarvadā janmamaraṇādighaṭīyantrabhramaṇena paravaśā atyantadīnā
analyzed: ye tu phala hetavaḥ phala kāmāḥ avaram karma kurvanti te kṛpaṇāḥ sarvadā janma maraṇa ādi ghaṭīyantra bhramaṇena paravaśā atyanta dīnā
translated: But those who perform inferior karma, desiring results and their causes, are miserable, always under the control of the revolving machine of birth, death, etc., and extremely pitiable.

original: ity arthaḥ / yo vā etad akṣaram gārgy aviditvā asmāl lokāt praiti sa kṛpaṇa BAU / / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: iti arthaḥ yaḥ vai etat akṣaram gārgi a viditvā asmāt lokāt praiti sa iti śruteḥ
translated: This is the meaning. As it is said in the Shruti: He who departs from this world without knowing this syllable, O Gargi, is miserable.

original: tathā ca tvam api kṛpaṇo mā bhūḥ kintu sarvānarthanivartakātmajñānotpādakaṃ niṣkāmakarmayogam evānutiṣṭhety abhiprāyaḥ /🔽yathā hi kṛpaṇā janā atiduḥkhena dhanam arjayanto yat kiṃcid dṛṣṭasukhamātralobhena
analyzed: tathā ca tvam api kṛpaṇaḥ mā bhūḥ kintu sarva anartha nivartaka ātma jñāna utpādakam niṣkāma karmayogam eva anutiṣṭha iti abhiprāyaḥ  yathā hi kṛpaṇāḥ janāḥ ati duḥkhena dhanam arjayantaḥ yat kiṃcid dṛṣṭa sukha mātra lobhena
translated: And so you also should not be miserly. Rather, you should perform only the Karma-yoga of action without desire, which produces the knowledge of the Self that removes all miseries. This is the purport.

original: dānādijanitaṃ mahat sukham anubhavituṃ na śaknuvantīty ātmānam eva vañcayanti tathā
analyzed: dāna ādi janitam mahat sukham anubhavitum na śaknuvanti iti ātmānam eva vañcayanti tathā
translated: For just as miserly people, earning wealth with great difficulty, are unable to experience the great happiness produced by charity etc. out of greed for mere visible pleasure, and thus deceive themselves,

original: mahatā duḥkhena karmāṇi kurvāṇāḥ kṣudraphalamātralobhena paramānandānubhavena
analyzed: mahatā duḥkhena karmāṇi kurvāṇāḥ kṣudra phala mātra lobhena parama ānanda anubhavena
translated: so those who perform actions with great difficulty, out of greed for mere trifling results,

original: vañcitā ity aho daurbhāgyaṃ mauḍhyaṃ ca teṣām iti kṛpaṇapadena dhvanitam // //
analyzed: vañcitāḥ iti aho daurbhāgyam mauḍhyam ca teṣām iti kṛpaṇa padena dhvanitam
translated: are deceived by the experience of supreme bliss. Oh, what misfortune and foolishness theirs is! This is conveyed by the word 'miserly'.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /🔽sakāmakarma nindati dūreṇeti /
analyzed: sa kāma karma nindati dūreṇa iti
translated: Visvanatha:🔽He censures action with desire by 'dūreṇa', etc.

original: avaram atinikṛṣṭaṃ kāmyaṃ karma /
analyzed: avaram atinikṛṣṭam kāmyam karma
translated: Inferior means extremely low, desirable action.

original: buddhiyogāt parameśvarārpitaniṣāmakarmayogāt /
analyzed: buddhi yogāt parameśvara arpita niṣāma karma yogāt
translated: From the yoga of the intellect, from the Karma-yoga of offering actions to the Supreme Lord.

original: buddhau niṣkāmakarmaṇy eva buddhiyogo niṣkāmakarmayogaḥ ////
analyzed: buddhau niṣkāma karmaṇi eva buddhi yogaḥ niṣkāma karma yogaḥ
translated: The yoga of the intellect is the Karma-yoga of action without desire, in the intellect, in action without desire.

original: baladevaḥ / atha kāmyakarmaṇo nikṛṣṭatvam āha dūreṇeti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ atha kāmya karmaṇaḥ nikṛṣṭa tvam āha dūreṇa iti
translated: Baladeva: Now he says the inferiority of desirable action by 'dūreṇa', etc.

original: buddhiyogād avaraṃ karma dūreṇa /
analyzed: buddhi yogāt avaram karma dūreṇa
translated: Action is far inferior to the Yoga of Wisdom.

original: he dhanañjaya /🔽ātmayāthātmyabuddhisādhanabhūtān niṣkāmakarmayogāt dūreṇātiviprakarṣeṇāvaram atyapakṛṣṭaṃ janmamaraṇādyanarthanimittaṃ kāmyaṃ karmety
analyzed: he dhanañjaya  ātma yāthātmya buddhi sādhana bhūtāt niṣkāma karmayogāt dūreṇa ati viprakarṣeṇa avaram ati apakṛṣṭam janma maraṇa ādi anartha nimittam kāmyam karma iti
translated: O Dhananjaya!🔽The meaning is that action done with desire for results, which is the cause of undesirable things like birth, death, etc., is far, i.e. very far, inferior, extremely low,

original: arthaḥ /
analyzed: arthaḥ
translated: than the Yoga of Action without desire for results, which is the means to the knowledge of the true nature of the Self.

original: hi yasmād evam atas tvaṃ buddhau tadyāthātmyajñāne śaraṇam āśrayaṃ niṣkāmakarmayogam anviccha kuru /
analyzed: hi yasmāt evam atas tvam buddhau tad yāthātmya jñāne śaraṇam āśrayam niṣkāma karmayogam anviccha kuru
translated: Therefore, you seek, undertake, refuge in the knowledge of that true nature, i.e. in the Yoga of Action without desire for results.

original: ye tu phalahetavaḥ phalakāmā avarakarmakāriṇas te kṛpaṇās tatphalajanmakarmādipravāhaparavaśā dīnā ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: ye tu phala hetavaḥ phala kāmāḥ avara karma kāriṇaḥ te kṛpaṇāḥ tad phala janma karma ādi pravāha paravaśāḥ dīnāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: But those who are the causes of results, who desire results and perform inferior actions, they are miserable, pitiable, being under the control of the stream of actions and results like birth, etc.

original: tathā ca tvaṃ kṛpaṇo mābhūr iti iha kṛpaṇāḥ khalu kaṣṭopārjitavittādṛṣṭasukhalavalubdhā
analyzed: tathā ca tvam kṛpaṇaḥ mā abhūḥ iti iha kṛpaṇāḥ khalu kaṣṭa upārjita vitta adṛṣṭa sukha lava lubdhā
translated: And thus, you should not be miserable. Indeed, in this world, the miserable ones are those who are greedy for the mere taste of happiness seen in wealth earned with difficulty,

original: vittāni dātum asamarthā mahatā dānasukhena vañcitās tathā kaṣṭānuṣṭhitakarmāṇas
analyzed: vittāni dātum asamarthāḥ mahatā dāna sukhena vañcitāḥ tathā kaṣṭa anuṣṭhita karmāṇaḥ
translated: who are unable to give away their wealth and are deceived by the great happiness of giving, and similarly, those who perform actions with difficulty,

original: tucchatatphalalubdhā mahatātmasukhena vañcitā bhavantīti vyajyate ////
analyzed: tuccha tad phala lubdhāḥ mahatā ātma sukhena vañcitāḥ bhavanti iti vyajyate
translated: are greedy for the trifling results of those actions and are deceived by the great happiness of the Self. This is what is implied.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: (Bhagavad Gita)

original: buddhiyukto jahātīha ubhe sukṛtaduṣkṛte /
analyzed: buddhi yuktaḥ jahāti iha ubhe sukṛta duṣkṛte
translated: One who is united with wisdom abandons here both good and bad deeds.

original: tasmād yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśalam ////
analyzed: tasmāt yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśalam
translated: Therefore, apply yourself to Yoga. Yoga is skill in action.

original: śrīdharaḥ / buddhiyogayuktas tu śreṣṭha ity āha buddhiyukta iti /
analyzed: tu   iti āha   iti
translated: Śrīdhara: But one who is endowed with the Yoga of the intellect is the best. Thus it is said: One endowed with the intellect.

original: sukṛtaṃ svargādiprāpakaṃ duṣkṛtaṃ nirayādiprāpakam /
analyzed: sukṛtam svarga ādi prāpakam duṣkṛtam niraya ādi prāpakam
translated: Good deeds lead to heaven, bad deeds to hell.

original: te ubhe ihaiva janmani parameśvaraprasādena tyajati /
analyzed: te ubhe iha eva janmani parameśvara prasādena tyajati
translated: He abandons both of them in this very life by the grace of the Supreme Lord.

original: tasmād yogāya tadarthāya karmayogāya yujyasva ghaṭasva /
analyzed: tasmāt yogāya tad arthāya karma yogāya yujyasva ghaṭasva
translated: Therefore, apply yourself to Yoga, for that purpose, to the Yoga of action.

original: yogo hi karmasu kauśalam /
analyzed: yogaḥ hi karmasu kauśalam
translated: For Yoga is skill in action.

original: svadharmākhyeṣu karmasu vartamānasya yā siddhyasiddhyoḥ samatvabuddhir īśvarārpitacetastayā tat kauśalaṃ kuśalabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: svadharma ākhyeṣu karmasu vartamānasya yā siddhi asiddhyoḥ samatva buddhiḥ īśvara arpita cetaḥ tayā tat kauśalam kuśala bhāvaḥ
translated: For one who is engaged in actions called one's own duty, the understanding of equality in success and failure, by having one's mind dedicated to God, is skill, the state of being skillful.

original: tad dhi kauśalaṃ yad bandhasvabhāvāny api karmāṇi samatvabuddhyā svabhāvān nivartante /
analyzed: tat hi kauśalam yat bandha svabhāvāni api karmāṇi samatva buddhyā svabhāvāt nivartante
translated: For that is skill by which even actions that are of the nature of bondage, by the understanding of equality, turn away from their nature.

original: tasmāt samatvabuddhiyukto bhava tvam ////
analyzed: tasmāt sama tva buddhi yuktaḥ bhava tvam
translated: Therefore, you be endowed with the understanding of equality.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: evaṃ buddhiyogābhāve doṣam uktvā tadbhāve guṇam āha buddhīti /
analyzed: evam buddhi yoga abhāve doṣam uktvā tad bhāve guṇam āha buddhi iti
translated: Having thus stated the fault in the absence of the Yoga of the intellect, he states the virtue in its presence with the words buddhi-yuktaḥ (endowed with the intellect).

original: iha karmasu buddhiyuktaḥ samatvabuddhyā yukto jahāti parityajati ubhe sukṛtaduṣkṛte puṇyapāpe sattvaśuddhijñānaprāptidvāreṇa /
analyzed: iha karmasu buddhi yuktaḥ samatva buddhyā yuktaḥ jahāti parityajati ubhe sukṛta duṣkṛte puṇya pāpe sattva śuddhi jñāna prāpti dvāreṇa
translated: Here, one who is endowed with the knowledge of equality, who is endowed with the knowledge of equality, abandons, gives up, both good and bad deeds, both meritorious and sinful, through the attainment of purity of mind and knowledge.

original: yasmād evaṃ tasmāt samatvabuddhiyogāya tvaṃ yujyasva ghaṭasvodyukto bhava /🔽yasmād īdṛśaḥ samatvabuddhiyoga īśvarārpitacetasaḥ karmasu pravartamānasya kauśalaṃ
analyzed: yasmāt evam tasmāt samatva buddhi yogāya tvam yujyasva ghaṭasva udyuktaḥ bhava  yasmāt īdṛśaḥ samatva buddhi yogaḥ īśvara arpita cetasaḥ karmasu pravartamānasya kauśalam
translated: Since it is so, therefore, you should apply yourself, strive, be diligent, for the yoga of the knowledge of equality.🔽Since such is the skill,

original: kuśalabhāvo yadbandhahetūnām api karmaṇāṃ tadabhāvo mokṣaparyavasāyitvaṃ ca
analyzed: kuśala bhāvaḥ yat bandha hetūnām api karmaṇām tad abhāvaḥ mokṣa paryavasāyi tvam ca
translated: the state of being skillful, of one who is engaged in actions with his mind dedicated to God, even of actions that are causes of bondage, and since it leads to liberation,

original: tan mahat kauśalam /
analyzed: tat mahat kauśalam
translated: that is a great skill.

original: samatvabuddhiyuktaḥ karmayogaḥ karmātmāpi san duṣṭakarmakṣayaṃ karotīti mahākuśalaḥ /
analyzed: samatva buddhi yuktaḥ karmayogaḥ karma ātmā api san duṣṭa karma kṣayam karoti iti mahā kuśalaḥ
translated: The yoga of action endowed with the knowledge of equality, even though it has the nature of action, destroys bad actions. Thus it is greatly skillful.

original: tvaṃ tu na kuśalo yataś cetano 'pi san sajātīyaduṣṭakṣayaṃ na karoṣīti vyatireko 'tra dhvanitaḥ /
analyzed: tvam tu na kuśalaḥ yatas san sajātīya duṣṭa kṣayam na karoṣi iti vyatirekaḥ dhvanitaḥ
translated: But you are not skillful, because even though you are conscious, you do not destroy the bad of the same kind. The contrast is implied here.

original: athavā iha samatvabuddhiyukte karmaṇi kṛte sati sattvaśuddhidvāreṇa buddhiyuktaḥ paramātmasākṣātkāravān sañjahāty ubhe sukṛtaduṣkṛte
analyzed: athavā iha samatva buddhi yukte karmaṇi kṛte sati sattva śuddhi dvāreṇa buddhi yuktaḥ paramātma sākṣātkāravān sañjahāti ubhe sukṛta duṣkṛte
translated: Or, here, when an action is performed that is endowed with the knowledge of equality, then one who is endowed with knowledge through the purification of the mind, who possesses the direct realization of the supreme Self, abandons both good and bad deeds,

original: tasmāt samatvabuddhiyuktāya karmayogāya yujyasva /
analyzed: tasmāt sama tva buddhi yuktāya karma yogāya yujyasva
translated: Therefore, be engaged in Karma-yoga, which is endowed with the attitude of equality.

original: yasmāt karmasu madhye samatvabuddhiyuktaḥ karmayogaḥ kauśalaṃ kuśalo duṣṭakarmanivāraṇacatura ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: yasmāt karmasu madhye samatva buddhi yuktaḥ karma yogaḥ kauśalam kuśalaḥ duṣṭa karma nivāraṇa caturaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Because, among actions, Karma-yoga, which is endowed with the attitude of equality, is the skill, the expertness, the cleverness in preventing bad actions.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: yogāyoktalakṣaṇāya yujyasva ghaṭasva /
analyzed: yogāya ukta lakṣaṇāya yujyasva ghaṭasva
translated: Be engaged in Yoga, which has the characteristics mentioned above.

original: yataḥ karmasu sakāmaniṣkāmeṣu madhye yoga evodāsīnatvena karmakaraṇam eva /
analyzed: yatas karmasu sa kāma niṣkāmeṣu madhye yogaḥ eva udāsīna tvena karma karaṇam eva
translated: Because, among actions with desire for fruits and without desire for fruits, Yoga alone is the skill, the cleverness, the expertness in performing actions with equanimity.

original: kauśalaṃ naipuṇyam ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: kauśalam naipuṇyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is the cleverness in preventing bad actions.

original: baladevaḥ / uktasya buddhiyogasya prabhāvam āha buddhīti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ uktasya buddhi yogasya prabhāvam āha buddhi iti
translated: Balarama: The Lord says that the power of the mentioned Buddhi-yoga is as follows:

original: iha karmasu yo buddhiyuktaḥ pradhānaphalatyāgaviṣayānuṣaṅgaphalasiddhyasiddhisamatvaviṣayayā ca buddhyā yuktas tāni karoti /
analyzed: iha karmasu yaḥ buddhi yuktaḥ pradhāna phala tyāga viṣaya anuṣaṅga phala siddhi asiddhi samatva viṣayayā ca buddhyā yuktaḥ tāni karoti
translated: Here, one who is endowed with Buddhi-yoga, who performs those actions with a mind that is endowed with the attitude of renouncing the principal fruits, and with the attitude of the equality of the attainment and non-attainment of the incidental fruits,

original: sa ubhe anādikālasañcite jñānapratibandhake sukṛtaduṣkṛte jahāti vināśayatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ ubhe anādi kāla sañcite jñāna pratibandhake sukṛta duṣkṛte jahāti vināśayati iti arthaḥ
translated: he abandons, destroys, both good and bad deeds accumulated since beginningless time, which are obstacles to knowledge. This is the meaning.

original: tasmād uktāya buddhiyogāya yujyasva ghaṭasva /
analyzed: tasmāt uktāya buddhi yogāya yujyasva ghaṭasva
translated: Therefore, be engaged in the mentioned Buddhi-yoga.

original: yasmāt karmayogas tādṛśabuddhisambandhaḥ /
translated: Because Karma-yoga is the connection with such a mind.

original: kauśalam cāturyaṃ bandhakānām eva buddhisamparkād viśodhitaviṣapāradanyāyena mocakatvena pariṇāmāt ////
analyzed: kauśalam cāturyam bandhakānām eva buddhi samparkāt viśodhita viṣa pārada nyāyena mocaka tvena pariṇāmāt
translated: And skill is the ability of the binders themselves, which, by the principle of mercury purified by contact with the intellect of the wise, is transformed into the state of being a liberator.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: (Bhagavad Gita 4.14)

original: karmajaṃ buddhiyuktā hi phalaṃ tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ /
analyzed: karma jam buddhi yuktāḥ hi phalam tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ
translated: For the wise, indeed, who are endowed with knowledge, by renouncing the fruit born of action,

original: janmabandhavinirmuktāḥ padaṃ gacchanty anāmayam ////
analyzed: janma bandha vinirmuktāḥ padam gacchanti anāmayam
translated: they attain the state free from sorrow, being liberated from the bondage of birth.🔽(Bhagavad Gita 4.15)

original: śrīdharaḥ / karmaṇāṃ mokṣasādhanatvaprakāram āha karmajam iti /
translated: Sridhar: He says the way in which actions are the means to liberation is born of action.

original: karmajaṃ phalaṃ tyaktvā kevalam īśvarārādhanārthaṃ karma kurvāṇo manīṣiṇo jñānino
analyzed: karma jam phalam tyaktvā kevalam īśvara ārādhana artham karma kurvāṇaḥ manīṣiṇaḥ jñāninaḥ
translated: The wise, the knowers, performing actions only for the worship of God by renouncing the fruit born of action,

original: bhūtvā janmarūpeṇa bandhena vinirmuktāḥ santo 'nāmayaṃ sarvopadravarahitaṃ viṣṇoḥ🔽padaṃ mokṣākhyaṃ gacchanti // //
analyzed: bhūtvā janma rūpeṇa bandhena vinirmuktāḥ santaḥ na āmayam sarva upadrava rahitam viṣṇoḥ  padam mokṣa ākhyam gacchanti
translated: being liberated from the bondage in the form of birth, go to the state of Vishnu, called liberation, which is free from all calamities and🔽free from sorrow.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: nanu duṣkṛtahānam apekṣitaṃ na tu sukṛtahānaṃ puruṣārthabhraṃśāpatter ity āśaṅkya tucchaphalatyāgena paramapuruṣārthaprāptiṃ phalam
analyzed: nanu duṣkṛta hānam apekṣitam na tu sukṛta hānam puruṣa artha bhraṃśa āpatteḥ iti āśaṅkya tuccha phala tyāgena parama puruṣa artha prāptim phalam
translated: Now, if it is argued that the destruction of bad actions is required, not the destruction of good actions, because it would lead to the loss of the human goal, then, by giving up the insignificant fruit, the attainment of the highest human goal is

original: āha karmajam iti /
analyzed: āha karma jam iti
translated: said to be the fruit by born of action.

original: samatvabuddhiyuktā hi yasmāt karmajaṃ phalaṃ tyaktvā kevalam īśvarārādhanārthaṃ
analyzed: samatva buddhi yuktāḥ hi yasmāt karma jam phalam tyaktvā kevalam īśvara ārādhana artham
translated: For, those who are endowed with the knowledge of equality, having renounced the fruit born of action,

original: karmāṇi kurvāṇāḥ sattvaśuddhidvāreṇa manīṣiṇas tat tvam asi ity ādivākyajanyātmamanīṣāvanto bhavanti /
analyzed: karmāṇi kurvāṇāḥ sattva śuddhi dvāreṇa manīṣiṇaḥ tat tvam asi iti ādi vākya janya ātma manīṣāvantaḥ bhavanti
translated: performing actions solely for the worship of God, the wise ones, through the purification of the mind, become endowed with the knowledge of the Self produced by statements like That thou art.

original: tādṛśāś ca santo janmātmakena bandhena vinirmuktā viśeṣeṇātyantikatvalakṣaṇena niravaśeṣaṃ🔽muktāḥ padaṃ padanīyam ātmatattvam ānandarūpaṃ brahmānāmayam avidyātatkāryātmakarogarahitābhayaṃ
analyzed: tādṛśāḥ ca santaḥ janma ātmakena bandhena vinirmuktāḥ viśeṣeṇa ātyantika tva lakṣaṇena niravaśeṣam  muktāḥ padam padanīyam ātma tattvam ānanda rūpam brahma anāmayam avidyā tad kārya ātmaka roga rahita abhayam
translated: And those who are such, being freed from bondage consisting of birth, are completely liberated, in particular, by the characteristic of eternality,🔽they attain, without distinction, the state called liberation, which is the highest human goal, the truth of the Self, which is of the nature of bliss, Brahman, free from disease, free from ignorance and its effects, free from all evils,

original: mokṣākhyaṃ puruṣārthaṃ gacchanty abhedena prāpnuvantīty arthaḥ /🔽yasmād evaṃ phalakāmanāṃ tyaktvā samatvabuddhyā karmāṇy anutiṣṭhantas taiḥ kṛtāntaḥkaraṇaśuddhayas
analyzed: mokṣa ākhyam puruṣa artham gacchanti abhedena prāpnuvanti iti arthaḥ  yasmāt evam phala kāmanām tyaktvā samatva buddhyā karmāṇi anutiṣṭhantaḥ taiḥ kṛta antaḥkaraṇa śuddhayaḥ
translated: the meaning is that they reach it.🔽Since it is so, those who perform actions with the knowledge of equality, having renounced the desire for results, by those (actions) the internal organ is purified,

original: tat tvam asy ādipramāṇotpannātmatattvajñānatatkāryāḥ santaḥ sakalānarthanivṛttiparamānandaprāptirūpaṃ
analyzed: tat tvam asi ādi pramāṇa utpanna ātma tattva jñāna tad kāryāḥ santaḥ sakala anartha nivṛtti paramānanda prāpti rūpam
translated: they become endowed with the knowledge of the truth of the Self and its effects produced by the means of knowledge beginning with That thou art, and being so, they attain the highest bliss in the form of the cessation of all evils,

original: mokṣākhyaṃ viṣṇoḥ paramaṃ padaṃ gacchanti tasmāt tvam api yac chreyaḥ syān niścitaṃ🔽brūhi tan me Gītā / ity ukteḥ śreyo jijñāsur evaṃvidhaṃ karmayogam anutiṣṭheti
analyzed: mokṣa ākhyam viṣṇoḥ paramam padam gacchanti tasmāt tvam api yat śreyaḥ syāt niścitam  brūhi tat me gītāḥ iti ukteḥ śreyaḥ jijñāsuḥ evaṃvidham karmayogam anutiṣṭha iti
translated: Therefore, you too, whatever is certainly good,

original: bhagavato 'bhiprāyaḥ // //
analyzed: bhagavataḥ bhiprāyaḥ
translated: speak that to me, O Gītā. Thus spoken, the Blessed Lord's intention is that one who desires to know the good should perform such Karma-yoga.

original: viśvanāthaḥ / Nothing /
analyzed: viśvanāthaḥ nothing
translated: Viśvanātha: Nothing.

original: baladevaḥ / karmajam iti /🔽buddhiyuktās tādṛśabuddhimantaḥ karmajaṃ phalaṃ tyaktvā karmāṇy anutiṣṭhanto manīṣiṇaḥ
analyzed: baladevaḥ karma jam iti  buddhi yuktāḥ tādṛśa buddhimantaḥ karma jam phalam tyaktvā karmāṇi anutiṣṭhantaḥ manīṣiṇaḥ
translated: Balarāma: The word 'karmajam' (arising from action).🔽Those endowed with such knowledge, the wise ones, renouncing the fruits arising from action, by performing actions,

original: karmāntargatātmayāthātmyaprajñāvanto bhūtvā janmabandhena vinirmuktāḥ santo 'nāmayaṃ
analyzed: karma antargata ātma yāthātmya prajñāvantaḥ bhūtvā janma bandhena vinirmuktāḥ santaḥ na āmayam
translated: becoming endowed with the wisdom of the true nature of the Self within action, being liberated from the bondage of birth, go to the state of Vaikuṇṭha,

original: kleśaśūnyaṃ padaṃ vaikuṇṭhaṃ gacchantīti /
analyzed: kleśa śūnyam padam vaikuṇṭham gacchanti iti
translated: which is free from distress and devoid of afflictions.

original: tasmāt tvam api śreyo jijñāsur evaṃ vidhāni karmāṇi kurv iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt tvam api śreyaḥ jijñāsuḥ evaṃvidhāni karmāṇi kuru iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, you too, desiring to know the good, perform such actions - this is the meaning.

original: svātmajñānasya paramātmajñānahetutvāt tasyāpi tatpadagatihetutvaṃ yuktam ////
analyzed: svātma jñānasya paramātma jñāna hetu tvāt tasya api tad pada gati hetu tvam yuktam
translated: Since the knowledge of one's own Self is the cause of the knowledge of the Supreme Self, it is proper that that [knowledge of one's own Self] also is the cause of going to that state.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG 2.70

original: yadā te mohakalilaṃ buddhir vyatitariṣyati /
analyzed: yadā te moha kalilam buddhiḥ vyatitariṣyati
translated: When your mind will transcend the mire of delusion,

original: tadā gantāsi nirvedaṃ śrotavyasya śrutasya ca ////
analyzed: tadā gantāsi nirvedam śrotavyasya śrutasya ca
translated: then you will attain detachment from what is to be heard and what has been heard.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kadāhaṃ tat padaṃ prāpsyāmi ity apekṣāyām āha yadeti dvābhyām /
translated: Sridhara: In anticipation of the question When shall I attain that state?, he says by the next two verses.

original: moho dehādiṣu ātmabuddhiḥ /
analyzed: mohaḥ deha ādiṣu ātma buddhiḥ
translated: Moha is the notion of the self in the body etc.

original: tad eva kalilaṃ gahanam /
analyzed: tat eva kalilam gahanam
translated: That itself is the kalila, the dense.

original: kalilaṃ gahanaṃ vidur ity abhidhānakoṣasmṛteḥ /
analyzed: kalilam gahanam viduḥ iti abhidhānakoṣa smṛteḥ
translated: Kalila is known as dense - according to the Smriti of the lexicon.

original: tataś cāyam arthaḥ /🔽evaṃ parameśvarārādhane kriyamāṇe yadā tatprasādena tava buddhir dehābhimānalakṣaṇaṃ
analyzed: tatas ca ayam arthaḥ  evam parameśvara ārādhane kriyamāṇe yadā tad prasādena tava buddhiḥ deha abhimāna lakṣaṇam
translated: And the meaning is this.

original: mohamayaṃ gahanaṃ durgaṃ viśeṣeṇātitariṣyati tadā śrotavyasya śrutasya cārthasya
analyzed: moha mayam gahanam durgam viśeṣeṇa atitariṣyati tadā śrotavyasya śrutasya ca arthasya
translated: When, in this way, the worship of the Supreme Lord is being done, then, by your grace, when your intellect will especially cross over the dense, difficult, delusion consisting of the notion of the self in the body etc.,

original: nirvedaṃ vairāgyaṃ gantāsi prāpsyasi /
analyzed: nirvedam vairāgyam gantāsi prāpsyasi
translated: then you will attain the state of indifference, detachment, to what is to be heard and what is heard.

original: tayor anupādeyatvena jijñāsām na kariṣyasīty arthaḥ ////
analyzed: tayoḥ anupādeya tvena jijñāsām na kariṣyasi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that you will not seek to know them, considering them unworthy of attention.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: evaṃ karmāṇy anutiṣṭhataḥ kadā me sattvaśuddhiḥ syād ity ata āha yadeti /
analyzed: evam karmāṇi anutiṣṭhataḥ kadā me sattva śuddhiḥ syāt iti atas āha yadā iti
translated: Thus, for one who is performing actions, when will there be purification of the mind? To this he says yada etc.

original: na hy etāvatā kālena sattvaśuddhir bhavatīti kālaniyamo 'sti /
analyzed: na hi etāvatā kālena sattva śuddhiḥ bhavati iti kāla niyamaḥ asti
translated: For there is no restriction on time that purification of the mind does not occur in this much time.

original: kintu yadā yasmin kāle te tava buddhir antaḥkaraṇaṃ mohakalilaṃ vyatitariṣyati avivekātmakaṃ
analyzed: kintu yadā yasmin kāle te tava buddhiḥ antaḥkaraṇam moha kalilam vyatitariṣyati aviveka ātmakam
translated: But when, at what time, your intellect, the internal organ, will cross over the delusion consisting of non-discrimination,

original: kāluṣam aham idaṃ mamedaṃ ity ādyajñānavilasitam atigahanam vyatikramiṣyati rajastamomalam
analyzed: kāluṣam aham idam mama idam iti ādi ajñāna vilasitam ati gahanam vyatikramiṣyati rajaḥ tamaḥ malam
translated: The very thick impurity of passion and darkness, which is the manifestation of the ignorance beginning with 'this is mine' and 'this belongs to me', will be overcome.

original: apahāya śuddhabhāvam āpatsyata iti yāvat /
analyzed: apahāya śuddha bhāvam āpatsyate iti yāvat
translated: The meaning is: you will attain a pure state, having abandoned that.

original: tadā tasmin kāle śrotavyasya śrutasya ca karmaphalasya nirvedaṃ vaitṛṣṇyaṃ gantāsi prāptāsi /
analyzed: tadā tasmin kāle śrotavyasya śrutasya ca karma phalasya nirvedam vaitṛṣṇyam gantāsi prāptāsi
translated: Then, at that time, you will attain detachment, non-attachment, towards the fruits of actions that are to be heard and that have been heard.

original: parīkṣya lokān karmacitān brāhmaṇo nirvedam āyāt MuṇḍU / / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: parīkṣya lokān karma citān brāhmaṇaḥ nirvedam āyāt muṇḍu iti śruteḥ
translated: As stated in the Shruti: Having examined the worlds created by action, the Brahmin attains detachment, shaves his head...

original: nirvedena phalenāntaḥkaraṇaśuddhiṃ jñāsyasīty abhiprāyaḥ ////
analyzed: nirvedena phalena antaḥkaraṇa śuddhim jñāsyasi iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The idea is: by means of the fruit of detachment, you will know the purification of the internal organ.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: evaṃ parameśvarārpitaniṣkāmakarmābhyāsāt tava yogo bhaviṣyatīty āha yadeti /
analyzed: evam parameśvara arpita niṣkāma karma abhyāsāt tava yogaḥ bhaviṣyati iti āha yadā iti
translated: Thus, your yoga will come about through the practice of selfless actions dedicated to the Supreme Lord. He says this with the word 'yadetat'.

original: tava buddhir antaḥkaraṇaṃ mohakalilaṃ moharūpaṃ gahanaṃ viśeṣato 'tiśayena tariṣyati /
analyzed: tava buddhiḥ antaḥkaraṇam moha kalilam moha rūpam gahanam viśeṣataḥ atiśayena tariṣyati
translated: Your intellect, the internal organ, will cross over the very thick delusion, which is in the form of delusion.

original: tadā śrotavyasya śrotavyeṣv artheṣu śrutasya śruteṣv apy artheṣu nirvedaṃ prāpsyasi asambhāvanāviparītabhāvanayor naṣṭatvāt kiṃ me śāstropadeśavākyaśravaṇena
analyzed: tadā śrotavyasya śrotavyeṣu artheṣu śrutasya śruteṣu api artheṣu nirvedam prāpsyasi asambhāvanā viparīta bhāvanayoḥ naṣṭa tvāt kim me śāstra upadeśa vākya śravaṇena
translated: Then, you will attain detachment towards the objects that are to be heard and the objects that have been heard, because the disbelief and wrong conception have been destroyed. What is the use of listening to the words of instruction from the scriptures?

original: sāmprataṃ me sādhaneṣv eva pratikṣaṇam abhyāsaḥ sarvathocita iti maṃsyasa iti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: sāmpratam me sādhaneṣu eva pratikṣaṇam abhyāsaḥ sarvathā ucitaḥ iti maṃsyase iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that you will think that it is proper for me to practice constantly in the means right now in every way.

original: baladevaḥ / nanu niṣkāmāṇi karmāṇi kurvato me kadātmaviṣayā manīṣābhyudiyād iti cet tatrāha yadeti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ nanu niṣkāmāṇi karmāṇi kurvataḥ me kadā ātma viṣayā manīṣā abhyudiyāt iti ced tatra āha yadā iti
translated: Balarama. But if you think, When will my mind turn to the Self, while I am performing actions without desire for results? then the Lord says yada etc.

original: yadā te buddhir antaḥkaraṇaṃ mohakalilaṃ tucchaphalābhilāṣahetum ajñānagahanaṃ vyatitariṣyati parityakṣyatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: yadā te buddhiḥ antaḥkaraṇam moha kalilam tuccha phala abhilāṣa hetum ajñāna gahanam vyatitariṣyati parityakṣyati iti arthaḥ
translated: When your intellect, the internal organ, will cross over, i.e. abandon, the dense ignorance which is the cause of the desire for insignificant results, which is full of delusion.

original: tadā pūrvaṃ śrutasyānantaraṃ śrotavyasya ca tasya tucchaphalasya sambandhinaṃ nirvedaṃ gantāsi gamiṣyasi /
analyzed: tadā pūrvam śrutasya anantaram śrotavyasya ca tasya tuccha phalasya sambandhinam nirvedam gantāsi gamiṣyasi
translated: Then you will attain, i.e. go to, the detachment from that insignificant result which was heard before and which is to be heard later.

original: parīkṣya lokān karmacitān brāhmaṇo nirvedaṃ āyāt iti śravaṇāt /
analyzed: parīkṣya lokān karma citān brāhmaṇaḥ nirvedam āyāt iti śravaṇāt
translated: Because it is heard that the brahmin, having examined the worlds created by action, attained detachment.

original: nirvedena phalena tadviṣayāṃ tāṃ pariceṣyati iti nāsty atra kālaniyama ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: nirvedena phalena tad viṣayām tām pariceṣyati iti na asti atra kāla niyamaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: By means of the result, detachment, he abandons the mind that is attached to that result. The meaning is that there is no restriction of time here.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: śrutivipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niścalā /
analyzed: śruti vipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niścalā
translated: When your mind, opposed by the scriptures, will stand firm,

original: samādhāv acalā buddhis tadā yogam avāpsyasyi ////
analyzed: samādhau acalā buddhiḥ tadā yogam avāpsyasyi
translated: then you will attain yoga, O Arjuna, when your intellect becomes steady in unwavering concentration.

original: śrīdharaḥ / tataś ca śrutīti /
translated: Sridhar. And then, when your mind etc.

original: śrutibhir nānālaukikavaidikārthaśravaṇair vipratipannā /
analyzed: śrutibhiḥ nānā laukika vaidika artha śravaṇaiḥ vipratipannā
translated: Contradictory due to the hearing of various non-worldly Vedic meanings.

original: itaḥ pūrvaṃ vikṣiptā satī tava buddhir yadā samādhau sthāsyati /
analyzed: itas pūrvam vikṣiptā satī tava buddhiḥ yadā samādhau sthāsyati
translated: And your mind, which was previously distracted, will stand firm in concentration.

original: samādhīyate cittam asminn iti samādhiḥ parameśvaraḥ /🔽tasmin niścalā viṣayair antarair anākṛṣṭā /
analyzed: samādhīyate cittam asmin iti samādhiḥ parameśvaraḥ  tasmin niścalā viṣayaiḥ antaraiḥ an ākṛṣṭā
translated: Concentration is the Supreme Lord, in whom the mind is concentrated.🔽In Him, unmoved, not attracted by other objects,

original: ataevācalā /
analyzed: ataeva acalā
translated: and therefore unshakable,

original: abhyāsapāṭavena tatraiva sthirā ca satī yogaṃ yogaphalaṃ tattvajñānam avāpsyasi ////
analyzed: abhyāsa pāṭavena tatra eva sthirā ca satī yogam yoga phalam tattva jñānam avāpsyasi
translated: and firm in Him alone by the perfection of practice, you will attain Yoga, the fruit of Yoga, the knowledge of reality.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: antaḥkaraṇaśuddhyaivaṃ jātanirvedasya kadā jñānaprāptir ity apekṣāyām āha śrutīti /
analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa śuddhyā evam jāta nirvedasya kadā jñāna prāptiḥ iti apekṣāyām āha śruti iti
translated: When the question arises as to when one who has thus purified the internal organ and become detached will attain knowledge, it is said: by the scriptures.

original: te tava buddhiḥ śrutibhir nānāvidhaphalaśravaṇair avicāritatātparyair vipratipannā 'nekavidhasaṃśayaviparyāsavattvena vikṣiptā prāk
analyzed: te tava buddhiḥ śrutibhiḥ nānāvidha phala śravaṇaiḥ avicārita tātparyaiḥ vipratipannā nekavidha saṃśaya viparyāsavat tvena vikṣiptā prāk
translated: Your mind, previously distracted by the scriptures, which are of various results, and whose purport is not considered, is opposed, having many kinds of doubts and misconceptions.

original: yadā yasmin kāle śuddhijavivekajanitena doṣadarśanena taṃ vikṣepaṃ parityajya
analyzed: yadā yasmin kāle śuddhi ja viveka janitena doṣa darśanena tam vikṣepam parityajya
translated: When, at what time, by the vision of faults produced by the knowledge of purification, abandoning that distraction,

original: samādhau parmātmani niścalā jāgratsvapnadarśanalakṣaṇavikṣeparahitācalā suṣuptimūrcchāstabdhībhāvādirūpalayalakṣaṇacalanarahitā
analyzed: samādhau parma ātmani niścalā jāgrat svapna darśana lakṣaṇa vikṣepa rahitā acalā suṣupti mūrcchā stabdhībhāva ādi rūpa laya lakṣaṇa calana rahitā
translated: Being steady, free from the distraction characterized by the perception of waking and dreaming, and free from the fluctuation characterized by the state of deep sleep, fainting, and dullness,

original: satī sthāsyati layavikṣepalakṣaṇau doṣau parityajya samāhitā bhaviṣyatīti yāvat /
analyzed: satī sthāsyati laya vikṣepa lakṣaṇau doṣau parityajya samāhitā bhaviṣyati iti yāvat
translated: it will remain, abandoning the faults characterized by fluctuation and distraction. It will become concentrated, this is the meaning.

original: athavā niścalāsambhāvanāviparītabhāvanārahitācalā dīrghakālādaranairantaryasatkārasevanair vijātīyapratyayādūṣitā satī nirvātapradīpavad
analyzed: athavā niścalā a sambhāvanā viparīta bhāvanā rahitā acalā dīrgha kāla ādara nairantarya satkāra sevanaiḥ vijātīya pratyaya a dūṣitā satī nirvāta pradīpa vat
translated: Or else, being free from the impossibility of steadiness and from the contrary conception, being steady, and being untainted by heterogeneous ideas through the service of long time, respect, and continuity, like a lamp in a windless place,

original: ātmani sthāsyatīti yojanā /
analyzed: ātmani sthāsyati iti yojanā
translated: it will remain in the Self. This is the construction of the sentence.

original: tadā tasmin kāle yogaṃ jīvaparamātmaikyalakṣaṇaṃ
analyzed: tadā tasmin kāle yogam jīva paramātma aikya lakṣaṇam
translated: Then, at that time, you will attain the yoga, which is characterized by the identity of the individual Self and the Supreme Self,

original: tattvamasīty ādivākyajanyam akhaṇḍasākṣātkāraṃ sarvayogaphalam avāpsyasi /
analyzed: tat tvam asi iti ādi vākya janyam akhaṇḍa sākṣātkāram sarva yoga phalam avāpsyasi
translated: which is the result of all yoga, the undivided direct knowledge produced by the statements beginning with That thou art,

original: tadā punaḥ sādhyāntarābhāvāt kṛtakṛtyaḥ sthitaprajño bhaviṣyasīty abhiprāyaḥ ////
analyzed: tadā punar sādhya antara abhāvāt kṛtakṛtyaḥ sthita prajñaḥ bhaviṣyasi iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: and then, because there is no other goal to be accomplished, you will become one whose wisdom is firm, one who has done what was to be done. This is the intention.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: tataś ca śrutiṣu nānālaukikavaidikārthaśravaṇeṣu vipratipannā asammatā viraketit yāvat /
analyzed: tatas ca śrutiṣu nānā laukika vaidika artha śravaṇeṣu vipratipannāḥ a sammatāḥ yāvat
translated: And then, in the scriptures, in the hearing of various extraordinary Vedic meanings, they are opposed, not agreed upon, as long as they are not desired.

original: tatra hetuḥ niścalā teṣu teṣv artheṣu calituṃ vimukhībhūtety arthaḥ /
analyzed: tatra hetuḥ niścalā teṣu teṣu artheṣu calitum vimukhībhūtā iti arthaḥ
translated: The reason for that is: steady, i.e. averse to moving about in those objects.

original: kintu samādhau ṣaṣṭhe 'dhyāye vakṣyamāṇalakṣaṇe 'calā sthairyavatī /
analyzed: kintu samādhau ṣaṣṭhe dhyāye vakṣyamāṇa lakṣaṇe calā sthairyavatī
translated: But in the sixth chapter, it will be said that in the concentration having the characteristics to be described, it is steady, i.e. firm.

original: tadā yogam aparokṣānubhavaprāptyā /
analyzed: tadā yogam a parokṣa anubhava prāptyā
translated: Then, by attaining yoga, i.e. by attaining the direct experience of the Self.

original: jīvanmukta ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: jīvanmuktaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: he is liberated while living.

original: baladevaḥ / nanu karmaphalanirviṇṇatayā karmānuṣṭhānena labdhahṛdviśuddher abhyuditātmajñānasya me kadātmasākṣātkṛtir iti cet tatrāha
analyzed: baladevaḥ nanu karma phala nirviṇṇa tayā karma anuṣṭhānena labdha hṛd viśuddheḥ abhyudita ātma jñānasya me kadā ātma sākṣātkṛtiḥ iti ced tatra āha
translated: Balarama. Now, if it is asked by you who are disgusted with the fruits of action, who have attained purity of heart by performing actions, and whose knowledge of the Self has arisen, When will I have the direct experience of the Self?, then he says

original: śrutīti /
analyzed: śruti iti
translated: by the scriptures.

original: śrutyā karmaṇāṃ jñānagarbhatāṃ prabodhayantyā tam etam ity ādikayā vipratipannā
analyzed: śrutyā karmaṇām jñāna garbha tām prabodhayantyā tam etam iti ādikayā vipratipannā
translated: By the scriptures which awaken the fact that actions are pregnant with knowledge, by the passage beginning with That art Thou, those who are opposed

original: viśeṣeṇa saṃsiddhā te buddhir acalā asambhāvanāviparītabhāvanābhyāṃ virahitā yadā
analyzed: viśeṣeṇa saṃsiddhā te buddhiḥ acalā asambhāvanā viparīta bhāvanābhyām virahitā yadā
translated: are especially well-established. Your intellect, which is free from disbelief and wrong conception, when

original: samādhau manasi nirvātadīpaśikheva niścalā sthāsyati tadā yogam ātmānubhavalakṣaṇam avāpsyasi /
analyzed: samādhau manasi nirvāta dīpa śikhā iva niścalā sthāsyati tadā yogam ātma anubhava lakṣaṇam avāpsyasi
translated: will stand still in concentration, like the flame of a lamp in a windless place, then you will attain yoga, which is characterized by the experience of the Self.

original: ayam arthaḥ phalābhilāṣaśūnyatayānuṣṭhitāni karmāṇi sthitaprajñatārūpāṃ jñānaniṣṭhāṃ sādhayanti /
analyzed: ayam arthaḥ phala abhilāṣa śūnya tayā anuṣṭhitāni karmāṇi sthitaprajña tā rūpām jñāna niṣṭhām sādhayanti
translated: The meaning is: actions performed without a desire for results accomplish the stage of knowledge in the form of the stage of one whose mind is steady.

original: jñānaniṣṭhārūpā sthitaprajñatā tv ātmānubhavam iti ////
analyzed: jñāna niṣṭhā rūpā sthita prajña tā tu ātma anubhavam iti
translated: And the state of being a man of steady wisdom, which is of the nature of the attainment of knowledge, is the experience of the Self.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: (Bhagavadgita 6.8)

original: arjuna uvāca🔽sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya keśava /
analyzed: arjunaḥ uvāca  sthita prajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhi sthasya keśava
translated: Arjuna said:🔽What is the speech of one who is a man of steady wisdom, O Keshava, who is in the state of samadhi?

original: sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kim āsīta vrajeta kim ////
analyzed: sthita dhīḥ kim prabhāṣeta kim āsīta vrajeta kim
translated: What does one of steady mind speak, what does he sit, what does he move about?

original: śrīdharaḥ / pūrvaślokoktasyātmatattvajñasya lakṣaṇaṃ jijñāsur arjuna uvāca sthitaprajñasyeti /
analyzed: uvāca
translated: Sridhar: Desiring to know the characteristics of one who knows the truth of the Self as stated in the previous verse, Arjuna said, What is the speech of one who is a man of steady wisdom?

original: svābhāvike samādhau sthitasya /
analyzed: svābhāvike samādhau sthitasya
translated: One who is established in natural samadhi.

original: ataeva sthitā niścalā prajñā buddhir yasya tasya bhāṣā kā /🔽bhāṣyate 'nayā iti bhāṣā lakṣaṇam iti yāvat /
analyzed: ataeva sthitā niścalā prajñā buddhiḥ yasya tasya bhāṣā kā  bhāṣyate nayā iti bhāṣā lakṣaṇam iti yāvat
translated: And therefore, what is the speech of one whose wisdom, whose intellect, is steady and unwavering?

original: sa kena lakṣaṇena sthitaprajña ucyate ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: sa kena lakṣaṇena sthita prajñaḥ ucyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Speech means that by which one speaks. The meaning is, by what characteristics is one called a man of steady wisdom?

original: tathā sthitadhīḥ kiṃ kathaṃ bhāṣaṇam āsanaṃ vrajanaṃ ca kuryād ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: tathā sthita dhīḥ kim katham bhāṣaṇam āsanam vrajanam ca kuryāt iti arthaḥ
translated: And what does one of steady mind do, how does he speak, sit, and move about?

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: evam labdhāvasaraḥ sthitaprajñalakṣaṇaṃ jñātum arjuna uvāca /
analyzed: evam labdha avasaraḥ sthita prajña lakṣaṇam jñātum arjunaḥ uvāca
translated: Having obtained this opportunity, Arjuna said, desiring to know the characteristics of a man of steady wisdom,

original: yāny eva hi jīvanmuktānāṃ lakṣaṇāni tāny eva mumukṣūṇāṃ mokṣopāyabhūtānīti manvānaḥ /
analyzed: yāni eva hi jīvanmuktānām lakṣaṇāni tāni eva mumukṣūṇām mokṣa upāya bhūtāni iti manvānaḥ
translated: thinking that the very same characteristics of the liberated while living are the means to liberation for the seekers of liberation.

original: sthitā niścalā ahaṃbrahmāsmi iti prajñā yasya sa sthitaprajño 'vasthādvayavān samādhistho vyutthitacittaś ceti /
analyzed: sthitā niścalā aham brahma asmi iti prajñā yasya sa sthita prajñaḥ vasthā dvayavān samādhi sthaḥ vyutthita cittaḥ ca iti
translated: One who is established in the wisdom that I am Brahman, the unborn, the imperishable, is a man of steady wisdom, who is in both states, being in samādhi and having a mind that has risen up.

original: ato viśinaṣṭi samādhisthasya sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā /
analyzed: atas viśinaṣṭi samādhi sthasya sthita prajñasya kā bhāṣā
translated: Therefore, he distinguishes: What is the speech of one who is in samādhi, the man of steady wisdom?

original: karmaṇi ṣaṣṭhī /
analyzed: karmaṇi ṣaṣṭhī
translated: The genitive case is in reference to the action.

original: bhāṣyate 'nayeti bhāṣā lakṣaṇam /
analyzed: bhāṣyate naya iti bhāṣā lakṣaṇam
translated: Speech is the characteristic by which one is spoken of.

original: samādhisthaḥ sthitaprajñaḥ kena lakṣaṇenānyair vyavahriyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: samādhi sthaḥ sthita prajñaḥ kena lakṣaṇena anyaiḥ vyavahriyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: By what characteristic is one who is in samādhi, the man of steady wisdom, spoken of by others?

original: sa ca vyutthitacittaḥ sthitadhīḥ sthitaprajñaḥ svayaṃ kiṃ prabhāṣeta /
analyzed: sa ca vyutthita cittaḥ sthita dhīḥ sthita prajñaḥ svayam kim prabhāṣeta
translated: And what would that one whose mind has risen up, whose intellect is steady, the man of steady wisdom, himself speak?

original: stutinindādāv abhinandanadveṣādilakṣaṇaṃ kiṃ kathaṃ prabhāṣeta /
analyzed: stuti nindā ādau abhinandana dveṣa ādi lakṣaṇam kim katham prabhāṣeta
translated: What kind of speech would he utter in praise, blame, etc., characterized by delight, hatred, etc.?

original: sarvatra sambhāvanāyāṃ liṅ /
analyzed: sarvatra sambhāvanāyām liṅ
translated: The suffix 'lin' is used in the sense of possibility in all cases.

original: tathā kim āsīteti vyutthitacittanigrahāya kathaṃ bahir indriyāṇāṃ nigrahaṃ karoti /
analyzed: tathā kim āsīta iti vyutthita citta nigrahāya katham bahis indriyāṇām nigraham karoti
translated: Similarly, how does he control the external senses while sitting, in order to control the mind that has risen up?

original: tannigrāhābhāvakāle kiṃ vrajeta kathaṃ viṣayān prāpnoti /
analyzed: tad nigrāha abhāva kāle kim vrajeta katham viṣayān prāpnoti
translated: How does he attain objects when he goes forth, at the time when there is no control over them?

original: tatkartṛkabhāṣaṇāsanavrajanāni mūḍhajanavilakṣaṇāni kīdṛśānīity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tad kartṛka bhāṣaṇa āsana vrajanāni mūḍha jana vilakṣaṇāni kīdṛśāni iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: What are the speaking, sitting, and going forth of him, which are different from those of a deluded person?

original: tad evaṃ catvāraḥ praśnāḥ samādhisthe sthitaprajña ekaḥ /
analyzed: tat evam catvāraḥ praśnāḥ samādhi sthe sthita prajñaḥ ekaḥ
translated: Thus, there are four questions for one who is established in samādhi, and one for one who is established in wisdom.

original: vyutthite sthitaprajñe traya iti /
analyzed: vyutthite sthita prajñe trayaḥ iti
translated: For one who is arisen from samādhi, there are three questions for one who is established in wisdom.

original: keśaveti sambodhayan sarvāntaryāmitayā tvam evaitādṛśaṃ rahasyaṃ vaktuṃ samartho 'sīti sūcayati ////
analyzed: keśava iti sambodhayan sarva antaryāmi tayā tvam eva etādṛśam rahasyam vaktum samarthaḥ si iti sūcayati
translated: Addressing you as Keśava, he indicates that you alone are capable of speaking such a secret by way of being the inner controller of all.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Viśvanātha.

original: samādhāv acalā buddhir iti śrutvā tattvato yogino lakṣaṇaṃ pṛcchati sthitaprajñasyeti /
analyzed: samādhau acalā buddhiḥ iti śrutvā tattvataḥ yoginaḥ lakṣaṇam pṛcchati sthita prajñasya iti
translated: Having heard that the mind of one in samādhi is steady, he asks about the true characteristics of a yogi: What is the definition of one whose mind is steady in samādhi?

original: sthitā sthirācalā prajña buddhir yasyeti /
analyzed: sthitā sthirā acalā prajña buddhiḥ yasya iti
translated: One whose wisdom, i.e., mind, is steady, unmoving.

original: kā bhāṣā / bhāṣyate 'nayeti bhāṣā lakṣaṇaṃ kiṃ lakṣaṇam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kā bhāṣā bhāṣyate naya iti bhāṣā lakṣaṇam kim lakṣaṇam iti arthaḥ
translated: What is the definition? The meaning is: what is the definition?

original: kīdṛśasya samādhisthasyeti samādhau sthāsyatīti /
analyzed: kīdṛśasya samādhi sthasya iti samādhau sthāsyati iti
translated: Of what kind is one who is in samādhi? The meaning is: of one who will be established in samādhi.

original: asyārthaḥ evaṃ ca sthitaprajña iti /
analyzed: asya arthaḥ evam ca sthita prajñaḥ iti
translated: The meaning is: and thus one who is established in wisdom.

original: samādhistha iti jīvanmuktasya saṃjñādvayam /
analyzed: samādhi sthaḥ iti jīvanmuktasya saṃjñā dvayam
translated: One who is in samādhi is the two names of one who is liberated while living.

original: kiṃ prabhāṣeteti sukhaduḥkhayor mānāpamānayoḥ stutinindayoḥ snehadveṣayor vā samupasthitayoḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta /
analyzed: kim prabhāṣeta iti sukha duḥkhayoḥ māna apamānayoḥ stuti nindayoḥ sneha dveṣayoḥ vā samupasthitayoḥ kim prabhāṣeta
translated: What does he speak? The meaning is: when pleasure and pain, honor and dishonor, praise and blame, affection and hatred are present, what does he speak?

original: spaṣṭaṃ svagataṃ vā kiṃ vaded ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: spaṣṭam svagatam vā kim vadet iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: what does he say to himself, clearly or not?

original: kim āsīta / tad indriyāṇāṃ bāhyaviṣayeṣu calanābhāvaḥ kīdṛśaḥ /
analyzed: kim āsīta tat indriyāṇām bāhya viṣayeṣu calana abhāvaḥ kīdṛśaḥ
translated: What does he sit? What is the absence of the movement of the senses towards external objects like?

original: vrajeta kim /
analyzed: vrajeta kim
translated: What does he go?

original: teṣu calanaṃ vā kīdṛśam iti ////
analyzed: teṣu calanam vā kīdṛśam iti
translated: Or what is the movement towards them like?

original: baladevaḥ / evam ukto 'rjunaḥ pūrvapadyoktasya sthitaprajñasya lakṣaṇaṃ jñātuṃ pṛcchati sthiteti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ evam uktaḥ rjunaḥ pūrva padya uktasya sthita prajñasya lakṣaṇam jñātum pṛcchati sthita iti
translated: Balarama: Thus addressed, Arjuna asks to know the characteristics of a man of steady wisdom mentioned in the previous verse, with the word sthita (steady).

original: sthitaprajñe 'tra catvāraḥ praśnāḥ samādhisthe ekaḥ /
analyzed: sthitaprajñe catvāraḥ praśnāḥ samādhi sthe ekaḥ
translated: There are four questions about a man of steady wisdom in meditation, and one in the state of distraction.

original: vyutthite tu trayaḥ /
analyzed: vyutthite tu trayaḥ
translated: But three in the state of distraction.

original: tathā hi sthitā sthirā prajña dhīr yasya tasya samādhisthasya kā bhāṣā kiṃ lakṣaṇam /
analyzed: tathā hi sthitā sthirā dhīḥ yasya tasya samādhi sthasya kā bhāṣā kim lakṣaṇam
translated: Thus, what is the speech, what are the characteristics of one whose wisdom is steady, whose intellect is firm?

original: bhāṣyate 'nayeti vyutpatteḥ /
analyzed: bhāṣyate naya iti vyutpatteḥ
translated: Because it is derived from the root bhāṣ meaning to speak by this.

original: kena lakṣaṇena sthitaprajño 'bhidhīyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kena lakṣaṇena sthita prajñaḥ bhidhīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: By what characteristics is one of steady wisdom designated? This is the meaning.

original: tathā vyutthitaḥ sthitaprajñaḥ kathaṃ bhāṣaṇādīni kuryāt /
analyzed: tathā vyutthitaḥ sthita prajñaḥ katham bhāṣaṇa ādīni kuryāt
translated: Similarly, how does a man of steady wisdom, when distracted, perform speech and other actions?

original: tadīyāni tāni pṛthagjanavilakṣaṇāni kīdṛśānīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: tadīyāni tāni pṛthagjana vilakṣaṇāni kīdṛśāni iti arthaḥ
translated: What are those of him, which are different from those of an ordinary man, like? This is the meaning.

original: tatra kiṃ prabhāṣeta /
analyzed: tatra kim prabhāṣeta
translated: What does he speak?

original: svayoḥ stutinindayoḥ snehadveṣayoś ca prāptayor mukhataḥ svagataṃ vā kiṃ brūyāt /
analyzed: svayoḥ stuti nindayoḥ sneha dveṣayoḥ ca prāptayoḥ mukhataḥ svagatam vā kim brūyāt
translated: What does he say to himself or aloud, when praise and blame, affection and hatred come to him?

original: kim āsīta bāhyaviṣayeṣu katham indriyāṇāṃ nigrahaṃ kuryāt /
analyzed: kim āsīta bāhya viṣayeṣu katham indriyāṇām nigraham kuryāt
translated: How should one sit? How should one control the senses towards external objects?

original: vrajeta kim /
analyzed: vrajeta kim
translated: How should one move?

original: kiṃ tannigrāhābhāve ca kathaṃ viṣayānavāpnuyād ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kim tad nigrāha abhāve ca katham viṣayān avāpnuyāt iti arthaḥ
translated: What should one do if one does not control them? How should one not obtain objects? This is the meaning.

original: triṣu sambhāvanāyām ////
analyzed: triṣu sambhāvanāyām
translated: In the three, in the possibility of...

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: śrībhagavān uvāca
analyzed: śrī bhagavān uvāca
translated: The Blessed Lord said:

original: prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha manogatān /
analyzed: prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha manaḥ gatān
translated: When one renounces all desires that are in the mind,

original: ātmany evātmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthitaprajñas tadocyate ////
analyzed: ātmani eva ātmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthita prajñaḥ tadā ucyate
translated: and is satisfied in the Self by the Self, then one is said to be a man of steady wisdom.

original: śrīdharaḥ / atra ca yāni sādhakasya jñānasādhanāni tāny eva svābhāvikāni siddhasya lakṣaṇāni /
analyzed: eva
translated: And here, the very natural characteristics of the accomplished one are the means of knowledge for the aspirant.

original: ataḥ siddhasya lakṣaṇāni kathayann evāntaraṅgāni jñānasādhanāny āha yāvad adhyāyasamāpti /
analyzed: atas siddhasya lakṣaṇāni kathayan eva antaraṅgāni jñāna sādhanāni āha yāvat adhyāya samāpti
translated: Therefore, while describing the characteristics of the accomplished one, he speaks of the inner means of knowledge until the end of the chapter.

original: tatra prathamapraśnasyottaram āha prajahātīti dvābhyām /
analyzed: tatra prathama praśnasya uttaram āha prajahāti iti dvābhyām
translated: There, he answers the first question with two verses, beginning with prajahati (he renounces).

original: manasi sthitān kāmān yadā prakarṣeṇa jahāti /
analyzed: manasi sthitān kāmān yadā prakarṣeṇa jahāti
translated: When one renounces all desires that are in the mind,

original: tyāge hetum āha ātmanīti /
analyzed: tyāge hetum āha ātmani iti
translated: he gives the reason for renunciation, saying atmani (in the Self).

original: ātmany eva svasminn eva paramānandarūpe ātmanā svayam eva tuṣṭa ity ātmārāmaḥ san yadā kṣudraviṣayābhilāṣāṃs tyajati tadā tena lakṣaṇena
analyzed: ātmani eva svasmin eva paramānanda rūpe ātmanā svayam eva tuṣṭaḥ iti ātma ārāmaḥ san yadā kṣudra viṣaya abhilāṣān tyajati tadā tena lakṣaṇena
translated: When one, being satisfied with the Self alone, with one's own Self which is of the nature of supreme bliss, by one's own Self alone, then, when one abandons the desires for trifling objects, then by that characteristic,

original: muniḥ sthitaprajña ucyate ////
analyzed: muniḥ sthita prajñaḥ ucyate
translated: one is called a sage, one whose wisdom is steady.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: eteṣāṃ catūrṇāṃ praśnānāṃ krameṇottaraṃ bhagavān uvāca prajahātīti yāvadadhyāyasamāpti /🔽kāmān kāmasaṅkalpādīn manovṛttiviśeṣān pramāṇaviparyayavikalpanidrāsmṛtibhedena
analyzed: eteṣām catūrṇām praśnānām krameṇa uttaram bhagavān uvāca prajahāti iti yāvadadhyāya samāpti  kāmān kāma saṅkalpa ādīn manaḥ vṛtti viśeṣān pramāṇa viparyaya vikalpa nidrā smṛti bhedena
translated: The Lord has given the answers to these four questions in order, from he abandons up to the end of the chapter.🔽All desires, which are mental states such as desire, conceptualization of desire, etc.,🔽which are elaborated in other systems as fivefold - valid cognition, error, imagination, sleep, and memory,

original: tantrāntare pañcadhā prapañcitān sarvān niravaśeṣān prakarṣeṇa kāraṇabādhena yadā
analyzed: tantra antare pañcadhā prapañcitān sarvān niravaśeṣān prakarṣeṇa kāraṇa bādhena yadā
translated: when one abandons completely, by the removal of the cause,

original: jahāti parityajati sarvavṛttiśūnya eva yadā bhavati sthitaprajñas tadocyate samādhistha iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: jahāti parityajati sarva vṛtti śūnyaḥ eva yadā bhavati sthita prajñaḥ tadā ucyate samādhi sthaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: then, when one becomes one whose wisdom is steady, devoid of all mental states, then one is said to be in concentration, the rest of the sentence.

original: kāmānām anātmadharmatvena parityāgayogyatām āha manogatān iti /
analyzed: kāmānām anātma dharma tvena parityāga yogya tām āha manaḥ gatān iti
translated: He says that desires are fit to be abandoned as not being the Self's attributes, by saying dwelling in the mind.

original: yadi hy ātmadharmāḥ syus tadā na tyaktuṃ śakyeran vahnyauṣṇyavat svābhāvikatvāt /
analyzed: yadi hi ātma dharmāḥ syuḥ tadā na tyaktum śakyeran vahni auṣṇya vat svābhāvika tvāt
translated: For if they were the Self's attributes, then they could not be abandoned, like the heat of fire, because of being natural.

original: manasas tu dharmā ete /
analyzed: manasaḥ tu dharmāḥ ete
translated: But these are the attributes of the mind.

original: atas tatparityāgena parityaktuaṃ śakyā evety arthaḥ /
analyzed: atas tad parityāgena śakyāḥ eva iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that they can be given up by giving them up.

original: nanu sthitaprajñasya mukhaprasādaliṅgagamyaḥ santoṣaviśeṣaḥ pratīyate sa kathaṃ
analyzed: nanu sthitaprajñasya mukha prasāda liṅga gamyaḥ santoṣa viśeṣaḥ pratīyate sa katham
translated: But in the case of one whose wisdom is firm, a special kind of contentment is understood to be indicated by the signs of the radiance of the face. How can that be

original: sarvakāmaparityāge syād ity āha ātmany eva paramānandarūpe na tv anātmani tuccha
analyzed: sarva kāma parityāge syāt iti āha ātmani eva paramānanda rūpe na tu anātmani tuccha
translated: in the renunciation of all desires? To this he says: in the Self alone, which is of the nature of supreme bliss, and not in the non-Self, which is worthless.

original: ātmnaā svaprakāśacidrūpeṇa bhāsamānena na tu vṛttyā tuṣṭaḥ paritṛptaḥ paramapuruṣārthalābhāt /
analyzed: ātmnaā sva prakāśa cit rūpeṇa bhāsamānena na tu vṛttyā tuṣṭaḥ paritṛptaḥ parama puruṣa artha lābhāt
translated: In the Self, which shines with its own nature of self-luminous consciousness, and not with modifications. Being satisfied, being fully content, due to attaining the supreme human goal.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ
translated: And thus says the Shruti:

original: yadā sarve pramucyante kāmā ye 'sya hṛdi śritāḥ /
analyzed: yadā sarve pramucyante kāmāḥ ye sya hṛdi śritāḥ
translated: When all the desires that lie in the heart are set free,

original: atha martyo 'mṛto bhavaty atra brahma samaśnute // KaṭhU / / iti /
analyzed: atha martyaḥ mṛtaḥ bhavati atra brahma samaśnute kaṭhu iti
translated: then the mortal becomes immortal, and in that he attains Brahman. (Katha Upanishad)

original: tathā ca samādhisthaḥ sthitaprajña evaṃvidhair lakṣaṇavācibhiḥ śabdair bhāṣyata iti prathamapraśnasyottaram ////
analyzed: tathā ca samādhi sthaḥ sthita prajñaḥ evaṃvidhaiḥ lakṣaṇa vācibhiḥ śabdaiḥ bhāṣyate iti prathama praśnasya uttaram
translated: And thus one whose wisdom is firm, who is in samadhi, is spoken of with words denoting such characteristics. This is the answer to the first question.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: catūrṇāṃ praśnānāṃ krameṇottaram āha prajahātīti yāvad adhyāyasamāptiḥ /
analyzed: catūrṇām praśnānām krameṇa uttaram āha prajahāti iti yāvat adhyāya samāptiḥ
translated: He answers the four questions in order, from he gives up up to the end of the chapter.

original: sarvān iti kasminn apy arthe yasya kiṃcin mātro 'pi nābhilāṣa ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: sarvān iti kasmin api arthe yasya kiṃcid na abhilāṣaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: 'All' means that he has no desire for anything at all.

original: manogatān iti kāmānām ātmadharmatvena parityāge yogyatā darśitā /
analyzed: manaḥ gatān iti kāmānām ātma dharma tvena parityāge yogyatā darśitā
translated: 'Mental' means that the renunciation of desires is shown to be possible because they are the attributes of the self.

original: yadi te hy ātmadharmāḥ syus tadā tāṃs tyaktum aśakyeran vahner auṣṇyavad iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yadi te hi ātma dharmāḥ syuḥ tadā tān tyaktum aśakyeran vahneḥ auṣṇya vat iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that if they were the attributes of the self, then they could not be renounced, just as the heat of fire cannot be.

original: tatra hetuḥ ātmani pratyāhṛte manasi prāpto ya ātmānandarūpas tena tuṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: tatra hetuḥ ātmani pratyāhṛte manasi prāptaḥ yaḥ ātma ānanda rūpaḥ tena tuṣṭaḥ
translated: The reason for that is: when the mind is withdrawn into the self, one becomes satisfied with the bliss of the self that is attained.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ
translated: And thus says the Śruti:

original: yadā sarve pramucyante kāmā ye 'sya hṛdi śritāḥ /
analyzed: yadā sarve pramucyante kāmāḥ ye sya hṛdi śritāḥ
translated: When all the desires that are in the heart are abandoned,

original: atha martyo 'mṛto bhavaty atra brahma samaśnute // KaṭhU / / iti ////
analyzed: atha martyaḥ mṛtaḥ bhavati atra brahma samaśnute kaṭhu iti
translated: then the mortal becomes immortal, and in that he attains Brahman. (Kaṭha Upaniṣad 5.15)

original: baladevaḥ / evaṃ pṛṣṭo bhagavān krameṇa catūrṇāṃ uttaram āha yāvad adhyāyapūrtiḥ /
analyzed: baladevaḥ evam pṛṣṭaḥ bhagavān krameṇa catūrṇām uttaram āha yāvat adhyāya pūrtiḥ
translated: Balarāma. Thus asked, the Lord gives the answer to the four in order, until the end of the chapter.

original: tatra prathamasyāha prajahātīty ekena /
analyzed: tatra prathamasya āha prajahāti iti ekena
translated: There, he says the answer to the first in one verse, beginning with prajahāti.

original: he pārtha /🔽yadā manogatān manasi sthitān kāmān sarvān prajahāti saṃtyajati tadā sthitaprajña ucyate /
analyzed: he pārtha  yadā manaḥ gatān manasi sthitān kāmān sarvān prajahāti saṃtyajati tadā sthita prajñaḥ ucyate
translated: O son of Pṛthā.🔽When one abandons all desires that are in the mind, then he is called one of steady wisdom.

original: kāmānām manodharmatvāt parityāgo yuktaḥ /
analyzed: kāmānām manaḥ dharma tvāt parityāgaḥ yuktaḥ
translated: Because desires are the attributes of the mind, their abandonment is proper.

original: ātmadharmatve duḥśakyaḥ sa syād vahnyuṣṇatādīnām iveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: ātma dharma tve duḥśakyaḥ sa syāt vahni uṣṇa tā ādīnām iva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that if it were the nature of the self, it would be as difficult as the heat of fire, etc.

original: nanu śuṣkakāṣṭhavat kathaṃ tiṣṭhatīti cet tatrāha ātmany eveti /
analyzed: nanu śuṣka kāṣṭha vat katham tiṣṭhati iti ced tatra āha ātmani eva iti
translated: If it is asked how it stands like dry wood, there he says in the self alone.

original: ātmani pratyāhṛte manasi bhāsamānena svaprakāśānandarūpeṇātmanā svarūpeṇa tuṣṭaḥ paritṛptaḥ kṣudraviṣayābhilāṣān saṃtyajyātmānandārāmaḥ
analyzed: ātmani pratyāhṛte manasi bhāsamānena sva prakāśa ānanda rūpeṇa ātmanā sva rūpeṇa tuṣṭaḥ paritṛptaḥ kṣudra viṣaya abhilāṣān saṃtyajya ātma ānanda ārāmaḥ
translated: When the mind is withdrawn into the self, being satisfied, completely content, with the self's own nature, which is self-luminous bliss, shining forth, abandoning desires for petty objects, delighting in the bliss of the self,

original: samādhisthaḥ sthitaprajña ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: samādhi sthaḥ sthita prajñaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that he is absorbed in meditation, his wisdom steady.🔽The author of the Medini says:

original: ātmā puṃsi svabhāve 'pi prayantamanasor api /
analyzed: ātmā puṃsi svabhāve pi prayanta manasoḥ api
translated: The self is the nature of a male, and also of a mind that has gone to rest,

original: dhṛtāv api manīṣāyāṃ śarīrabrahmaṇor api //🔽iti medinīkāraḥ /
analyzed: dhṛtau api manīṣāyām śarīra brahmaṇoḥ api  iti medinīkāraḥ
translated: and also in support, and also in the intellect, and also in the body and Brahman.

original: brahma cātra jīveśvarānyataradgrāhyam ////
analyzed: brahma ca atra jīva īśvara anyatarat grāhyam
translated: And here Brahman should be understood as either the individual soul or the Lord.

original: BhG /🔽duḥkheṣv anudvignamanāḥ sukheṣu vigataspṛhaḥ /
analyzed: bhg  duḥkheṣu anudvigna manāḥ sukheṣu vigata spṛhaḥ
translated: Bhagavad Gita

original: vītarāgabhayakrodhaḥ sthitadhīr munir ucyate ////
analyzed: vīta rāga bhaya krodhaḥ sthita dhīḥ muniḥ ucyate
translated: One who is not disturbed in mind even amidst the afflictions of the world, who is free from attachment, fear and anger, is considered by the wise to be a sannyasin.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kiṃ ca duḥkheṣv iti /
analyzed: ca
translated: And what is more, in the midst of afflictions, etc.

original: duḥkheṣu prāpteṣv api anudvignam akṣubhitaṃ mano yasya saḥ /
analyzed: duḥkheṣu prāpteṣu api anudvignam a kṣubhitam manaḥ yasya saḥ
translated: One whose mind is undisturbed even when afflictions befall him,

original: sukheṣu vigatā spṛhā yasya saḥ /
analyzed: sukheṣu vigatā spṛhā yasya saḥ
translated: who is free from desire for pleasures,

original: tatra hetuḥ vītā apagatā rāgabhayakrodhā yasmāt /
analyzed: tatra hetuḥ vītāḥ apagatāḥ rāga bhaya krodhāḥ yasmāt
translated: The reason for that is stated: Vītā, free from; rāgabhayakrodhāḥ, attachment, fear and anger.

original: tatra rāgaḥ prītiḥ /
analyzed: tatra rāgaḥ prītiḥ
translated: There, attachment is affection.

original: sa muniḥ sthitadhīr ucyate ////
analyzed: sa muniḥ sthita dhīḥ ucyate
translated: He is called a sage, one whose mind is steady.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: idānīṃ vyutthitasya sthitaprajñasya bhāṣaṇopaveśanagamanāni mūḍhajanavilakṣaṇāni vyākhyeyāni /
analyzed: idānīm vyutthitasya sthita prajñasya bhāṣaṇa upaveśana gamanāni mūḍha jana vilakṣaṇāni vyākhyeyāni
translated: Now, the speaking, sitting and walking of one whose mind is steady, who has risen from concentration, should be explained as being different from those of a deluded person.

original: tatra kiṃ prabhāṣetety asyottaram āha duḥkheṣv iti dvyābhyām /
analyzed: tatra kim prabhāṣeta iti asya uttaram āha duḥkheṣu iti dvyābhyām
translated: In that regard, the answer to the question What does he speak? is given by the two verses beginning with In sorrows.

original: duḥkhāni trividhāni śokamohajvaraśirorogādinimittāny ādhyātmikāni vyāghrasarpādiprayuktāny
analyzed: duḥkhāni trividhāni śoka moha jvara śiraḥ roga ādi nimittāni ādhyātmikāni vyāghra sarpa ādi prayuktāni
translated: Sorrows are of three kinds: those caused by grief, delusion, fever, headache, etc., which are internal; those caused by tigers, snakes, etc., which are external;

original: ādhibhautikāni ativātātivṛṣṭyādihetukāny ādhidaivikāni teṣu duḥkheṣu rajaḥpariṇāmasantāpātmakacittavṛttiviśeṣeṣu
analyzed: ādhibhautikāni ati vāta ati vṛṣṭi ādi hetukāni ādhidaivikāni teṣu duḥkheṣu rajaḥ pariṇāma santāpa ātmaka citta vṛtti viśeṣeṣu
translated: and those caused by excessive wind, heavy rain, etc., which are divine. In those sorrows, which are special modifications of the mind in the form of distress caused by the transformation of rajas,

original: prārabdhapāpakarmaprāpiteṣu nodvignaṃ duḥkhaparihārākṣamatayā vyākulaṃ na bhavati
analyzed: prārabdha pāpa karma prāpiteṣu na udvignam duḥkha parihāra akṣama tayā vyākulam na bhavati
translated: which are brought about by the previously performed sinful actions, the mind of the one whose mind is not agitated is not disturbed by the inability to remove the sorrow.

original: mano yasya so 'nudvignamanāḥ /
analyzed: manaḥ yasya saḥ n udvigna manāḥ
translated: He whose mind is not agitated.

original: avivekino hi duḥkhaprāptau satyām aho pāpo 'haṃ dhiṅ māṃ durātmānam etādṛśaduḥkhabhāginaṃ
analyzed: avivekinaḥ hi duḥkha prāptau satyām aho pāpaḥ ham dhik mām durātmānam etādṛśa duḥkha bhāginam
translated: For one who is undiscriminating, when sorrow is attained, he thinks, Oh, I am sinful, fie upon me, the wicked one, who am a partaker of such sorrow.

original: ko me duḥkham īdṛśaṃ nirākuryād ity anutāpātmako bhrāntirūpas tāmasaś cittavṛttiviśeṣa udvegākhyo jāyate
analyzed: kaḥ me duḥkham īdṛśam nirākuryāt iti anutāpa ātmakaḥ bhrānti rūpaḥ tāmasaḥ citta vṛtti viśeṣaḥ udvega ākhyaḥ jāyate
translated: What will remove this kind of sorrow of mine? — from this kind of regret, a particular kind of mental activity called anxiety, which is of the nature of delusion and belongs to the tamas strand, is born.

original: yady ayaṃ pāpānuṣṭhānasamaye syāt tadā tatpravṛttipratibandhakatvena saphalaḥ syāt /
translated: If this were to occur at the time of the performance of sin, then it would be fruitful by being an impediment to that activity.

original: bhogakāle tu bhavan kāraṇe sati kāryasyocchettum aśakyatvān niṣprayojano duḥkhakāraṇe
analyzed: bhoga kāle tu bhavan kāraṇe sati kāryasya ucchettum aśakya tvāt niṣprayojanaḥ duḥkha kāraṇe
translated: But occurring at the time of experience, it is useless, since the effect cannot be removed when its cause is present.

original: saty api kim iti mama duḥkhaṃ jāyate iti avivekajabhramarūpatvān na vivekinaḥ sthitaprajñasya sambhavati /
analyzed: sati api kim iti mama duḥkham jāyate iti aviveka ja bhrama rūpa tvāt na vivekinaḥ sthita prajñasya sambhavati
translated: Even when the cause of sorrow exists, the thought Why is sorrow born to me? does not occur to the discerning one, the one of steady wisdom, because it is of the nature of delusion born of non-discrimination.

original: duḥkhamātraṃ hi prārabdhakarmaṇā prāpyate na tu taduttarakālīno bhramo 'pi /
analyzed: duḥkha mātram hi prārabdha karmaṇā prāpyate na tu tad uttara kālīnaḥ
translated: For only sorrow is experienced through the karma that has begun to bear fruit, not also the delusion that comes after it.

original: nanu duḥkhāntarakāraṇatvāt so 'pi prārabdhakarmāntareṇa prāpyatām iti cet / na /
analyzed: nanu duḥkha antara kāraṇa tvāt saḥ u pi prārabdha karma antareṇa prāpyatām iti ced na
translated: If it be said that since it is the cause of another sorrow, it should also be experienced through another karma that has begun to bear fruit, it is not so.

original: sthitaprajñasya bhramopādānājñānanāśena bhramāsambhavaāt tajjanyaduḥkhaprāpakaprārabdhābhāvāt /
analyzed: sthita prajñasya bhrama upādāna ajñāna nāśena bhrama asambhavāt tad janya duḥkha prāpaka prārabdha abhāvāt
translated: For the discerning one of steady wisdom, delusion does not occur due to the destruction of the ignorance that is the basis of delusion, and there is no karma that has begun to bear fruit that would bring about the sorrow produced by that [delusion].

original: yathākathaṃcid dehayātrāmātranirvāhakaprārabdhakarmaphalasya bhramābhāve 'pi bādhitānuvṛttyopapatter iti vistareṇāgre vakṣyate /
analyzed: yathā kathaṃcid dehayātrā mātra nirvāhaka prārabdha karma phalasya bhrama abhāve pi bādhita anuvṛttyā upapatteḥ iti vistareṇa agre vakṣyate
translated: For, even in the absence of error, the continuation of what has been annulled is logically possible, as the means of somehow maintaining the body, by the fruition of the prārabdha karma. This will be explained in detail later.

original: tathā sukheṣu sattvapariṇāmarūpaprītyātmakacittavṛttiviśeṣeṣu trividheṣu prārabdhapuṇyakarmaprāpiteṣu vigataspṛha āgāmitajjātīyasukhaspṛhārahitaḥ
analyzed: tathā sukheṣu sattva pariṇāma rūpa prīti ātmaka citta vṛtti viśeṣeṣu trividheṣu prārabdha puṇya karma prāpiteṣu vigata spṛhaḥ āgāmi tad jātīya sukha spṛhā rahitaḥ
translated: Similarly, in the three kinds of pleasures, which are mental modifications consisting of the transformation of sattva in the form of joy, that are obtained through the fruition of meritorious prārabdha karma, he is free from desire, devoid of the desire for the pleasure of that kind in the future.

original: spṛhā hi nāma sukhānubhavakāle tajjātīyasukhasya kāraṇaṃ dharmam ananuṣṭhāya vṛthaiva tadākāṅkṣārūpā tāmasī cittavṛttir bhrāntir eva
analyzed: spṛhā hi nāma sukha anubhava kāle tad jātīya sukhasya kāraṇam dharmam an anuṣṭhāya vṛthā eva tad ākāṅkṣā rūpā tāmasī citta vṛttiḥ bhrāntiḥ eva
translated: For desire is nothing but a deluded mental modification in the form of longing for that kind of pleasure without undertaking the dharma that is the cause of it, at the time of experiencing pleasure.

original: sā cāvivekina eva jāyate /
analyzed: sā ca avivekinaḥ eva jāyate
translated: And that arises only in the undiscerning.

original: na hi kāraṇābhāve kāryaṃ bhavitum arhati /
analyzed: na hi kāraṇa abhāve kāryam bhavitum arhati
translated: For an effect cannot come into being in the absence of its cause.

original: ato yathā sati kāraṇe kāryaṃ mā bhūd iti vṛthākāṅkṣārūpa udvego vivekino na sambhavati
analyzed: atas yathā sati kāraṇe kāryam mā bhūt iti vṛthā ākāṅkṣā rūpaḥ udvegaḥ vivekinaḥ na sambhavati
translated: Therefore, just as the anxiety in the form of longing, which is groundless, that an effect should not come into being when its cause is present, is not possible for the discerning,

original: tathaivāsati kāraṇe kāryaṃ bhūyād iti vṛthākāṅkṣārūpā tṛṣṇātmikā spṛhāpi nopapadyate
analyzed: tathā eva asati kāraṇe kāryam bhūyāt iti vṛthā ākāṅkṣā rūpā tṛṣṇā ātmikā spṛhā api nā upapadyate
translated: in the same way, the longing in the form of craving, which is thirst, that an effect should come into being when its cause is absent, is also not logically possible.

original: prārabdhakarmaṇaḥ sukhamātraprāpakatvāt /
analyzed: prārabdha karmaṇaḥ sukha mātra prāpaka tvāt
translated: Because prārabdha karma only brings about mere pleasure.

original: harṣātmikā vā cittavṛttiḥ spṛhāśabdenoktā /
analyzed: harṣa ātmikā vā citta vṛttiḥ spṛhā śabdena uktā
translated: The state of mind called ‘desire’ is a form of the state of mind called ‘joy’.

original: sāpi bhrāntir eva /
analyzed: sā api bhrāntiḥ eva
translated: That also is a form of error.

original: aho dhanyo 'haṃ yasya mamedṛśaṃ sukham upasthitaṃ ko vā mayā tulas tribhuvane kena vopāyena mamedṛśaṃ sukhaṃ na vicchidyetety evam ātmikotphullatārūpā
analyzed: aho dhanyaḥ ham yasya mama īdṛśam sukham upasthitam kaḥ vā mayā tulaḥ tribhuvane kena vā upāyena mama īdṛśam sukham na vicchidyeta iti evam ātmikā utphulla tā rūpā
translated: It is a state of mind in the form of a swelling up of the heart, in the form ‘Oh, how fortunate I am, that such happiness has come to me! Who is there equal to me in the three worlds? By what means can such happiness as mine not be destroyed?’

original: tāmasī cittavṛttiḥ /
analyzed: tāmasī citta vṛttiḥ
translated: It is a form of the state of mind called ‘darkness’.

original: ataevoktaṃ bhāṣye nāgnir ivendhanādyādhāne yaḥ sukhāny anuvivardhate sa vigataspṛhaḥ iti /
analyzed: ataeva uktam bhāṣye na agniḥ iva indhana ādi ādhāne yaḥ sukhāni anuvivardhate sa vigata spṛhaḥ iti
translated: For this very reason it is said in the Bhāṣya (commentary on the Yoga Sūtras): ‘He who does not increase his happiness by the addition of fuel like fire, is free from desire.’

original: vakṣyati ca na prahṛṣyet priyaṃ prāpya nodvijet prāpya cāpriyam Gītā / iti /
analyzed: vakṣyati ca na prahṛṣyet priyam prāpya na udvijet prāpya ca apriyam gītā iti
translated: And it will be said (in the Bhagavad Gītā): ‘He should not rejoice on obtaining what is pleasant, nor grieve on obtaining what is unpleasant.’

original: sāpi na vivekinaḥ sambhavati bhrāntitvāt /
analyzed: sā api na vivekinaḥ sambhavati bhrānti tvāt
translated: That also cannot occur in a discerning person, because it is a form of error.

original: tathā vītarāgabhayakrodhaḥ /🔽rāgaḥ śobhanādhyāsanibandhano viṣayeṣu rañjanātmakaś cittavṛttiviśeṣo 'tyantābhiniveśarūpaḥ /
analyzed: tathā vīta rāga bhaya krodhaḥ  rāgaḥ śobhana adhyāsa nibandhanaḥ viṣayeṣu rañjana ātmakaḥ citta vṛtti viśeṣaḥ atyanta abhiniveśa rūpaḥ
translated: Similarly, he is free from attachment, fear and anger.🔽Attachment is a form of the state of mind called ‘desire’, which consists in the delighting of the mind in objects, and is based on the superimposition of beauty, and is in the form of excessive attachment.

original: rāgaviṣayasya nāśake samupasthite tannivāraṇāsāmarthyam ātmano manyamānasya dainyātmakaś cittavṛttiviśeṣo bhayam /
analyzed: rāga viṣayasya nāśake samupasthite tad nivāraṇa asāmarthyam ātmanaḥ manyamānasya dainya ātmakaḥ cittavṛtti viśeṣaḥ bhayam
translated: Fear is a form of the state of mind called ‘darkness’, which consists in dejection, when one thinks oneself incapable of preventing the destruction of the object of attachment when it is about to happen.

original: evaṃ rāgaviṣayavināśake samupasthite tannivāraṇasāmarthyam ātmano manyamānasyābhijvalanātmakaś cittavṛttiviśeṣaḥ krodhaḥ /
analyzed: evam rāga viṣaya vināśake samupasthite tad nivāraṇa sāmarthyam ātmanaḥ manyamānasya abhijvalana ātmakaḥ citta vṛtti viśeṣaḥ krodhaḥ
translated: Similarly, when the destruction of the object of anger is imminent, the mind of one who considers himself capable of preventing it is inflamed, and that particular mental state is anger.

original: te sarve viparyayarūpatvād vigatā yasmāt sa tathā /
analyzed: te sarve viparyaya rūpa tvāt vigatāḥ yasmāt sa tathā
translated: He is so called because he is free from all those, since they are of the nature of error.

original: etādṛśo munir mananaśīlaḥ saṃnyāsī sthitaprajña ucyate /
analyzed: etādṛśaḥ muniḥ manana śīlaḥ saṃnyāsī sthita prajñaḥ ucyate
translated: Such a sage, who is given to reflection, is a renunciant, and is called one of steadfast wisdom.

original: evaṃlakṣaṇaḥ sthitadhīḥ svānubhavaprakaṭanena śiṣyaśikṣārtham anudveganispṛhatvādivācaḥ prabhāṣeta ity anvaya uktaḥ /
analyzed: evaṃlakṣaṇaḥ sthita dhīḥ sva anubhava prakaṭanena śiṣya śikṣā artham anudvega nispṛha tva ādi vācaḥ prabhāṣeta iti anvayaḥ uktaḥ
translated: One whose mind is steady with such characteristics should speak words such as freedom from anxiety and desire by revealing his own experience for the purpose of teaching disciples. Thus the forward order is stated.

original: evaṃ cānyo 'pi mumukṣur duḥkhe nodvijet sukhe na prahṛṣyet /
analyzed: evam ca anyaḥ pi mumukṣuḥ duḥkhe na udvijet sukhe na prahṛṣyet
translated: And thus another seeker of liberation should not be anxious in suffering, nor rejoice in happiness.

original: rāgabhayakrodharahitaś ca bhaved ity abhiprāyaḥ ////
analyzed: rāga bhaya krodha rahitaḥ ca bhavet iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: And he should be free from attachment, fear and anger. This is the intention.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: kiṃ prabhāṣetety asya uttaram āha duḥkheṣu kṣutpipāsajvaraśirorogādiṣv ādhyātmikeṣu
